GAME: Pandemic Legacy: Season 1
RANK: 2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Awesome game for a play through. Good successor to Risk Legacy. The linear plot & co-opness keep it from having the same heights, but it also has a very high floor. Recommended for everyone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fantastic spin on the traditional Pandemic experience. Without spoiling anything, there are a number of changes that occur throughout the game that I think give it a fresh enough experience that should give even the seasoned Pandemic player something new to tinker with (and that's well appreciated). In particular, I think the Legacy system is really well suited for this sort of endeavor and in the event of a sequel, I wouldn't hesitate to pick it up. If nothing else, to get 15-25 games out of a boardgame which ran about $55 isn't bad. The opportunity cost itself works out to a series of evenings which have wondrous and fresh experiences, even if they do seem familiar. This is one of the few games which really ventures into new territory without dropping the replay value considerably (e.g. TIME Stories).

On that note, there are some problems which I think exist here that Pandemic doesn't normally exhibit. First, we find that the game is sort of tied to a group of people so if you find yourself gaming with larger groups and different people each week/month/session then this becomes a much more difficult sell. Second, while the game's Legacy component does overcome some of my problems with how Pandemic became stale, ultimately this game will come to an end, and when it does, it's less attractive than normal Pandemic as the expansions aren't intended for this (but someone might be able to finagle it, who knows).  So while I do like this more than regular Pandemic (at this time rated a 6) for the exhilarating romp through a new disease evolution which is unlike most other games, ultimately it's going to end and fall over to the memory pile so I find it difficult to rate it a 9 or 10 when it's not expected to live past the number of iterations or time span that my other favorites have. Second, it's not a game I can suggest for just anyone, it requires a certain group to play (although, with the right group, one of the fall months can be super funny).  Finding a rating on BGG sort of implies some sort of replay-ability, and after 16 games of it, I'm glad to be done. In that regard, I think P:L is a comfortable 7, maybe a strong 6.

RATING: 8
I had a lot of fun playing this game. The story was great and I enjoyed the way the game evolved over time. 

I was frustrated by my own rules mistakes (many many) which began almost immediately and I never felt like I played a full game without mistakes. (In a normal game you would get these rules bloopers ironed out over time.) I was also frustrated by things that didn't seem as clear to me as I would have liked. 

I would still highly recommend the game, just pay super close attention to all the rules, especially the changes.

RATING: 1
Three things: 1. I love Pandemic 2. I love Legacy games where the game state changes across plays 3. I'm not concerned that you can't play again once you've finished. So why have I rated this a 1? Because for me and my fellow player the game turned out to be broken. Three quaters of the way through a card was revealed that contains, with hindsight, ambiguous instructions. We followed these and ended up some plays later, in a terrible position. We were then presented with something new that made no sense so we checked the internet and discovered the card was intended to be read in another way. By this time we couldn't reasonably undo prior plays and there was no point continuing. So we abandoned it before the end with great disappointment. If we'd read the card the way it was intended I think it would have lead to an exciting conclusion. Very surprised this didn't come up in play testing, and we aren't the only ones this has happened to. So very disappointing for us. I've avoided going into any detail so as not to provide spoilers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Jan (win) : 2p.  Like Pandemic with extras.  Looking forward to the rest of this.  We were cruising to an easy win, but I guess we didn't shuffle enough because most of the blue cards ended up on the bottom, which delayed us finishing off the scenario for a couple of turns and made the ending tighter than it should have been.

Feb (loss) : We added an additional character to up the difficulty a bit.  It came down to the wire, but getting 3 epidemic cards in fairly quick succession were too much for us to stop.

Feb (win) : We got ahead of things early and cruised to an easy victory.

March (win) : We had three outbreaks towards the end, but still won fairly easily.  We have a very strong combo going through our characters and their upgrades/relationships.  After playing, I realized that we made it harder for ourselves by meeting all three objectives.

April (win) : We won, but the board got pretty ugly by the end with 6 outbreaks.  The plot twist was great!  Really looking forward to the rest of this.

May (loss) : Rough initial card draw, although we got ahead of things and nearly won.  Our combo is great for curing diseases but not so great for controlling cubes.

May (loss) :  I suggested to my wife that we switch up our characters and change up our strategy.  She was having none of it.  We lost again, but it was close.  We met two objectives and were very close to completing a third for the win.

June (win) : Won in an absolute nail-biter.  My wife agreed to switch up our characters/strategy for this one.  This has been my favourite month so far.  Great game and can't wait to see what the second half has to offer!  The state of our board isn't looking good since we've had a lot of outbreaks.  We've definitely made a few rules mistakes here and there.  I've tried to correct them when possible but I figure we've come out about even with rules errors helping/hurting us.

July (win) : This was a fairly easy win.  Favourable initial card draw for our super combo to come out.  The new mechanic that was added this month wasn't super interesting in my opinion.  I'm hoping that whatever is added next is better.

August (loss) : We got absolutely crushed.  Our three previous losses were close and came down to the wire, but this was one of those Pandemic games where the luck of the draw crushes you.

August (win) : This was the opposite of early August...a cake walk.

September (win) : Wow!  Crazy twist, but still a fairly comfortable win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2016-10-13
As of this writing we are approximately halfway through the campaign. At this point I feel that the game is really about playing the same Pandemic scenario over and over again. The Legacy thing just adds new game mechanics and rules after every round. And the pace at which the game evolves is fast. At first the changes felt exciting and opening the boxes and dossiers was like Christmas. Now I already feel like I couldn't care less. There is a tsunami of rule breaking exceptions flooding out of every box and it is very difficult to maintain interest in learning all of them properly. Your choices do not seem to affect the future too much. In other words, there are apparent no one way doors that would really make you agonize over your decisions.

The game looks absolutely gorgeous though.

2016-11-10
With three quarters of the game cleared I have to say that Pandemic Legacy achieves to do something many other co-ops do not. At least in our group there has been no single dominant alpha player. Instead the experience has truly been a co-operative one. Ironically this is due the fact nobody has been able to maintain interest in the events all the time.

Finally the first ghosts from the past have started to emerge as your earlier decisions begin to have at least some accumulated effect on the outcome of a month. Moreover, the mystery behind the background story has started to unravel. In my opinion it is quite late for this story arc to develop as the early to mid-game is more or less predictable basic stuff. 

I still do not think this is a bad game and I definitely want to play this through. But at the same time I am eager to finish.

2016-11-17
4 months, 7 sessions, 19 games and 20-25 hours (depending on whether you include the time spent on setting up and cleaning). That is how long it took for us to finish the whole campaign. Was it worth it? Hard to say. The game had its moments but in the end, it was still the same Pandemic over and over again. My primary motivation to keep playing stemmed from Pandemic Legacy being the current No. 1 rated game on BGG and as a boardgame hobbyist I felt obliged to go through the experience myself. 

In some games we had really really bad luck (the quickest defeat came in six turns) while in other games we felt invincible right from the start. So, the spectrum of luck in the game can be quite wide. We finished the game with a score of 541 points which I would guess to be close to the average. This is also in line with my gut feeling that we had average luck.

That being said, my final thought about the game is that our actions had little to no effect on the final outcome as our month-to-month success was mostly dictated by the luck of draw. Of course, the upgrades we chose during the game made the following months easier but still I did not once think that we had any kind of decisive edge over the fate that was shuffled into the two decks of cards. Perhaps the last two months were an exception when our highly debated decisions in November actually allowed us to win December in the nick of time. 

The standard BGG rating system clearly does not work with legacy games. I do not have any desire to play Pandemic Legacy ever again because it is a one time experience. This would be in line with a rating of 3-4. However, at the same time the game works well because it has the same tested and proved Pandemic mechanics running under the hood. Thus the game should be rated a SIX. In the end, I think I am more inclined to rate Pandemic Legacy a FIVE. I did not find the legacy mechanic to enhance the game enough to justify a playing time of 25 hours. This is primarily because your decisions do not alter the course of the game enough and there is only one way to finish the campaign. At the moment, I'd rather play a 60min game of the original Pandemic than commit to playing Season 2 for another 25 hours. However, I fear the latter is inevitable...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Two plays in and so far, so good.  To make the most of the game, I am writing session reports about each of our plays.  You can read them [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/blogcategory/3750/pandemic-legacy]here[/url].  WARNING: Those reports are heavy on spoilers.

So far, it feels like base game Pandemic, but even within the first game it began to feel like a different beast.  Just knowing that decisions you make in one game will have lasting repercussions changes the way you think about and play the game.

I'm looking forward to finding out what happens next!

RATING: 2
My wife and I love Pandemic but couldn't grasp the continuity of this game given the core games principles.  If you lose, the game makes it easier, and easier to the point where you open a box that completely cheats the game by eliminating epidemics.  Throw in the continuing complexity of the rules month by month and the introduction of zombies, I feel that there are other parts of the game that are broken. or I actually threw the game in the trash after a month 3 loss but pulled it out when my wife reminded me it was a birthday gift and that we should at least finish it given the money spent (she knows I am a cheap SOB).  So, yeah, we love Pandemic and look forward to getting "On the Brink" when it is released again but I don't ever see myself playing a legacy game again given the once playthrough and the strange, complex gameplay.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(No spoilers)

I was so excited to see the Legacy system applied to a game that isn't Risk, and it's every bit as awesome as I'd hoped.

I don't yet know if there's replay value after the main sequence is complete, but after what just happened in our most recent game, I don't even care.  Pandemic Legacy has already given me tension, excitement, joy, and shock that I've never felt in another game, and I'm bumping it up from 9 to 10 as a result.  This is my third 10 ranking ever.

Update:  We've finished our season 1 play-through, and I'm very confident in my 10 rating.  I don't expect to keep playing this copy, but it was so much fun that I'm okay with that.  I recommend this game to everyone, and I'll buy season 2 without a second thought.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like this game.  Pandemic is a nice game that is easy to teach, so it has made numerous appearances at the table.  My personal opinion is the legacy idea really helps Pandemic shine, giving any game a story is a huge benefit.  I love progression and variety, the plot really shines here.  However the added complexity is an actual downside to my family as we've gone from month to month.  I'm a wargamer so this game is not complicated to me, but I understand that it's bothersome to suddenly stop a game mid-session and read off 3-4 new rules and sort through some new game components.

Anyway I applaud what the designers have done here.  They've taken a decent game and created a wonderful game experience.  I won't rate this higher because once I've finished my 12 or so games, it's done and can't be repeated (without buying another set).  I'm very happy to share this game with my family, but I'm definitely not looking for more Legacy style games in my collection.

Postmortem: Well it took about 18 months but my family finished season one.  We liked it enough that we picked up season two, but I stand by the seven rating.  Now that I've finished season one, I never want to play that season again.  The experience was good, we could've played better (or had help from certain events), but nevertheless we know the story and there's no need to go back through it.  It feels weird to look at a game and think about just trashing it.  I'll hold onto the map as a keepsake, but everything else goes.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Was great fun for our group of 4 spread across 3 days of 6-8 play sessions each.  Improves on the basic Pandemic formula (which I'm not really a fan of) and breathes life into it with a story, stakes, and constant rule changes as the story progresses, giving you a slightly different game each round.  The damage caused by failing in a given month will carry over into future rounds and you're scored on your overall success at the end.  Enjoyed it and would definitely play it again with another group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The fundamental problem for me is that there is only limited and not very good problems and ways to play.

RATING: 9.5
Don't let anyone who has a problem with "consumable games" talk you out of buying this one ... it is a fantastic game.  If you like Pandemic, this game is a must ... but only if you can get 3 or 4 people to play the entire campaign through with you.  The game can be found, now that is over a year old, for less than $50 so you can count on about 15-20 plays, for an hour or so each, for that price.  

Find it, buy it, play it, enjoy it!

RATING: 4.5
Overhyped. If you LOVE Pandemic and play it regularly, this is going to blow your socks off, but it's not the end-all-be-all of gaming that it's been presented as. If you're already tired of base Pandemic then this is just going to be ~20 more games of that with some extra mechanisms thrown in. The Legacy content is more interestingly different than in Risk Legacy, but also less exciting.

RATING: 8.5
We haven't started the campaign yet, so this review is for the original Pandemic. 

This is one of the few games that if we loose, my husband will be willing to play again. So that tells a lot about how great this game is for us. I cannot wait to find a couple of friends to start the campaign with us.

I definitely love this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4

1st plays: This is a much better version of Pandemic than the original, because the little decisions that you can ignore in pursuit of the greater victory suddenly become meaningful.  I rate the normal Pandemic at a 5 or a 6, and this game is better.  So far though, the game hasn't lived up to the hype - it's interesting but not even close to the best game ever.

2nd play: The game continues to heat up with new objectives, additional player powers and a brutal infection deck.  It's still Pandemic though.  It probably replaces base pandemic for me, and I'm happy to play it, but it ends up being just ok.  I don't understand all the love it's getting, but maybe when we get to May or June I'll come to understand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ok, at the start it is exactly like Pandemic, but on the progress we've made the game is about to change a lot. I won't evaluate it proper until we finish our campaign, but it is a solid game for the ones who enjoy Pandemic. I liked the Legacy system a lot, it is really cool the way things get delivered to players as the game progress.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is not Pandemic, this is a fantastic adventure stuffed in a box which starts out as just Pandemic, but becomes SO much more. The story, the abundance of choices, the ripping apart of cards, the stickers... It all adds up and becomes a great game, if not one of the best games I've ever played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]no spoilers[/b]
[i]2017/05/15 - 9 plays 4 players - 6 victories[/i]

First legacy game I play, some conclusions:
- you need to really like the base game, because you are going to play it a lot. Fortunately, I like Pandemic.
- Because the ruleset evolves from one session to another, you really need to play regularly, otherwise you have to relearn the whole ruleset before a play.
- PL is the kind of legacy game that requires all players to attend each play. You could play without someone, but that would severely affect the experience (this is different for instant to Gloomhaven). As a result, we tend to play 1 game per month on average.

Otherwise great game, the campaign aspects definitely raises the stakes, and the legacy element gives a touch of finality to what happens. One of the players even had nightmares after the first play (a defeat).

As a result you pay a lot more of attention and give more thought to a play of PL than a play of Pandemic. I often was thinking about strategy before starting the game, which is great sign.

The funding system helps to regulate difficulty level of the campaign. So far our performance is within the difficulty range of the system, so the game was not too hard or too difficult for us. Very nice.

This is a great experience for Pandemic lovers, if you can keep a group playing the same game over a couple of months.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The Legacy concept is simply brilliant: you start with a small set of rules which is constantly increased during the "year", and the fact that the game keeps changing puts you in a constant state of suspense. Moreover, the materials are of excellent quality.
Having said that, it is not at all the best board game out there. Not by far. Too simple, and the sessions last waaaaay not enough. If you are a seasoned player you can finish a game in 30 minutes or so, which, considered the high price and that you can play it up to 24 times, it leaves you with a feeling of unsatisfaction. Having said that, I cant wait to buy and play Season 2...

RATING: 10
Pandemic is one of the best cooperative games, and the legacy version is much better.  The legacy format synergizes so well with the co-op aspect; your play group will bond as you work through the changes on the board and repeatedly experience the thrill of opening new boxes of components/rules.  If the last few months of play are a bit less exciting (they repeat a mechanic that gets a bit boring) than the first half of the game, it's only because those first six months are about as great a game experience as you can have.

RATING: 8
Un juego muy chulo: Super temático y sobre todo innovador. Un juego que ha marcado tendencias, como en su día lo hicieron otros. No ha sido el primero en usar el sistema legacy, pero si que ha sido el primero en hacerlo de manera rompedora.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I'm not particularly a fan of Pandemic. The base game feels like you could usually do anything you want for 90% of the game, and your actions are basically a randomizer for the last round of the game when you finally need to coordinate with the team a bit. It's fine, but there are other cooperatives that I think are more interesting to play.

I was hoping that Legacy would:

1) Add story
2) Fix the above issue

For the first, I would say...not really. You could probably fit all of the story text that goes into the game on one side of a single sheet of regular sized paper, in regular 12 point font. Stretched over 12-24 games, that's just not enough to be worth calling story. TIME Stories gives you more story text in a single play than all of Pandemic: Legacy, and TIME Stories puts 70% of their story in pictures, not words.

There's one major change to the map pretty early on and, after that, not much changes. The map change, once dealt with, no longer really effects how you play the game by very much for the rest of the campaign. So it's really only 1 or 2 plays, out of the 12-24 which feel like something different is happening. The other 90% feel like ordinary Pandemic.

A couple of times a side quest is thrown in after the map change, but the mechanism that the side quests use (which is reused for each instance) isn't terribly interesting, so I sort of discount that from the above statement.

As to the second want, an improvement to the cooperative aspect, it's hard to tell. A couple of times the game would slam us and force us to lose. It's unclear whether that was an aspect of the difficulty ramping up after a rule change or simply that we got unlucky with the ordering of the deck and the timing of epidemics. If the former, then I suppose it does occasionally jump out of its comfortable, overly-scripted game flow. But I suspect that regular Pandemic does the same thing, and I've simply not played it enough times to encounter the effect.

On the whole, I'd say that if you love Pandemic, then you might enjoy the tweaks that occur as you play this version. But it feels more like a few mini-expansions (with an emphasis on the "mini") and rules variants thrown into a box of regular Pandemic, than it feels like an unfolding story or anything different than you're used to from the base game.

Go for it if you love Pandemic. Don't worry about what you're missing if you don't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
While it's streaking up the charts, let's be clear that this isn't one of the very best games of all time. It IS, however, one of the best gaming EXPERIENCES of all time. The manner in which is extends and adds tension to the base pandemic experience is incredible, but so much of what makes it great is playing it with the same group and watching your individual experience unfold, discussing strategy and character choice and upgrades, celebrating the close wins and mourning the tough losses...the legacy format has legs and it is HERE to stay, and it is glorious. Those who can't fathom tearing up cards, prepare to weep.

After a campaign: without spoilers, I feel that the storytelling got pretty lazy late in the game, and it definitely ended with a whimper not a bang. Still awesome, but the next big legacy game (seafall?) is going to take over this #1 spot potentially (the pandemic brand might be the difference maker)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Puff. The game is good. I wasn't really sold on Pandemic before jumping to this game and the experience was great. I won't rate the experience of playing with the same people every few weeks until ending the season, even though it was really good.

If you already like Pandemic, this is a must. If you are interested in the campaign aspect, opening new content and shape your own map, you should look at this game. If you dislike Pandemic and you expect to play a way different game, look elsewhere. This game is and will be Pandemic with some minor or not so minor differences depending on the month.

It's not perfect. It's not the best game of all time. But it can be a great experience.

Now, my biggest critizism about the game are spoiler, so I'll tag them and strongly advise anyone to not read it if they think they'll play the game.

[o]The game has an anticlimatic final which kinda deteriorates the rest of the campaign. How well you did,
 count points, all posible epilogues are in one face of a card.
The plot twist is not very surprising, but ingame is way worse. Turn 2 one of our players was a civilian because of a random even any of us had control. It could have been done better, giving clues about the potential risk of the upgrade or something.
The story doesn't have ramifications. You have no decisions on all the story, you are just on your railroad until the end of the campaing where you will have one ending or another.
And having every search up to date, losing twice the same month and having some deux ex machina soldiers solving our mission when we only had that month to complete the last one(and was imposible due to bad luck) was terrible. And it wouldn't be relevant until the end of the game,
 where you will find that it doesn't matter any of your previous searches, because we could had ignored them all and the points would have been the same. And the difference is pretty big, we got the 3th one and would have ended with the best result if we could have finish that last search.

So yeah, until August, I would have rated this game with a 9. Liked September, but the final three months were a huge dissapointment. December was kinda cool, but not after seeing what a shitty way had the game to end.

A very recommended experience, but I think 7.5 is a fair rating. The game could have been so much better with a better finale and adding more player agency to the story in the final months.[/o]

RATING: 7
It's good, but it's not the best game ever made.

The legacy doesn't so much feel like a story so much as a series of consecutive games of Pandemic that get more cluttered with rules, stickers and tokens the further on you go.

Part of the reason for this feeling of distance to the story is that it is a cooperative game. As such, each person is playing exactly the same story, as dictated by the alpha player. So the games happens at you and, win or lose, you don't really feel like you made any decisions of consequence to the story.

Right now, my eagerness to get to the next game is overshadowed by my keen addiction to another legacy game that I'm currently working through, Seafall. I would say that, because Seafall is PvP and each person can play how they want, the story feels so much more personal and immersive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Fantastic so far, through April. Take Pandemic, but add a chaperoned story. It's amazing and worth the hype.

Edit: Finished the game in 16 plays (plus one ghost play that we ended up resetting because I forgot to open a box). In the end, it was excellent and I am even thinking about playing again. The middle rounds (from June to October ish) are a little flat, with not much new coming out, but some of the twists in the final three months are amazing and were great moments. Reading the November mission briefing was an amazing "holy crap" moment. Excellent all around.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Πάμε και στο πολυβραβευμένο Pandemic Legacy. Έχει βάση όλος αυτός ο χαμός και το hype? Να πω αρχικά πως ενώ μου αρέσουν πολύ τα συνεργατικά παιχνίδια, δεν είμαι φαν της απλής πανδημίας καθώς την βρίσκω αρκετά απλή και σχετικά παρωχημένη σαν συνεργατικό παιχνίδι. Παρόλα αυτά ήθελα να ολοκληρώσω όλη την campaign του Legacy ώστε να έχω πιο σφαιρική άποψη.  

Δεν θέλω να spoilάρω το τι συμβαίνει στο παιχνίδι οπότε θα είμαι λίγο γενικός αλλά θα πω πως αρχικά ξεκινάει σαν την απλή πανδημία και σιγά σιγά αλλάζει κάθε μήνα του campaign. Δεν έχω παράπονο από την παραμετροποίηση. Μπορείς να πειράξεις τον χάρτη, να αναβαθμίσεις τους χαρακτήρες να ξεκλειδώσεις καινούργιους, να επηρεάσεις τις ασθένειες, τις κάρτες της τράπουλας, καινούργια components μπαίνουν στο παιχνίδι, αλλάζουν τα actions, και άλλα πολλά. Το παιχνίδι δεν σε αφήνει σε ησυχία και συνεχώς πετά νέες προκλήσεις. :) 
 
Τα παράπονα μου έχουν να κάνουν περισσότερο με το backstory του παιχνιδιού και συγκεκριμένα με την μη δυνατότητα να επηρεάσεις την εξέλιξη του. Η υπόθεση θα προχωρήσει όπως είναι γραμμένη να προχωρήσει ασχέτως το πως τα πάει η ομάδα. Αυτό για μένα είναι φάουλ. Θα έπρεπε σε κάποια κομβικά σημεία να υπάρχουν διακλαδώσεις, αλλιώς πιο το νόημα σε μια campaign? Το αποτέλεσμα είναι ότι ενώ όλοι αρχικά ήμασταν ενθουσιασμένοι με το παιχνίδι, μετά αρχίσαμε να ξενερώνουμε όταν βλέπαμε πως στην τελική το στόρυ πάει μόνο του αγνοώντας το τι κάνουν οι παίκτες. 

Παικτικά επαναλαμβάνω είναι πολύ ωραίες οι αποφάσεις για τα upgrades και το ποιους χαρακτήρες θα πάρουμε μαζί μας στη κάθε αποστολή. Βέβαια συνεχίζεις να παίζεις πανδημία οπότε αν την σιχαίνεστε τελείως δεν νομίζω να σας αλλάξει άποψη η legacy εκδοχή της. Από την άλλη οι φαν της πανδημίας θα ξετρελαθούν. Ο Legacy μηχανισμός έχει να δώσει πολλά. Περιμένω κάποιο άλλο παιχνίδι να τον εκμεταλλευτεί καλύτερα. ;)

Προφανώς είναι καλύτερο από την απλή πανδημία αλλά μην περιμένετε παπάδες. Θα μπορούσε να είναι πολύ καλύτερο αν είχαν εστιάσει περισσότερο στο story κομμάτι του παιχνιδιού. Ίσως φταίει πως είχα μεγάλες προσδοκίες λόγο του hype. Γενικά πάντως αξίζει να την δοκιμάσετε. Είναι μια ωραία εμπειρία.

RATING: 10
Player: 2-4
Time: 60 mins

Your disease-fighting team must keep four deadly diseases at bay for a whole year.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
"Legacy games shouldn't count in the rankings," they say. "A one-time 'experience' isn't a real 'game,'" they say. "What, do you just throw it away when you're done?" they say. Balderdash. Pandemic Legacy took a riveting and enjoyable cooperative game and turned it into a white-knuckle narrative bombshell. Every game felt like we were doing the best we could, but we had no clue what to expect from the Legacy Deck. Blah blah blah SPOILERS, it was riveting and unforgettable.

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
Working together with my teammates knowing that everyone had, at one point, made at least one critical error in planning because of what we didn't know. Looking back on each choice and agonizing over our simultaneous best-choice-right-now agency and the very realistic dread that we-could-never-have-known drama awaited us at every turn. The permanence of our inability to play a perfect game, as represented in the scarring across the board, is very gripping.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
Like normal Pandemic, some games are simply unwinnable given how the deck is randomized. When the second card is an Epidemic, and the next two Epidemic cards from their respective stacks are, in fact, directly on top of each other, cities are going to riot very quickly, and then you lose. 

[hr]
Here's to "Season 2"!

[hr]
:arrowE: [size=13][url=https://play.spotify.com/user/jwilliamparkin/playlist/2mpa3GZqn4TfItRcjtrkXq][b]PLAYLIST[/b][/url][/size]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Anna was ready to sacrifice herself. She was so surprised when Ernie did. Now she has to just deal with being alive.

In short, this is how you tell a story in a game - this is how you immerse people in a world - this is how you make characters seem real and breathing. Not just by blurring real world consequences (destroying or modifying objects) with game ones, either - I think a lot of what works best here need not be in strictly Legacy format.

RATING: 7
A solid legacy game that admittely loses some appeal on subsequent play-throughs. A lot of the enjoyment and appeal comes from the surprises and strategies that develop as the game goes on. I played with two separate groups at the same time. I always dramatically enjoyed the sessions with whatever group was ahead. The other group wasn't as much fun because I knew what was coming, I knew what would or wouldn't work, and I felt like I had to be far less involved simply so I could avoid tainting the experience for the other players. If you play a second time, I'd recommend doing it with others who have played the game so you can share the same experience.

RATING: 1
The true Number 1 in the Bgg rank is Twilight Struggle and not this loathsome deception named Pandemic Legacy.

Everybody knows that Twilight Struggle is the best game in the last 10 years and it beats Pandemic Legacy in every aspect as well as Through the Ages, Caverna, Agrícola or Mage Knight do, but we live in strange times in which a game with only 20 plays and a worse concept by far can be brought to the top without merit.

In 5 years everybody will be complaining about the proliferation of different Legacies and perishable games and then this kind of games will not be cool and amazing anymore.

RATING: 9.5
Such a fantastic game! Offers a very unique experience with lots of surprises. To those concerned about only playing through this game once for $60, remember that's a MINIMUM of 12 plays, and a maximum of 24. Ask yourself...how many games do you own that are medium weight games, take 1.5 hours each game to play through, have you ACTUALLY played more than a few times? Those of us with huge collections I'm sure can point to a game we love, but have only played a handful of times. This game is made all the more special because when you complete the game, you have so many fond memories of what happened over the course of the game to reflect on. Amazing game.

The gameplay itself? Golden.

RATING: 10
Only on month one, but I am hooked.

Terrified and hooked! The game has many twists and turns and the legacy function really works in pandemic to make choices feel more important and have more debate around the table as any wrong move could be your last (literally!).

The changes really add to the stress and epic nature of pandemic, plus when all is said and done (provided you don't tear up any character cards) you have a base game of pandemic to play normally.

Eagerly awaiting February and dreading what could be behind some of those doors!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pandemic is one of my favorite co-ops. After playing Legacy, I've dropped the vanilla original to a 9 and Legacy is now the 10. It's a brilliant story-driven reimplementation and a natural fit for the Legacy system. I'd be sorely tempted to play multiple campaigns of the same season, and definitely looking forward to the next season. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Rég voltam ennyire kíváncsi játékra, és ma végre megadatott a próbajáték 2 db kétfős parti formájában, ami remélem csak egy hosszabb játékfolyam kezdete volt, mert ezt bizony több okból is muszáj lesz folytatni (okokat lásd később)!

Több, mint 850 játékot pontoztam eddig, és bár korábban több 10-est is adtam, a folyamatos átpontozások után egy ideje már csak a Caylus állt nálam 10-esen. Egészen mostanáig. A Pandemic Legacy ugyanis ezennel ünepélyesen megkapja a 10-est. Kivárhatnék még néhány partit ezzel a magas ponttal, hiszen még csak töredékét ismerhettem meg a játéknak, de már így is annyira átütő, hogy simán megérdemli. Így a kőkemény eurogém Caylus mellett egy könnyedebb coop játék is felkerült a képzeletbeli legfelső polcomra. 

Mi indokolja a 10-est:

Először is: a sima Pandemicet egy jó családi coopnak tartom (7-est adtam rá), de nem a legjobb coopnak (BSG, vagy Robinson sokkal jobb). A Lab kieggel már egy nagyon jó játék (8 pont), ha nem is kedvenc, de bármikor kategória. A Legacy viszont olyan magasan veri az alap változatot, hogy a 9-es már csak ezért is kevés lenne rá. Több, mint 2 pont a különbség.

Másodszor: A Legacy mechanizmust a Risk-nél nem próbáltam, így nekem totál új volt. Nos, szerintem lehengerlő, igaz még csak 2 hónapon vagyunk túl, de tisztára olyan, mintha minden egyes pályához egy külön kis kieg járna, ráadásul itt nem az van mint egy "normál kiegnél", hogy felkészülök a szabályából és hozzáadom az alaphoz. Itt menet közben tudok meg mindent. Én egy mezei promo lapnak is örülni tudok, ennek itt sokszorosát kapom negyed óránként. Már a legelső hónap is több egy kicsit, mint az alap Pandemic, de a 2. pályán már új (eddigi kiadásokban sosem látott) kellék jelenik meg, és nem kell nagy fantázia hozzá, hogy a többi doboz is rengeteg meglepit rejt. Szóval nálam/nálunk telitalálat a mechanizmus.

Harmadik: Ha a játékot nem érezném ennyire forradalminak, akkor is lenne egy dolog, ami miatt elgondolkodnék a 10-esen: a sok tulok miatt, aki kipróbálás nélkül csak azért 1-est ad, mert nem akarják, hogy a kedvencét beelőzze egy ilyen fura agyonhype-olt újítás. Nos én személy szerint pl. a Terra vagy a TTA elsőségének nagyon tudnék örülni (az új TTA elsőségét nem is tartom kizártnak valamikor pár év múlva), és a TS elsőségét is korrektnek tartom (sokakkal ellentétben nem zavar, hogy 2 személyes játék vezet), de egyáltalán nem zavarna, ha a P.Legacy lenne a top1, szerintem annyira unikum a top100-ban ez a stílus, és ráadásul tök jól is működik, hogy miért ne? Persze ha most 3 éven belül minden klasszikust kiadnak ebben a stílusban, annak nem fogok örülni, de erről még szó sincs. Kiadtak egy Risk Legacyt, még az a faék egyszerűségű játék is top100-ba került Legacy köntösben, most egy nagyon népszerű és ismert játékot adtak el a Legacyval, törvényszerű a sikere. Én egyáltalán nem érzem irritálónak, és a büntető 1-eseket baromságnak tartom ez esetben. Ennyi erővel azért is osztogathatnák az egyest, hogy valami csak a Star Wars téma miatt van elől:) 

Konkrétan mi tetszik a játékban:
-Nyílt lapok a régiben ha jól emlékszem opcionális volt, de teljesen oké, hogy itt kötelező: gondolom részben a nyelvfüggőség miatt.
-A kiegyenlítő mechanizmus rohadt jó. Ha veszítünk, egyre jobban segít a játék, a következő partiban több akciókártyát ad, ami önmagában is jó, de ezáltal még növeli is a paklinkat. Ha zsinórban sokat veszítünk, még van valami extra dolog, de nem tudom mi az, mert még nem vesztettünk. Ha nyerünk, gyengül és csökken a paklink.
-A játék magját adó Legacy deck nagyon szájbarágós, ami pozitívum, de még így is sikerült egy lapról lemaradnunk, pedig gyengébbek kedvéért direkt van egy emlékeztető jelző:))
-Vicces, hogy pont Adventkor kezdtünk neki, mert a titkos mappák pont olyanok, mint az adventi csoki naptár:)) A dobozok is jópofák. A kaparós sorsjegyek meg csúcs:) (Update: 14 parti után, végigjátszva az egészet már nem tartom olyan jónak a kaparóst, tök idegesítő volt ezzel szarakodni az izgalmas játszmának esetleg a kellős közepén, bár biztos van aki ezt halál izgalmasnak éli meg. Összesen vagy 10 ilyen kapargatás van benne.)
-A meglepik közül eddig a kedvenceim a folyamatosan kiderülő szabályrészletek.
-Úgy általában szuper a játékvégi fejlesztések lehetősége. Bár győzni jó dolog alapvetően, de ha néha veszítünk, többször fejleszthetünk, cserébe viszont a győzelemért járó díjazásról maradunk le esetleg.
-A térképből és a szereplőkból is sokat kihoztak, zseniális pl. bizonyos szereplőknek egymáshoz való viszonya, a plusz képességek, stb.
-Nagyon durván eltérhet 2 társaság táblája és szereplői már a 2. évszak végén is, ha ebből indulunk ki, végtelen újrajátszhatóságot rejt a játék.
-Nagyon fantáziadús, jól leteszteltnek tűnik, és rendkívül dinamikus.
-Nagyon játszatja magát, kíváncsivá tesz, mondjuk ez lehet hogy csak az első játék alkalmával van főleg, amikor még a kellékek se ismertek! Mi lehet a többi dobozkában?
-Nagyon nagy jövő rejlik még nemcsak úgy általában a Legacyban, de konkrétan a P.Legacyban is, kismillió fajta épület, szerep és mechanizmus található ki hozzá, nagyon kíváncsi vagyok, mikor cseng le a dolog.

Ami nem tetszik:
-A játékmód bár zseniális, de lényegéből fakadóan károsítja a játékot:))) Ez az én kényszeres játékféltésemmel nehezen összeegyeztethető. Nagyon sokat gondolkodtunk, hogyan lehetne megkímélni a játékot úgy, hogy közben a szöszmötölés ne menjen a játékélmény rovására. Szerintem némi munkával ez elérhető, de nem egyszerű! Simán elfogadom, ha valaki 20 partinként beruház egy új játékra, simán megérheti még úgy is, hiszen ha 4 fővel tolják, leosztva játékalkalomra és létszámra nem is olyan drága.
-Spoiler: a meglepetés másodjára már nem üt majd akkorát?! Bár ez szerintem nem annyira nagy gond, annyi minden van benne, 2 parti alapján úgy látom, hogy simán végigjátszható lesz többször is. A többi 850 játékban, amit próbáltam, semmi meglepi nem volt, a szabályban elspoilereztek mindent, mégse volt ez gond egyiknél sem:)
-Aki a régi Pandemicet a családi jellege miatt szereti az lehet, hogy csalódni fog, ez szerintem jóval gémerebb lett így. Ráadásul a nyelvfüggőség több szinttel nagyobb, de elég ha egy ember tud angolul a csapatban!

Összességében mindenkinek ajánlom, aki kicsit is komolyabban társasozik, függetlenül attól, hogy ismeri/szereti-e az eredeti Pandemicet, vagy úgy általában a coop-okat. Szerintem egy ilyen különlegességet mindenképp ki kell próbálni.

Majd 10 év múlva térjünk vissza erre, de én most azt mondom, egy korszakos játékkal van dolgunk.
---

7 parti után néhány megjegyzés:
1. Először is ketten túl könnyűnek tűnik. Egyikünk mindig az orvos, másikunk pedig a küldetéshez épp legalkalmasabbnak tűnő karakter. Már júliusnál tartunk, és eddig még szoros is csak 1-2 alkalommal volt, igaz volt olyan hogy hibáztunk a saját javunkra, de szerintem nem ezen múlt. Egyszerűen az hogy csak 2 felé mennek a kártyák és így könnyebb kifejleszteni az ellenszert, nagyon sokat számít, ráadásul az erős karakterek sűrűbben jönnek. Akkor lennénk bajba, ha 3 karakterre lenne szükség, bár lehet 2 fővel is 3-4 karaktert vinni, majd lehet hogy kipróbáljuk.
2. Olyan mennyiségű apró szabály zúdult ránk a hétvégi 5 parti során, hogy mi már el sem tettük a játékot, szerintem addig elől lesz, amíg be nem fejezzük. Minden nap nyomunk legalább 1 hónapot:) Ha eltenném 3-4 hétre, szerintem legalább 30-40 perc lenne belerázódni, hogy akkor most hol is módosult a szabály, melyik karakter mit tud, stb.
3. Egy játék hosszának kb. felét az teszi ki, hogy bontogatunk és ismerkedünk az új dolgokkal:)
4. Feleségem találóan megjegyezte, hogy ez a játék kb. Robinson Crusoe kiegre emlékeztet, annyi különbséggel, hogy itt közben derülnek ki a szabályok. Tényleg jó a hasonlat, mert ott is egymásra épülnek némileg a pályák, de a Robinson nehezebb azért, több szabállyal, és ha elvonatkoztatunk a Legacy módtól és csak a lecsupaszított szabályokat nézzük (bár még csak 60%-át ismerem a Pandemicnek) akkor változatosabb és jobb is a Robinson. Nálam az egy nagyon erős 9-es volt, a Legacy szerintem ha ugyanúgy lenne tálalva, előre ismert szabálkönyvvel, gyengébb lenne a Robinsonnál, sima 9-es. Itt tehát a meglepik +1 pontot jelentenek, kifejezetten a Legacy mechanizmus miatt jobb a Pandemic. Ebből következik, hogy nálam a Robinson Legacy lenne talán a tökéletes játék:)))
5. Nagyon játszatja magát a játék. Függőséget okoz. Kérdés, hogy ez a 12. hónap után is megmarad-e. 7 parti után én azt érzem, hogy nagyon is van létjogosultsága az újrajátszhatóságnak, pont a fentiek miatt: ha végzünk, akkor sem lesz kijátszva, egész egyszerűen lesz egy már ismert szabályú, egymásra épülő pályák sorozatából álló jó kis coop-unk, ami így "lelepleződve" is nagyon csábító lesz szerintem. Pl. szívesen kipróbálnám más létszámmal, vagy más karakterleosztással, stb.
6. A játék megmentése az újrajátszáshoz szerintünk nem gond, júliusig legalábbis sikerrel vettük az akadályokat:)
7. Az elején még családi, de egyre nehezedik, egyre több apró szabályra kell figyelni.
8. Ha bárki elkezdi, legyen vele tisztában, hogy ezzel semmi értelme 1-2 partit játszani, mert az elején még szinte semmi sem derül ki a játékról. Még most a 7. hónap után is (ami 4 fővel simán 10+ partit jelentene, 2 fővel csak 7 parti volt) félve mondok véleményt, mert vannak kibontatlan dobozkák, nem ismerem még mindig a teljes szabályt, és az összes kelléket. Az alapelvek jól látszanak az elejétől, de az hogy mit hoznak ki a szerzők a játékból, csak fokozatosan derül ki. Eddig nagyon elégedett vagyok, szerintem jót hoztak ki belőle.
---
Némi spoiler: a városkártyák szerezhetnek bizonyos plusz képességet (pl. az egyik eldobáskor +2 akciót ad az aktív játékosnak), és a szereplők közt létrejöhetnek bizonyos kapcsolatok (pl. 2 szereplő egymás eldobott kártyáit veheti fel 2 lap eldobásáért cserébe), így  megfelelő kártya+kapcsolat esetén nagyon erős kombó jöhet létre szerintem, 2 főnél legalábbis mi nagyon kihasználtuk.
---
Végeztünk! 1 hétig elő volt a játék, szinte minden nap játszottuk. Nos a 2. hónap végén adott 10-est tartom! Van sztorija, csattanója is, egyszerűek, de praktikusak a kellékek. Az alapjáték 8 akciójához képest itt a végére közel 20 féle akciónk van, emiatt sokkal kevésbé családi játék. Újrajátszhatóság kapcsán elismerem, hogy a sztori ismeretében máshogy csinálnék dolgokat, de ha új társasággal játszom, ki fogom bírni, hogy csak a pillanatnyi célokra koncentrálok, nem a 3-4 hónappal későbbi dolgokra:) Ha azonos társasággal játsszuk, akkor meg a játékvégi pontszám javítása lehet cél. Szóval szerintem többször végigjátszós, és megoldható, hogy fizikailag egy játékkal többet játsszunk, igaz ehhez némi scannelés/nyomtatás szükséges, és egy nagy fólia, ami a táblát védi a matricáktól:) 

---
Na lehet, hogy szentségtörés, de végigjátszottam még egyszer. Tapasztalatok:
Igenis van létjogosultsága az újrajátszásnak, főleg mert teljesen más szereplők kerültek elő, más létszámnál más volt a nehézség, ketten sokkal könnyebb volt, de azt is el kell ismerni, hogy másodjára nem ütött azért akkorát. Mondjuk ha most pontoznám, 8-as 9-es közt lenne, hiányzik belőle a Legacy-s plusz. Ezt a részét mondták azok, akik az egyszeri játszhatóságra szavaztak. Én erre azt mondom, hogy ez se rossz pontszám, de mivel ez 15-20 partit jelent szükségszerűen, max azoknak jöhet szóba több menet, akik nagyon sokat játszanak, mert hát sok más elől elveszi az időt:) A játékélménybe (nem csak itt érvényes) súlyosan beleszámít a többiek hozzáállása. Elsőre olyannal játszottam, akinek szintén nagyon tetszett, nyilván ilyen közegben szabad teret kapott a lelkesedésem:) Másodjára egyik játékostársam azért elég sokszor szidta a játékot, meg mondogatta hogy nem érti miért top1, a végén már unta, nyilván ilyen közegben nehezebb lelkesedni. Bár az is tény, hogy másodjára a hangulatot én is megöltem kicsit azzal, hogy a bontogatás izgalmát kiiktattam, és házi elemekkel rásegítve 5 perc alatt prezentáltam egy-egy olyan újítást, amit hagyományosan kibontogatva, ragasztgatva, értelmezve a történetet kb. 30-40 perc lenne. Ez nyilván agyonvágta kicsit a hangulati részt.
Még egy dolog: ha valaki csak annyit megtesz, hogy fóliát tesz a táblára és arra ragasztgat, és amúgy mindent tépked és ragaszt ahogy kell, egyedül arra figyel, hogy a város paklit és az infection paklit ne károsítsa (néhány lapot nem tép el, amit különben el kéne), akkor egy teljes értékű alap Pandemic-je marad a játék után. Csak úgy mellékesen, és nagyobb táblával mint a sima. Ja a szereplők nem lesznek benne, de az tényleg házilag is legyártható. Szóval nem értem hogy lehet kevesebb pontot adni rá, mint a simára:)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The modern classic coop receives the Legacy treatment.
Every game will permanently modify your copy, and after a few games, it will be unique.

For this game's comment, I need to quote user Hivegod, because he nailed it:
"This is an experiment in emergent narrative told through mechanical gameplay. The physical game is the engine that drives the story forward, but it's not the "thing". The thing is what goes on inside you, how it makes you feel, the stuff left over when all the bits go back in the box."

The stakes are so high, the experience so much involved... what a great, neat idea!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pandemic itself is a great game. Legacy, however, is not perfect and I prefer Iberia (and vanilla Pandemic) to it overall. Despite its minor flaws, Legacy does offer a unique experience that is above and beyond worth the price tag. 

In Legacy, you play a different variant of Pandemic during each month. We found some months to be more fun than others. Additionally, we interpreted some of the objectives as pushing us towards building the board in a certain way to mitigate the disease spread, but the game commonly uncovered a new rule to penalize that mitigation in a future month. To us, that felt like the game used simple design tricks to up the difficulty as opposed to more interesting ways of increasing the difficulty. We also got very unlucky when a twist from one of the summer months was triggered during the opening game of that month. That is not particularly Legacy's fault, but it left a bad taste for the remaining portion of that game and the next two games of Legacy. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Base [thing=30549]Pandemic[/thing] is a solid game in itself, but the Legacy element really adds a whole new layer to the game.
All of a sudden all your choices have so much more consequences. If you lose a game, you didn't just lost – most likely the board will have some bad changes that affect you for ALL your upcoming plays. That adds a level of tension to the play that really excites us.

In our very first game we had some really bad luck that (most likely) will haunt us for the rest of the campaign:
* We got our first city at panic level 2
* Half of the cities in Asia/Oceania are at panic level 1
* The medic has already 2 wounds and is in real danger to die

But none the less, our plays have been a GREAT time filled with joy, excitement, tension and despair.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

We didn't finish it that night (only made it through a third of the game.) I suppose that if it gave us 3 nights of play that is pretty good value.

RATING: 3
No way a board game that destroys itself while playing can get any decent point rating from me.

Also very odd: when I visit my gaming club NO ONE plays it, no one is interested and you all get negative comments...

While other high rated games are treated and spoken by with respect, this Pandemic Legacy is laughed at.

Clearly some internet stooges for the industry hyped it but the game is not supported by the opinion leaders in the local hobby clubs.

A strange case of orchestred hype on BGG. They like to promote disposable board games, a kind of Magic but with the winner tearing up cards (like MTG was supposed to be played at launch)...!

RATING: 9
The legacy aspect really spice up the game, you're more careful in every step that you take. I love all the post-game discussion, deciding on the game end upgrades. You really have no idea what curve ball is coming your way, there were so many WTF moments throughout. Game gets really tougher as it goes on, losing characters, gaining scars and getting more fallen cities. 

Finally completed the legacy experience on the 1st day of September. It had been an excellent journey with very good team mates. One of them appropriately described the game being light at start and gradually developed into a heavy game. There were so many things to consider at late game and so many information to digest. Our last ever game ended just one turn too early, luck of the draw affects the game but it's all part of the fun. I don't see myself ever replaying this as there's no thrill of discovery once you played through the whole game. Can't wait for Season 2.

RATING: 6
The first few games start off as base Pandemic, which is something that I can appreciate. However, the rules change ever so slightly every month, and with them come increases in missed rules, set up times, and time spent in the rule book. Opening boxes didn't turn out to be as exciting as cumbersome, and I was tired of fiddling with the game halfway through. The last month was really cool,  but it didn't make up for the slogs that comprised 2/3 of the game. Ultimately, the legacy concept broke what was most appealing about Pandemic: a shorter experience with concise and sensible rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Easily the most amazing game I've ever played. So immersive, it reveals itself like a great book or movie. Incredibly addictive. We played with three players and scored 753. We played the whole thing in two days, 9 games per day. 

Prior to playing, I thought I would have a difficult time destroying game components and making replay impossible. Once I got into it though, you quickly realize that replay is not the goal. The goal is to experience each twist of the story as you were really going through it. The play experience is increased by getting into the roles, naming the characters and the diseases. 

I can't wait for Season 2!

RATING: 8
I don't know about best game of all time. In fact, I don't even think it's the best Legacy game (I had more fun with Risk). It's very good, though, and it turns vanilla Pandemic's already satisfying puzzle into an constantly mutating challenge with many levels of decisions to be made. The best thing about it is trying to balance the group's desire to win the current scenario against the need to think about what will happen to the game state in future scenarios.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
April finished; we've had a lot of fun so far.

In the long run, I'm worried about the replayability and what to do with the game after the 12 months. I buy games for life and shun the disposability.

Before the first game, my intentions was to make a flow chart of the alterations in the game, but after the first game, it didn't seem like a good idea anymore. At this point, it feels like the game could have been designed to be replayable (of course, you'd know all the surprises) with flow charts, memo pads, and additional markers instead of stickers. On the other hand, I'm not sure if I even wanted to play this for another "year" (which would make me decrease the rating after the whole year). 

It doesn't really matter if you win or lose a game, since the alterations usually take place before or after a certain month, regardless of the outcome. I was expecting a tree-like structure; if you win a certain month, you'd get a unique permanent bonus, which you'd miss if you'd lose that month, and vice versa. In addition, I expected that all the roles would become useful in the game (like in Pandemic, the dispatcher is quite useless unless the medic is in the game) and I still hope they do. So far, we've played with the same (two) roles since the second game, and I don't expect this to change. 

So far, the spirit of this game could be mimicked with objective cards added to the regular Pandemic (which would be nice).

----------

August through now, my comments are still pretty much the same as four "months" earlier. Although, playing another "year" seems more probable now.

RATING: 8.9

It makes for a great narrative and I think it excels in the cooperative form of Pandemic. It is very much a different way of consuming board games but that is okay. Really enjoy this one.

Looking forward to Season Two :)

RATING: 7
It's an ok game, but I would personally say it is basically like playing Pandemic with a small twist, module each time and with a tiny bit of story in between and if you want more "story" you have to roleplay it more...
It's an ok to good game but definitely not an amazing one for me. There are plenty of games who offer more in all segments, from things happening, choices wise, mechanics wise.
I would just say Pandemic Legacy series is probably one of the best if not best legacy games out there but watch out in thinking that legacy element is true RPG. Not yet...

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Overall this is a campaign adaption of the already great Pandemic base mechanisms. Unfortunately the campaign mostly consists of adding minor additional rules to pandemic, which does only make the game more convoluted, while you still play 90 % base pandemic. 
On the one hand pandemic is a very well designed game and this game benefits from this. On the other hand the campaign adaption is pretty standard. Your characters gain special abilities, relationsships and permanent negative effects. Also you build stuff on the board and this and other stuff on the board can be destroyed. A negative aspect here is that the game is on purpose designed to be consumable, although this would not have been necessary. The special abilities, relationsships and scars could have been cards, which you add to the ziplock bag in which you store each character. The stuff you glue on the board, can be noted in a simple table. This lengthens set-up by about 1-2 minutes. Even the stickers you apply to the player cards, could be just put into the sleeve of the respective card.
Personally I also do not like, that this game is actually easier than base pandemic. It starts with only 5 epidemic cards and you mostly only need to cure three diseases, which makes the game maybe 60 % as difficult as base pandemic at the same epidemic card count. To counter this some mission like aspects get added to the game. These are sometimes fun, but overall not very imaginative and mostly it is only one kind of mission.
One other thing is the pretty boring story (Zombies and a conspiracy to gain world dominance). 
So overall: Base pandemic is better, this has the usual problems of campaign games, which get amplified by the game being consumable and it is mostly just Pandemic plus minor rules additions.
Would this be a normal replayable game, then it would be a 6/10, since you technically need to rebuy it, to play the campaign again I would be reluctant to play it again -> 4/10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Imagine playing a drama TV show that is what playing this game is like. The end of every game you think what is going to happen in the next episode. 17 great games. Can't wait for season 2.

RATING: 10
This game was absolutely amazing. It take Pandemic which was already a great game and adds so much to it. It adds an interesting story, it adds new features to the game as the story unravels, and you always have to think about how your actions will impact the rest of the campaign. Each time you get to open a box or you get a new card it feels like you are opening a present. Overall just a great experience. I played with 4 players and we played 17 games, with 11 wins.

I will admit that I played the game in a non-destructive manner. There were 3 different groups of people I wanted to play this with and I was not going to buy 3 copies. I used a lot of post-it notes and card sleeves to keep everything intact. I don't feel like I missed anything and it was actually fun that it was all our own handwriting. At the end we took pictures of everything if we ever wanted to look back at our board. I have just finished resetting everything to start playing with my second group. I am going to play passively and let them make all the decisions. I am really looking forward to playing this great game again.

RATING: 10
Lucky enough to have won this as a random commenter on Joel Eddy's favourite game of 2015 on Drive Thru review. Looking forward to our first play.

31/12/16 Update
The strange prologue to our amazing journey with this game is my wife and I had both decided it was too much of a commitment, so we reasoned it out and decided on Time Stories instead since it is episodic.

Cue to us getting to the end of our first game in The Asylum, enjoying it very much, when due to me randomly opening my mouth in the Drive Thru Review comments I was awarded the princely prize of the world's hottest game. Still one of the best emails I've ever received.

Now later today we will play our last game of this remarkable experience that has turned Saturday nights into Pandemic Saturday nights. I usually have to slightly persuade my wife to play a boardgame but now I find myself nudged toward the table as the hour draws near. 

20/08/16 - Finally got around to playing this. Great game gets greater. Really enjoyed it.

03/09/16 - After second February play this is now a 10. What a great game.

15/10/16 - Just passed the second May game and still really enjoying ourselves.

31/12/16 - Early morning. Later today we will play the final game. The world has changed significantly and the stakes are high. Some of our friends and enemies lie dead back along our path but we are ready. It is today.

31/12/16 - Won it at the 11th hour. What an amazing experience!

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Pandemic Legacy is a mixed bag (naturally). What I specifically mean by that though, is that some of gameplay variations aren't particularly good and those which are, are only good for the time they are introduced and would never make an interesting game by themselves.
Some are well integrated and stay with you for longer, but others felt like tacked-on, rng-dependent, boring minigames.


All in all the puzzles are enjoyable, because of their novelty and variation. The good ones stay longer and fortunately the bad ones were cleared by our group quickly. For me it shows that legacy games are not the bright future of gaming. In a legacy game you need way more content, which will be - by the nature of legacy games - not long with the group. As such they will usually require the mechanics to small variations or minigames, that by themselves will not reach the quality of the core game. At least that seems very unlikely, since designing a working core is hard enough.

The story is not very interesting; I enjoyed the overall plot, but I found the card text somewhat uninspired.

Character building is PL strongest asset. You become related to the characters and they become real characters with their own story. Mechanically their usefulness seemed very unbalanced, but this wasn't a big deal for me, since it's a coop.

Pandemic Legacy was fun overall. It is one the better coops in existence, because it offers a slightly different challenge every time, which forced us to think a little more than usual Pandemic. On the other hand PL turned out to be a too simple challenge, which a core group of ever-the-same, overpowered characters would rush through only hindered by extraordinary bad card draws and not by the in-game challenges.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
playing in game group.  group ownership, 1/4 share per person

First session 10/23/15

Wow.  

I enjoy Pandemic when playing with the family.  Really good game.  Haven't played with any expansions yet even though I own On The Brink.  Legacy takes it in a whole different direction from what I was used to without making it so convoluted that it would drive me away.  We are at April and I am always looking forward to the next play session.

This is a tough one to rate.  It is a really great experience and deserves a high rating but when you throw in the replay-ability factor it will ultimately have to take a hit because i don't see breaking this out year after year (actually instead of "breaking it out" you would have to purchase it and play a fresh copy)consistently because once you start a "game", you are committed to at least 18 sessions to play it through.  So, giving it a 10 seems wrong based on the accepted rating system.  Yes, it is a game I want to play at every chance, but only until it is completed.  Afterwards, I don't see having that same feeling about it. So it has to be rated lower.   

(update) Getting towards the end and the game experience is really starting to drag on.  The story is still engaging but playing virtually the same game 14 straight times is tiresome.  As well, there are a bunch of components (characters and items)  that got opened along the way that aren't getting utilized and probably won't before finishing.  The lack of replay-ability means that these components will never be used; there will never be an opportunity to see how playing those characters in different combinations would affect game play. 

Finished in 17 games. Finished with a win. 693 points.

RATING: 10
The perfect marriage!
To add some clarity to my comment. I enjoy original Pandemic and will play it with virtually anyone at any time. The mechanic and theme are well matched. I enjoy co-ops when it actually feels like the players work together. Yes, a player can "take-over" but it is up to the other players to tell that person to back down, since they probably don't realize how much they are doing it. 
When I first experienced the Legacy mechanic added to Pandemic, I fell in love. The narrative that grows with the plays gives each play through it's own feel, as if you've added an expansion. I would actually love to spend a weekend with a group of friends and play through the whole thing in a few days. It would be money well spent, about the same cost as 4 people going see a single 3D movie at prime time (in Seattle).

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
At the time of this comment, I am halfway through the game, having played 7 times with one loss.  I can confidently say that  Pandemic Legacy is very deserving of all the accolades it has received.  It is true that it is limited in how you can approach it - it begs to be played by a dedicated group of 4 people who enjoy co-op games.  If you don't have a group that wants to commit to playing the campaign together, or you simply don't like co-ops, this is probably not the game for you. 

For me, it has been perfect.  My wife and I get together once a month with another couple to play games for the day, and we have thoroughly enjoyed Pandemic Legacy.  Each "month" of the campaign brings a new wrinkle to the game that makes it a little more complicated, or changes how you play a little.  This makes each game feel new, but still familiar, injecting extra life into the game in the form of discussions of how you will need to handle the thing that is new this time.  These changes build on each other to result in a significantly deeper experience over time, which is also satisfying.  I have also enjoyed the way the game tells a story that is unique to my copy.  Those expecting the depth of story found in a book or movie will be disappointed, but I think it's just right - enough detail to help you be invested in the characters and outcome of the game without bogging down the actual playing of the game.  

I will say that I doubt I will buy a second copy or attempt to "reset" my copy and play through a second time.  Much of the fun is in not knowing what is coming up, and in guessing how to best use your end game upgrades to set yourself up for the next game.  Knowing how the campaign will play out would remove that, and I would have a hard time not using that knowledge.  I could see possibly re-running the campaign with the same group, but am hoping that Season 2 comes out before we need to do that.

Overall, this is one of the best games on my shelf, and I am very glad to own it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I want this game. Any suggestions on where to acquire this game in the far east ?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
WOW! Game of the year for sure. My wife and I have never had a gaming experience like this! It was edge-of-your-seat, cinematic, and full of surprises along the way. There were moments of triumph and defeat, frustration and excitement, and even times where it seemed like our fate would come down to simple luck.

We have played through the whole year. Went 11-4 playing 1 character each, and both of us absolutely loved it. 

My wife, who is not really into games, not only helped power through 15 games in around 2 and a half weeks, but often suggested playing. We also had really great conversations around what had just happened or what we thought was going to happen, which doesn't happen often with games that hit our table.

This deserves it's 10. Not because it's a fad, not because I'm cult-of-the-new, not because it's the new hotness, but because it's an excellent game that kept me coming back. I wish my season wasn't over but I'm definitely on board for season 2!

RATING: 7
About halfway through a campaign now. So far, I'm really liking all the legacy twists. The new roles, the upgrades, the permanent changes to the map... all this stuff is a lot of fun.

The story is not very interesting (basically it's just "disease keeps getting worse"), but that's hardly a dealbreaker for me.

The problem is that, in the end, the gameplay for each mission still feels too much like vanilla Pandemic. The twists are all cool, but then we just end up drawing cards and hoping to find five of the right color. That's still what it comes down to, and I just don't find it that exciting or satisfying a mechanic.

RATING: 8
Is it the hype?
Well, no.

Pandemic: Legacy brought the fun back to Pandemic.
It really pulls you into the game and you want to go on playing, you want to know what is happening next.
(Unfortunately the story twist in April, I believe, is a bit predictable.)

Unfortunately the game is much easier than what we played with Pandemic. You have only 5 Epidemic-cards and 3 additional Connections that change South-America and Africa from being a dead-end to being just a detour.

That's why we currently have a 6-0 streak, but we see the game becoming more difficult...so maybe we are facing our first loose in the next 2-3 games.

To be continued...

...and the day after christmas, the world was saved.
We got to 16 games (11-5) and eventually won.

Unfortunately there was a big mistake on one of the german cards that cost us a game. Without that printing error we would have needed one less game.
The game isn't the problem, I'm more dissappointed about the error. In a game where it is important when you open what there can't be such a mistake.
That really pissed me off...

The game really is an uncomparable experience (if it wasn't for that last minute turn-down).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's undeniable that the little boxes and evolving rules are very cool.   They add a sense of discovery and anticipation that most games can't touch.

To me, the greatest fault of this game is that it's still a co-op and at its core Pandemic (which I rate a 5).   Having to complete the same mandatory objective over and over again (at least through June so far) is somewhat tedious and still prone to the same problems that bad card draws can bring about in Pandemic.

So... I applaud the creative game design, but don't quite think any modifications to Pandemic could raise my rating.

EDIT:  July 2016:  we abandoned the game at July.   It was just becoming Pandemic with more pieces, which, to me, isn't a good thing.  Rating for pandemic = 4.  +2 for the cool idea of this game   = final rating of 6.

Opinión sin spoilers. Si te gusta Pandemic, esto es una versión mejorada y narrativa del mismo. Las mecánicas son una evolución de la versión básica con nuevos añadidos según avanza la historia que consiguen que las partidas no se vuelvan repetitivas.

RATING: 8.5
An amazing, intense, addictive gaming experience, one that I would gladly do again with a second copy (maybe in a couple of years). It greatly renewed my interest in my favorite game, demanding that each session be played differently from month to month. I loved everything about it... except for one: with two players, it was simply too easy.

We only lost two or three times total throughout the whole campaign, which is simply unacceptable for a coop game. I wish there had been a way to make it harder for two players. 

The best part about the In the Lab and On the Brink expansions is that they make the base game significantly more challenging and rich, with lots of more difficult and crucial choices to make. In Legacy, the principal difficulty was simply getting bad luck with the epidemic/infect cards. So in that way, it was really fun but ultimately less rewarding than the base game.

[b]TOTAL = 415.0/45 = 9.22[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POTENTIAL POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Pandemic is my best coop game, so a better version with a legacy story-driven campaign to it is an awesome gaming experience (this is how we must approach this game, as a gaming experience and not just a game, so the non-replayability after the campaign is more acceptable this way).
++ The legacy aspect to the base Pandemic game really increase the fun tension that was already present in the base game.
++ The evolving story of the legacy campaign, which leads to evolving game rules, increase the fun to solve the ever-evolving puzzle of this game (and really needs players to change strategy sometimes). 


:thumbsdown: [b]POTENTIAL NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- I hate buying a game that have a finite shelf life. You can play one full campaign of 12 to 24 games and then you're done with this game (you can no longer play it with the full Legacy experience). But, you can still play it as a kind of expansion of Pandemic afterward with your custom content though, which can be fun (I have still to play it that way though)
-- On the point above, I would have like that the designers would include a sealed envelope that would have official variants to play the game using your own unique board afterward (to mitigate the one time use aspect).
-- This is a lower value game (strictly speaking, because of the lack of replayability of the Legacy campaign), but still a great value gaming experience.
-- [i](Not a concern for me, but an important recommandation)[/i] This game should always be played with the same people and individual games should be played relatively close together (ideally at least a game every week, max every two weeks) to keep the additional rules fresh in your memory. 


:arrowE: [b]OTHER GAME INFO:[/b]
[b]
Game Weight = 2.8/5
Release Date = 2015
Number of Player = (1)2-4
2-player length = 45-60 min (playtime) + 15 min. (briefing and discussions) = 60-75 min.
Player Count Preference = Best at 2, probably great at 3 and 4 too! :thumbsup::thumbsup:
[/b]
