=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like Risk: Legacy, Pandemic Legacy gets a bit weighted down with a bunch of bloat by the end - tons of roles and event stickers you're just not going to use, but because of the in-game action for adding stickers to cards the game space gets unreasonably large. Then there are a ton of rules it's super-easy to misplay even if you're binging - scars are particularly problematic since the effects are often rare and easy to forget. It would have been better to retire certain game elements as the story goes through different phases, removing some complexity while adding some in other areas, instead of always just layering things on top of other things. The rules are a bit out of control by the end.

I really enjoyed about months 3-6, but like Risk: Legacy, it just felt slack and messy by the end and didn't use the storytelling potential of the Legacy format in all that interesting a way. I was also kind of surprised at how much re-use their was of stuff from previous Pandemic incarnations.

Anyway, that sounds a bit negative, and I guess it is because the endgame let me down a bit which is always a bummer. But there is still a lot to enjoy here, and I still rate it pretty highly. The Legacy style is inherently pretty fun. The bar to doing one of these things is still pretty high so we're not likely to see a ton of competition in the space for a while - we'll need another big printing cost reduction for Legacy games to be easy to do - but at some point they're going to need to get better.

---

Man, I hate to down-rate this after really enjoying the first 6 months or so, but wow, it's turning into a grind. After 10 games it's become super-complicated with scars, abilities, dual-use city cards, different travel rules for rioting, falling, etc. cities, plus all the special rules, it's super-hard to play error-free games. And the narrative energy has really stalled. I dunno. It's still fun but I really felt overwhelmed by dinky rules and restrictions. We needed more Matt Leacock, and a lot less Rob Davaiu I think.

---

(no spoilers in any of these comments)

---

I realize there is a certain futility to these running comments when the game changes a lot from month to month :)

So I'll refrain from further comment 'til we're done.

Well, except: we're really enjoying the heck out of it. And, pick your roles carefully, as I've mentioned. We've lost 3 of 9 games; one was due to bad luck, and two were almost certainly winnable with better role choices. While at some level the experience is what you're getting here, as with all cooperative games; but with the Legacy format losing too often will start to cause problems if the world gets out-of-control unstable.

---

6 games in. I think if you're hard-core Pandemic players and up for a series that will go 18 games, you probably want to play with 6 Epidemic cards. Of the 6 games we've played, I'd say two were easy enough to not be all that interesting, two were comfortable wins, and two were close losses. The group I'm playing this with is quite good, but not the best I play with.

Couple additional things on difficulty:

Sunsetting diseases is a big deal; the downstream effects of a couple early disease sunsets and easier cure abilities are potentially quite large (just look at those game-end stickers). If you're cruising through the early scenarios, sunsetting and kneecapping diseases, you might need to take it up a notch.

Role and relationship selection also has a huge impact on the difficulty of any given game. One of our two losses really was just down just to poor selection of roles at the outset. Ideal roles obviously change over time, but choose your roles for any given game carefully. Dispatcher and Medic are obviously indispensable until the rules change dramatically, one other role will probably be basically mandatory for the current objectives, then choose the last roster slot appropriately. Characters can die due to scarring; if you aren't careful and get a vital role killed: you were warned.

Relationships are also a fairly big deal, wise assignment of these can make a big difference. There are some obvious good combos (e.g., Scientist and Co-worker). Get them into play and don't assign them casually. There are some roles with similar functions (i.e., both the Researcher and Scientist make finding cures easier), so bear that in mind when choosing which roles to develop.

Pandemic: Legacy has been quite absorbing and we've really enjoyed it, it's gotten a classic game back onto the table. I can even see playing the campaign a second time sometime in the future, maybe with a higher difficulty level set from the beginning.

I suspect I'll have a few nits to pick once this is done, but I'll wait until then :)

---

Played 3 times. If you're a good Pandemic team, you probably want to consider snagging an extra Epidemic card from you base set and use 6 to increase the difficulty somewhat. We had a really bad Epidemic split the first month and lost in a close game, but the second two games were not that challenging. Depends on what you like I guess; I can see it being more enjoyable (especially early games) if you can cruise through the first few months, without having to worry about replaying, when not a huge amount is going on. I guess just keep that option in mind as you play.

As mentioned below, we play with cards held in hand, not open, which we prefer, but as always YMMV.

Anyway, we enjoyed this. We are hard-core Pandemic veterans - we've been playing since at least two years before the game was published - and have racked up 50+ plays or so on the base games and all the different expansions. At this point, the game was pretty played our for us and the most recent two expansions hadn't helped that much in terms of getting us energized to get it back on the table. But Legacy is great and we're psyched to play it some more.

Risk: Legacy was a great idea that largely failed to deliver on its promise and was ultimately pretty disappointing. At this point I have a lot more optimism that Pandemic Legacy is going to get the job done. 

---

A little surprised to see that the game nominally requires you to play with open hands. I haven't even started the season yet, but I would still suggest that you feel free to adjust to your group's preferences and dynamics. Playing with open hands does remove some interesting communication questions, and also can feed some tricky group dynamics. Anyway, you'll likely know what your group likes, so I'd recommend playing that way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[b]Won this on the G4GG geeklist. 
Special thanks to Vance :thumbsup:[/b]

RATING: N/A
If you win, less people die. What a cruel and bizarre theme for a "game". That it is one of the most popular titles and available everywhere is a sad testimony to the state of modern society; how will people feel about owning this when the next massively fatal and contagious disease hits?

I have nothing against science or reality based games - for a title which is far less morbid there is Stop the Germs (PNP): https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/142902/stop-germs and
Virus! https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/180020/virus

There is also Healing Blade:

https://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/179322/healing-blade-defenders-soma

Pandemic is a perfect example of what unfettered capitalism and mob mentality inflicts on all of us - there are many ways to make a game about the same subject matter (I live not much more than walking distance from the CDC and count many epidemiologists there as close friends) morally and in a way that respects life - in the case of Pandemic, simply changing fatalities to number of infections would be a start. Infectious diseases do not exist outside the context of global politics and society and Pandemic's crass and banal approach to the inequalities of our world is simply repugnant. 

It's also a poor game as pointed out by many other reviewers. Barnes and Noble, how I loathe thee for popularizing such thoughtless "games".

RATING: 4.75
To be noted: I have only played through the end of August so far. 

It's a good co-op. I would give the gameplay a 6 or 6.5. However, the nature of the game does not gel with my personality- being required to play several games of it in a short period of time makes me bored and frustrated at the same time. The problem is that the legacy features do not change the game substantially enough to feel like enough variety is happening. At the end of the day, you have to play the same game 12-24 times in a relatively short period of time. 

I find the legacy elements end up forcing the game to play you, to the extent where your choices don't have as much of an effect as it would have you believe. At the end of the day, you are on a linear path that follows the story of the legacy deck. It's like a co-op being run by a GM who takes into account our little decisions and shows us the little impacts that our choices make, but as a whole, is leading us down a story he/she has already created in it's entirety.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Disclaimer: I am a Pandemic nut. Pandemic is one of my all-time favorite games.  I think it's one got some of the cleverest design around, and I've played all of its expansions to death. Unquestionably Pandemic [i]as a system[/i] rates a perfect 10 for me.

Coming to Legacy, I was a bit worried that the surprises for veteran players would be minimal. That I'd enjoy the campaign play, find novelty in the Legacy aspect, but ultimately be employing the same strategies I had been for years now. 

Good god, how wrong I was. Without spoiling anything, I can confidently say that this game will make you think differently. You will push the basic rules you've come to know in very different directions for very different purposes. Some of this is due to new mechanics which require different lines of thinking, but I also underestimated just how much the campaign play would impact the basic experience. There's a whole new fascinating decision space to navigate, and even something as (previously) simple as selecting characters takes on a whole new cognitive twist. 

And what's more, the Legacy aspect only serves to make these dilemmas even more nail-biting. This game has real, true-blue dramatic and mechanical stakes.

I could gush about this game forever, but the point is whether you're a veteran or a newbie to the Pandemic franchise you owe it to yourself to play this game. Seriously, just get it.

Update: 01/10/16 - we won! Final score: 766. Thus ends the saga of Hank McChiselbeef Sr., AIDS McCancer, Dr. Doqtuer M.D., Col. Mustard, Lady Flibble, Whiskey Tango Foxtrot, and Jim "Needles" McGillicutty.  The fight against Avian Swine Flu, Sudden Poop Explosion Disease, Erectile Dysfunction, and Zambles is over. God bless us, every one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
LOVED this game. Loved saving the world.

Admittedly, I only ever okay-enjoyed the regular game of Pandemic. Legacy changes that- there's too many rules to keep track of, too many things to deal with, and it prevents the quarterbacking that the original game sort of led to. The changing board and story makes it really fun, and opening packages/dossiers is also just the highlight of every session. (We maybe cringed super hard on our first "destroy the card" bit though, because it felt so sacreligious to do so.) Highly recommend IFF you can find a group that can play it consistently and loves working together.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
NO SPOILERS:
My rating reflects my experience with the game. I played a full campaign with my wife over three days - not consecutive days, but in about two weeks. That is very fast for us and rare that we play the same game 15 times in a short period of time! 
The actual gameplay is of course interesting due to the legacy aspect, i.e. because the story is evolving, but I have to say that the challenge itself wasn't too hard and that was hugely disappointing. Tbh, the game is actually easier to win than regular Pandemic, at least that is our take as we won 12 of 15 games (and should have been 14).
Other than that, the gameplay was exciting and we had a good time, and that's what my rating reflects - but I'm not sure I would play it again (but when season 2 comes out, I'm going to be all over it!)

It has been an enjoyable ride, but I think my enthusiasm is also partly because I played it casually with my wife and we had a good time – so my rating reflects that. I think that if I were to play it again, my rating would be much lower as the surprise element would be gone… However, I’m not totally against trying it with a different group of players, perhaps as a 4p game with some of my friends. 

The story is not bad, but it also isn’t that great either – merely just “okay”. I did try to be enamored with the game, but couldn’t quite get to that point. I feel like something is missing, and the game could have been much more fun with more “wow” moments. If you look at Risk Legacy (no spoilers), I think much more happen in that game. More radical and interesting changes. The things that happen in PL don't change the gameplay as much as they do in RL. I think Pandemic Legacy could have explored that part even more, but I do look forward to season 2 and see what that brings…

RATING: 10

Update: first generic play with coworkers. I've got two coworkers that are candidates for the full legacy game, and one initial play is all it took to get them excited.

Update: We've now played through May, and my two coworkers are hooked. We started gangbusters, cruising through wins and are now neck-deep in hardship and pain... but it's a good challenge.

Update: Finished December. Totally worth it. If I never play this game again, I will still consider it a 10 and entirely worth the acquisition. I was impressed that the story arc was sustained so successfully from start to finish. This is truly a unique game design that deserves all the accolades.

5 game mini review: What games promised me when I was a kid. I will always draw a line between before PL and after PL.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm not finished with the full campaign yet, but so far it's so-so. I've played around ten games. I don't see why all the concern with spoilers yet. Maybe it's just having been more of a roleplayer, but there is barely a story. Granted it got my group to buy the game because we weren't able to watch a gameplay video since we were worried about "spoiling" it based on the reviews we'd seen saying it would be spoiled. Had we watched gameplay, we wouldn't have bought it based on the fact that it's pretty much the pandemic we already own. Another thing I don't understand is the need to make it disposable. I don't mind destroying components, this isn't about that. It's more that there have been campaign games since forever, and they all offer more change and story throughout play. This game offers basically the same thing from game to game, almost no story, but is a one-off play. Seems incredibly wasteful. I suppose I can recycle it when we're done:)

UPDATE: We continue to trudge on, Our group is getting pretty tired of pandemic at this point even though we've been really spacing out the games since hitting the mid-way point. We're determined to complete it, but I think you need to love regular Pandemic or opening boxes to enjoy Pandemic Legacy. If you enjoy opening packs of cards for CCGs, this will probably scratch that same itch.

2ND UPDATE: Still not done. We're down to our last few games, but we keep playing something else because while Pandemic isn't bad, it also isn't good. It's very mediocre and there are so many other actually good games that it's difficult to justify playing beyond for the sake of completion. I really don't get the worry about spoilers, there is practically no story in this. It's 12 sentences of story spread over 12+ games. I think I felt mislead into thinking it would be more than regular pandemic, but it's really not. It's the same pandemic experience with a couple modifiers that don't even do as much as some of the previous expansion material already released. Anyways, I'm dropping my rating from a 6.9 to a 5. I think my initial rating was built on hope of more interesting things coming out of the boxes but all I got was a variation on one of the most over-used tropes in all of board gaming.

3RD UPDATE: We've finally finished this terrible game. I never want to play Pandemic again, dropping my rating to a 4.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
*SPOILER FREE*

Innovative in its execution, superb in its narrative, and solid in its core, like Pandemic is. It all started interesting and engaging, and I loved the way things kept on unfolding. Around October game time however, I got really bored with the whole layered complexity, and missed the elegance that Pandemic stands for. I admire the design with its complications, and I am glad I had the experience, but I do not wish to ever play anything similar. Too much underlying repetitiveness for too little marginal enjoyment... 

For sure this is not the best boardgame ever, far from it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
A very unique experience. The only game I know of that can get equally involved gamers and non-gamers alike, begging for more! Plays very quick as well but there's a lot of things to discuss and decide as a team before and after each game. Believe the hype, this IS a true gem!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
(✿ ♥‿♥)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the best games out there becomes even better with the introduction of persistent elements that alter the game as you go. In our game, for instance, one of the disease strains became incurable within the first month. Yikes! Luckily, our crack team also grew in power, gaining new skills that carried over to future play sessions.

I've noticed that, while I enjoy the game plenty, it seems to fatigue my gaming partners, enough so that they're not necessarily eager to play again soon. There's undeniably a great deal of stress throughout the game, since outbreaks are always right around the corner. If you prefer your gaming time to be relatively stress-free, "Pandemic" games of any kind are probably not for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a weird 8, as I doubt I will ever play this again, but take the 8 as my "how much I recommend this to you based on my own virgin experience" benchmark in this case. It's worth noting that replaying this, even if you didn't destroy it, really wouldn't work well as knowledge of what is going to happen will almost necessarily lead you to want to make some decisions differently in terms of upgrades, character use, board alterations, and the like. For me, this one time, disposable nature is not desirable as such, but the value of the experience that you get in trade makes it worth it. YMMV.

Finished the game with a score of 764 with my gf, though IMO playing this for score is kind of missing the point; this is more of a hybrid between a traditional game and a narrative experience and I think it is best enjoyed by embracing that narrative and doing your best to advance that over worrying about winning per se or rushing the game for the sake of your final score.

Very much Pandemic, but I love how much the long term ramifications of your decisions can affect the game. Without spoiling, having to make decisions about what areas of the board absolutely must remain accessible, and how to upgrade your characters and starting configuration are very interesting.

This is a significant other game for me, and it's fantastic in that regard as my gf loved it and we got a lot of enjoyment out of it. I don't think it is anywhere near the best game ever, but it is certainly my favourite co-op by a significant amount, and I think the price for the unique experience here is well-worth paying.

My only real niggle with the game is that though the objectives make the game a good deal more interesting, they also seem to make it much easier in practice. We invested heavily in infrastructure to make the base objective easier to meet (by repeatedly eradicating and making the diseases easier to deal with) and as a result we have had the game become progressively easier as it has gone despite the increasing complexity and all of that. We did hit a bit of a wall midway through the game, but we were able to turn the corner quickly, again by investing in infrastructure / permanent bonuses, and then finished the game strong.

Overall I thought this was very fun and I loved the changing nature of the game. Though it maintained a Pandemic feel, the game managed to throw enough curveballs along the way to keep the flow going and to maintain my interest. I definitely plan to buy the Season 2 release.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Addictive like the best TV series. It is GoT of the boardgames: you start with suspicions, you finish the first game (season, if talking about GoT) with a  "meh...nice, after all" and by the end of game 2 you are struggling to play just an episode at the time. Our group is now half way trough the  first season, we decided we were just playing one episode per month and this is making us crazy, we avoid spoilers from the web and talk about strategies when we meet. Just like a good TV series.

...and we know when this season will be over we will be waiting for the next one, even if we say "we had enough" (I don't see this as a probable event!) we will be playing the next one. 

Maybe not my n°1 game by itself, I have more fun playing other kind of games, but the overall experience provided by this game is mindblowing, close to worshipping. Boardgamers have to try this, this is a milestone in game history
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Like Risk Legacy, Pandemic Legacy appealed me more than original - because of campaign feel and surprises. If the game would been made replayable like Voyage of the Beagle for Robinson Crusoe, I'd give it a point or two higer rating. But because of disposable design I simply can't - the game has absolutely no value after you finish it.

However, I disagree with the point that the game is completely rubbish because you can play it only once. That is simply not true because you will play it with good company at least 12 to 24 times and spend your time well. So the price per play is not too high.

RATING: 7
Excellent gaming experience that pushes the boundaries of what board games can be. Yes it's worthy of the hype. However, be warned this is still ultimately Pandemic. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Finished the campaign in 17 games. Final score 815. I really enjoyed a unique story experience. There's no denying that Pandemic Legacy is a significant step forward in terms of incorporating embedded narrative in an analog game. The Legacy aspect of the game will of course be controversial, but I 'm okay with it for what it brings to the experience of the game. However, I'll be curious to see how others  try to take this forward and work around the permanancy aspect of the Legacy concept. As the game stands at the end it is unplayable after the campaign, and I don't see myself wanting to play through the same experience again. Probably my biggest gripe with the game would be the confusion and play errors which can come from a constantly evolving rules set. (My rating is based on how I'm felt while playing the campaign and my likelihood to continue playing this style of game -- i.e. Season 2.)

RATING: 7.5
Early in the campaign, I would likely have rated this higher.  Obviously a well-thought-out design with interesting additions as we get further into the campaign.  We are now in June, and it just feels more fiddly the farther along we go.  Without mentioning spoilers, once you start losing, it can feel that you're so far behind the 8 ball that it's hard to come back - definitely not fun.  So for now, I'll give this a 7.5 - to recognize the great ideas in the game, but to also recognize that at this point it's feeling more like work than fun.

RATING: 9
Very, very, very good version of Pandemic.

The main reason for this is the scripting of the game (one to two play per month during the course of one year).

The second reason is the legacy aspect: your plays will modify your game forever (adding more cards in play, putting stickers on the boards, etc).

You can feel the pressure during each play session, the Legacy part is well thought and the game is just amazing!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game isn't for everyone.  It is a co-op.  With an alpha gamer, it could be quite un-fun.  It is a legacy game, so eventually it will be done.  And quite frankly Pandemic itself doesn't have a lot of interesting choices.  It isn't deeply strategic, and I don't see this really changing that all that much.

That being said, I really do love it.  It is an experience.  Will we look back at it as an all time great?  Maybe not.  But I hope that this will be another stepping stone in continuing great games.  It is a little like 24.  I loved the show.  It was fun and at just the right time.  Would I go back and watch it again and again like other shows I like?  No probably not, but that doesn't make it any less great.

[c]
Production  -> :star::star::star::star:
Fun         -> :star::star::star::star:
Play Desire -> :star::star::star::star:
Theme       -> :star::star::star::nostar:
Down Time   -> :star::star::star::star:
[/c]

Oh any why do I knock the theme?  Well it turns out that as cool as it is to name the characters and such, I just can't get into it.  The theme is there, but it just hasn't clicked with me yet.

RATING: 10
I have always loved Pandemic, but we weren't playing it constantly anymore. Hearing that it had been adapted to the Legacy model was very intriguing and I had to buy it. We were not disappointed.

Pandemic Legacy ratchets up the tension as you know every bad move can have an impact on future games. [NOT REALLY A SPOILER:]  Just knowing that a city having outbreaks can gradually become harder to deal with instills a real sense of panic which meshes well with the theme.

At this point we're just one game in, but I'm positive this is an adventure that we will be pushing to complete within the year. Like a good novel, there's a driving narrative that makes you want to find out what happens next. Exciting!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
A game that completely needlessly requires players to destroy it while playing? Let alone one this expensive? Horrible - no, thank you! It should not have been a problem to design/produce it in a way that the changes can be undone after the campaign and the game can be played anew. I consider the fact that it wasn't produced this way as impertinent. The fact that this throw-away game is the number 1 on BGG leaves me speechless. The requirement to literally break the game while playing could actually be considered as one of the definitions of a "clearly broken" game, hence a rating with the abysmal 1 might be warranted. Because I see some positive aspects of the legacy elements as well, I rate it with a 2.

RATING: 5
STATUS: Played

Designer: Matt Leacock  

Publisher: Z-Man Games

Price: 

Player Count: 4 (best)

Notes:

We finally finished our last game of Pandemic Legacy, and I can honestly say that I am glad it is over. With 8 victories and 9 defeats, we left the world in turmoil and it would take many, many years to recover from our teams failure. What started out as a fun experience soon became repetitive and tiresome. The experience was only uplifted by a victory or when the game changed direction. Will I be in line for Season 2? I am doubtful...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Rating Legacy games is tricky. Over the campaign, my enthusiasm ranged between a rating of 9 and 7; I'm rating it at the low end of that spectrum both because that's where I ended the campaign at, and because the game has been slightly disruptive to the group dynamics of several gaming nights.]

Just like Risk Legacy was still Risk, this is still Pandemic - there's a constant amount of puzzle spread out over N players - but the campaign elements do help distract me from that. There are some cogent criticisms of the concept in [thread=1498463]this thread[/thread] that I don't entirely agree with, but which are perhaps worth reading.

One modest design irritation: If your Funding goes to 0, Event selection simply... drops from the game. We'd house-rule it to a minimum of 1, but the difficulty was spot-on for us (we ended up going 12-3, but with many *extremely* close games) and we don't want to make it needlessly easier.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
We love this game. I love Pandemic, but the extra stress and story added by the Legacy system just takes this game to a new level. So many "aha!" moments and plot twists kept us wanting to play more and more.

We played two separate games with different groups, and it was very interesting how each of the games took on a life of their own. Even though we got ahead with one game, we were able to keep the secrets from our other group. And it was definitely still fun for us.

Even though we lost both of our last games...BAH...they were both awesome experiences.

We CANNOT WAIT for Season 2!!!!

RATING: 6
Playing with Kris, MJ and G. At the start of 1st May we'd played four, won four. Then on the 1st May we (appropriately) started playing our first game of May. A few hours later, we'd shifted to a played seven, won five record. The others refused a second attempt at June as being potentially "too depressing on a bank holiday weekend". Unfortunate when we got to November, a serious grammatical error on a card (that isn't in any errata) resulted in our playing three games and then having to revert back - a nightmare - which really irritated us. I can't give it a 10 when there's such a serious design error. A few months after finishing, reflections make me realise how little fun we actually had playing Pandemic Legacy. Although I’ve bought Season 2 (for someone else - NOT me) you’d struggle to get me to play it. Over time, my score for this went from 10 to 9 to 8 and finally to 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
A game that is suppose to be different every time you play, never the same as the last time. That sounds fun, right? That's what I thought, then I actually go the game and boy was I wrong!
The game tells you to glue additional rules in the rule book. Okay that is bad enough on its own but oh no there is more, it tells you to put STICKERS on the BOARD! What!?! And that is not even the worst part, it tells you that once a character dies in the game you then rip up its profile card, that right there just breaks my board game morals. 
I mean what if you want to take it to a party and the group there and you want to play from the beginning? Also once you have played it you can't sell or trade it because changes are permanent! I think that they either should've sold it for less or given you at least 2 of everything. This game defies board game morals and it is a game that at most will last for 1-2 years then you got no more stickers. So it's a lose on the money, it's a lose on the fun, it's a lose on the board game morals, it's a lose on quantity AND it is a lose on lasting for a long time! 
My advise, save your money and buy a different game, and if you have the game and it doesn't have permanent changes then trade it or sell it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game takes everything that you get from standard Pandemic and adds in an exciting, tense, and sometimes frustrating ongoing story. The ability to develop your own character over the course of the game and the timing of the changes to the story and diseases is well thought out and effective at engaging players. The knocks against this game would be mostly similar to those of normal Pandemic and are in my opinion offset in score by the engrossing campaign. What does hurt Pandemic Legacy, and only does so slightly, is that after the complete playthrough of the campaign, the excitement of some of the reveals is not as strong and some of the stress is diminished.

RATING: 1
SPOILERS!! This game is a rip off. They have you destroy is contents and make resale/replay impossible. It has boxes that contain game pieces that you can't reseal. If you look at games like harry potter Hogwarts battle you can see there are other ways to package game box contents so that they are resealable. You can also direct people to put one time use contents back in the box after they are used instead of ripping them apart. The rules for later games are done on stickers that you stick in the instruction manual which in other games are done by a small sheet of paper and a slip pouch inside the manual. The game board also gets stickered up rendering it also useless for future games which every other game does by removable tokens. And when you actually do waste your money on this game you find out that, surprise it's just yet another zombie board game(when there are much better zombie games out there). This game is a cash grab and you are better off spending money on basically any other game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My friend Brett and I just saved the world.  You're welcome.

This was not the narrative wonder I had expected, based on some very enthusiastic reviews.  The story is lightweight and not especially surprising if you're versed in genre conventions, and there's also no real branching; though the decisions you make during gameplay affect your future games, they don't change the overall arc.

For me, the compelling aspect was the way new rules were incrementally doled out in dossiers and boxes.  Opening each one was exciting, a little dip into the unknown, and making permanent changes to the board and decks was a lot of fun.  It was this, rather than the storyline, that kept me coming back with enthusiasm each time.  We played 14 games over five sessions in just under a month, and though I'm not the biggest fan of regular Pandemic, I enjoyed each one and looked forward to more.

The ending was a bit of a fizzer.  Due to good board management in prior games and a spot of luck, the finale was the easiest we played.

Overall, it's fun.  It's compelling.  I'm glad I experienced it.

It also leaves me really excited for what Legacy games might do next.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played 1 full season.
Was fun at first but the game started dragging at around May-July. The last few months got tense again due to some plot twists and we barely finished off the season with a  decent score. I don't think I like Pandemic the game very much but I did like Pandemic Legacy. This is due to a number of reasons:

1) The game encourages group commitment. My game group wanted to come back week after week to see what happens next. If I just hosted a regular board game night, I don't think I would have gotten this level of commitment.

2) Slow ramp up of complexity. It's a natural tendency to want to see all that a game has to offer up front. Especially since the "starter" version of a game tends to be a boring tutorial that misses the meat of the game, what makes it really fun (looking at you Agricola!). However this can also be really exhausting, trying to look up and remember all of the rules. When the rules are introduced slowly, it's easier to remember them. We still made some rules goofs though, because it did get to a point where there was maybe too much stuff to remember. 

Towards the end of the year it was better because some rules basically fell out of the game, so it was easier to keep track of everything. 

Cons: Lots of unclear rules in the rulebook (and stickers) maybe due to limited space? It was tricky to look up answers without getting spoilers too. Very easy to play something wrong and it's kind of a damper on your campaign, because your group thinks "did we really deserve that win/loss?" But most of the time, these small rules issues aren't a big deal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still sitting on the shelf, waiting to be played. I'm very interested to play this, but want to have a fixed group for the whole series. Will most likely be a 2p experience, which may prove to be too easy.

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I loved Pandemic.  Past-tense.  It was just the same thing, over and over and over... and over.  After a while, it just was too samey.  But those first few experiences of figuring out the game, then trying to figure out how to attack it on the most difficult setting was a fantastic experience.  But it got stale.  

So take those first experiences, where there's a novel challenge that you have to figure out.  That is what this game is.  It evolves as you play, and your play has to adapt in order to keep up.  Brilliant.

I really enjoyed Risk Legacy (even though we never finished it).  But I don't like Risk--it was the Legacy aspect that intrigued me.  Now there is a Legacy game based on a game I adore: Pandemic.  The one thing I didn't like about Pandemic has been remedied.  Now I will argue that it is a perfect game--and I don't say that lightly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
Being at the November game atm, I'll write a few words about the game but won't give it a rating until I've fully played it.

So far:
Pretty good game, but (for me at least) it isn't the holy grail it seems to be praised as ever so often. It's still Pandemic, albeit significantly updated (and thus more fun). To be honest, I can't really fault Pandemic Legacy for being what it is; because it is a very good version of a game I sadly find to be rather stale - and that's also kind of the problem I have with it. That and obviously the price tag and no replayability. You might say it's good value-for-money to play at least 12 games of it, and while I agree and even like the idea of legacy games, I hate thinking about how I'll finish it and then it's...done. No finding the game at the bottom of your collection after years and getting excited about it again, no gifting or selling it when it's done; it just sounds wrong.

Would rate it 8/10 as of now, most of it because of the fun we had being stupid and immature while naming things.

Update: after winning the October game, more than a year passed without playing Pandemic Legacy getting any play. Not because there was no opportunity to play it but because nobody was really interested in continuing it.

RATING: 8
[19 Jan 2016]
This is by far one of the best games that I've played. It's a role-playing game in a box that doesn't feel like a fantasy role playing game. The mechanics feel balanced enough for the casual gamer but has enough surprises for the experienced player as well. The only problem, and reason it's not a 10, is that the game eventually has to end. Once we make it through the months, the game will be stuck until we buy the next season. 

[28 Feb 2016]
Dropped the rating 1/2 point after getting into August. I question whether or not I'll pull out the legacy board after a full year and play Pandemic from that point or if I'll just gravitate back towards the original game. For this reason, I had to drop the rating.

[28 Mar 2016]
I think '8' is the final rating for this game. The story line made possible with the legacy elements is wonderful and keeps the game fresh; the big reveal in Sept was awesome. Why not a higher rating? To experience the legacy storyline you end up playing a game of Pandemic every time, win or lose. After three months of Pandemic, I'm a little burnt out on Pandemic. Combined with the lack of replayability, the game isn't perfect. It's not one to keep  long term but it sure was a hell of a good time in 2016.

RATING: 10
I went into this game skeptical. While I enjoy pandemic occasionally, and was intrigued by the legacy aspects, I wasn't really sure I could stomach the swingy nature of the games difficulty (I find some of the "you're just screwed" games to be quite frustrating). 

After playing 6 games, I've gotten so engrossed I don't even care. I had worries about a few bad games destroying our board to the point of being unwinnable, but it hasn't happened despite having some very tough games (only one loss thus far, though).

A lot of my preconceived ideas about the game (I did minimal research because surprises are fun) weren't quite right, but everything has surpassed expectations.

If you can get a dedicated group to sit and play through this game, it is well worth the effort. I'm hooked.

RATING: 10

When you're instructed, in the middle of the FIRST GAME, to destroy a component, you realize that you're in this thing, there's no going back, and by God, you're going to see it through to the end. I would definitely pay full retail for this game again and play it through again . . . just not in a 24-hour period.

If you like Pandemic, you will love this game.

RATING: 7
Yep. It's all justified. (er... not so much... see edits below...)

In two sessions I went from "a legacy version of a game I'm not crazy about is still just a game I'm not crazy about," to all-in, all other games on hold. When the f is season 2?

Edit: And we never played it again after "May". Every gamer I know has started it, all have liked or loved it, none have finished it. Every once in a while we open the box, realize what it would take to get back into it, and close it again. If you don't have a dedicated game table where you can leave a game out for a month or two, I wouldn't recommend it.

Edit: Finally finished, solo. By the end it was a chore. Also, I guess I lost by forfeit. I got a new rule wrong on my last two plays and made the game way too easy on myself. Of course there's no way to backtrack or to correct my mistake. So, after all that effort, it's over, it wasn't particularly fun, and there is little to no sense of accomplishment. The only satisfaction is mostly just relief that it’s over.

I've heard friends say they have had the same problem. [i]It is very, very difficult to keep the rules straight in a familiar game when they are changing every time you play.[/i]

I still have to give it a solid 7, although the fact that I would NEVER play it again, even if the opportunity presented itself, suggests a lower score ld be appropriate. (Does that mean it wasThereare good movies you would never want to see again...) 

Bottom line for me, if you're new to gaming and don't have a lot of games you love to play, this may be a great experience. But if you have more great games you're dying to get to the table than you can actually play, like me, PL may prove a distraction, a nuisance and ultimately a letdown.

RATING: 10
This game takes pandemic in a whole new direction while still keeping true to the essence of pandemic.  Every month my group wants to know what comes next, what new mechanics/story developments will happen.  

The game is filled with self-balancing mechanics (funding/upgrades) to keep the game at just the right level of difficulty for each play group; although I would still recommend most of the players play normal pandemic.

I have to say, the first time I had to place a sticker, my heart wrenched.  And then the first time I read, "Destroy this card"...  I had to think long and hard.  Now we spend a great deal of time trying to think of clever new ways to destroy each card.  So far: tearing, burning, shredding, eating, and soaking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The legacy implementation fits this game very well. Permanent changes give the game a narrative quality, and add tension because players feel more invested in the extended experience. The game is self-handicapping, so a team that does poorly has a better chance to win next game, and vice versa.

While a copy of the game could be played with different team members, the experience is best if played all the way through with the same players. That does limit the audience a little bit. The game is very good, but it will be interesting to see long-term opinions after groups have completed the experience and moved on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

beautifully put together game tells a good story for a board game unlikely to disappoint anyone who has played the base game before

I think I got this from my secret santa 2015, but I got no note, or taunt.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So, it's still pandemic.  I've had plenty of people, myself included, say that the base game was getting kind of stale, and that they weren't sure there was enough there to build a legacy game off of.  Others hate the 'alpha-player' syndrome where everyone else argues over the optimal move to take on your turn (something that's still very present).  That said, there's a lot of new stuff here, and they bolt these ideas onto the existing framework in a well-designed way.  

[Rather non-specific descriptions follow, but if you'd rather know nothing at all before playing, skip ahead.]
It starts out very simply, as a normal game of Pandemic.  But then, even without any rules additions, the game starts to change.  As events occur in your game, stickers are placed on cards, on sheets, and on the map.  Each month you play will see a furtherance of the story, usually introducing a new challenge &/or a new tool to combat it.  Your objectives (win conditions) change, new modules are added, and outdated cards are torn up.
The only complaint I had about this is that it can become a challenge to remember what to do as the new rules accumulate, or what options are available on your turn as new action choices become available.  
As you wind through the story, you'll open more boxes and panels, adding additional components to the game and more rules to the book.  However, the story itself is pretty bare-bones and could be summed up in a couple sentences.  If you're playing for the narrative, you'll likely be disappointed.  It's really up to the players to create their own narrative.  
I also feel like there is a certain amount of min-maxing that goes on, and must go on.  Some of the combinations of abilities that you can put together are very strong, while others seem pretty weak.  Characters can also suffer disabling conditions, so if you take too many risks, you could lose your most effective members.  If you make sub-optimal moves selecting these (permanent) upgrades, or play too sloppily, or just get unlucky in how the cards come out, you could find your game sliding towards disaster pretty quickly.  If the persistent conditions on the board degrade enough, it will get [i]very[/i] tough to win.  Now, the game does have a couple balancing mechanisms to make up for this.  You get extra 'funding' through beneficial events added to the deck, but only if you lose.  If you lose a lot, you'll get to open a special packet (presumably to try and salvage the game).  If you keep squeaking out wins even through the higher difficulty, the game won't help you out.  So, it doesn't track or differentiate between a well-organized/lucky game where you coast to victory and one where you win by the skin of your teeth.  Further, you get a bonus for the next month if you win, and nothing if you lose, making the up-/down-ward spiral more likely.
Lastly, if you liked On the Brink, In the Lab, or the latest one, you may be unhappy that barely anything from those modules made it into this version.  Legacy, though, adds enough new content to easily make up for that.

Anyway, to avoid spoilers, I've not asked for specifics from my friends who've finished yet.  (At time of writing, we were nearing the finale.)  So, I only have my own game to judge from.  I'm really curious, though, how others' experiences compare.  
At a minimum, the design's breathed new life into Pandemic and held our interest through the campaign.  And not everyone in our group even liked the base game that much, or co-ops in general.  From those measures, I'd call it a success.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Just a fantastic overall experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Spoiler-free comments: Finished. The system is clever. It often generates surprise, tension, and excitement. The story felt too generic and capricious to get me caring much about the narrative.

Fun:
* Preparing for one thing, but getting an event in the middle of a session that changes the rules.
* Getting the feeling that we were experiencing episodes of a TV show.

Unfun:
* Large, ever-changing ruleset, setup time, and upgrade choices at the end all added a lot of bookkeeping time to each session.

RATING: 10

RATING: 9.437
Out of league.
This is not an ordinary board game experience.
The excitement and the suspance, the game changing as you play it.. if you never tried it before, this is the perfect door to the Legacy system.
Masterfully built, it shocked everybody in my gaming group.
Yes, it is a one shot adventure, and then is over. You can probably use it as a "standard" pandemic game after playing it, but once the campaign is done, you have spoiled yourself the plot, like in a tv serie, and furthermore you will have destroyed some pieces and altered the board permanently xD.
Nonetheless, if you are even a bit into the hobby, it's totally worth it.

RATING: 7.25
I am flabbergasted by this whole Legacy concept. It's hitting most of the spots I love in (video) games where the game state changes from game to game, new abilities, levels, areas, items or objectives are being unlocked. And you never know what you will get, because it's sealed in envelopes or black boxes. Just this one gimmick is enough to turn average game into amazing one.

[b]Update:[/b] Downgraded from 8.3 to 8.1 due to the disappointing November. Would drop even further if not for very good September.

RATING: 8
Going into PL I was not expecting much. I had previously gotten burned out on Pandemic as we played it a lot when we first got into board games. Unfortunately our group has, once again, kind of gotten distracted and we are stuck in the middle of the campaign. In fact, PL made us realize that we actually like Pandemic and we went ahead and got a copy of vanilla Pandemic to scratch that itch until Season 2 comes out. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'll update this after each session, with final comments upon completion of the campaign.

Our second session was a rather difficult one... we lost 3 games in a row (both in May and first game of June) before finally winning one. 

Can't say too much without including spoilers but suffice it to say that this is definitely better than base Pandemic. The game and tension intensify as you progress throughout the year and the legacy mechanic continues to hold my interest (what is on those stickers? What is in those packets?). Designers have done a very good job coming up with variants that pose tough choices and keep you engaged.  I've now played 10 games of Pandemic Legacy in the last 2 weeks and I find it unlikely I would have played 10 games of base Pandemic in the next 5 years.

Some early critiques:

- I expected more narrative as everything is scripted from month to month, however, all we get is a sentence or two per legacy card. Certainly we have moments during the plays and a general escalation and progression is there, but I would prefer a little more explicit story as opposed to letting the players fill in the blanks. Perhaps my expectations were too high coming in as a result of all the hyped reviews stating this feels like you're in a movie... haven't felt that yet, but this certainly has more story than your average game.

- The mechanics evolve over the time but the actual game play still feels much like base Pandemic. Once you get over the excitement of reading the legacy cards and opening packets, it doesn't take very long before you get a samey feeling; most likely because the core actions (e.g. cure), infect step, epidemics, etc. remain in tact.. perhaps that will change before the end of the campaign.

- I haven't seen anything terribly innovative YET, but we still have 6 months to play. The Legacy system has been done before, some of the variants are in existing expansions and others are somewhat obvious. Still waiting for something that will fundamentally change the feel of the actual game play.

- The campaign is a bit long. I normally get 2 game nights a month, and if we continue at our current pace, this will take up to 2 months of my gaming in 2016. While I'm enjoying my experience, there are many other games I would like to play.

- This is a shared goal, open information, cooperative game, which is not my favorite type of game. I find these type of games to be OK, but not something I would typically rate higher than a 7 or so.

Pandemic Legacy is tough to rate as the BGG rating system wasn't designed for this type of game. After my first session, I rated this a 7.5 and this session hasn't done anything to improve upon that, in fact, I may move this down to a 7, which is the absolute floor as this is strictly better than base Pandemic which I rate a 6.5. I'm still having fun after 2 sessions but am ready to take a break and get back to playing other (non-cooperative) games in our group's collection, picking this back up in a month or so. I think this has the potential to move up, but only if I see something that significantly changes the game play or more of an explicit narrative with unforeseen twists.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best co-operative game ever cant wait for season 2

RATING: 10

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What can be said about the current #1 game on BGG? So many things, but the problem is that many of of them would be spoilers. Spoilers in a board game? Yes. Basically, when you play Pandemic Legacy, you are playing a campaign where the choices you make in one game will have a great impact on how the campaign evolves. In addition, there are many surprises that unfold. The campaign has a very cinematic sort of feel as each game you play represents one month a year where the CDC has it's work cutout for itself. If you succeed in a month, you go to the next month. If you fail in a month you get to try and play that month again. Only one do-over however. So, the campaign will last between 12 and 24 games (averaging 18). Between each game, you can upgrade your characters, your network, or other kinds of infrastructure. In addition, months can have various mandatory or optional objectives. The campaign almost felt like the way you do a campaign in Starcraft 2: Wings of Liberty since there are between-mission upgrades you can customize and various objectives the game throws at you.

If you like Pandemic, chances are, you will really like Pandemic Legacy. Other than a few periphery opinions, most agree that when you're finished the campaign, the game is over. Some people feel you can keep playing on this customized board but, I don't think I ever would. I don't mind this as I had a really fun 15 games. In addition, I can use the Pandemic Legacy box to house my normal edition of Pandemic with all available expansions, which is fantastic. In addition, if I lose a cube or research station, I now have direct replacement components.

I might have even rated this a 10 except for the fact that they didn't design the physical components in such a way that the campaign could be replayed. This was the designer and company's intention, but that doesn't mean I have to like it. Despite knowing the various surprises that happen, it would be nice to introduce to new players, it would be nice to try different characters/upgrade paths, and for other spoilerific reasons. It's certainly an achievement in mechanisms and narrative story-telling, but I seriously dislike that this can't be replayed without modding the game or re-purchasing another copy. Thankfully, another season is on the way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
A fun take on Pandemic, but legacy games have an inherent shortlife, so strictly following BGG's ratings methodology, this has little replay value for me and I've ended up with a hacked and modified board.  A fun concept for sure and definitely the best legacy game there is, but it is Pandemic and once finished, are you really going to replay it? 

My other gripe - applicable to any legacy game - is you need the same group of dedicated players to keep going.  This is a bridge too far and on that basis I can't recommend any legacy game.  So no replayability and a constant group is a bit hurdle for me, so I've knocked it down a point.  I may one day get my PL gaming group back again and finish the year, but I'm skeptical.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although I do not at all agree with its historic rise up the BGG ladder, this is still a great game. Its just Pandemic with some legacy mechanisms plopped on top, but those legacy mechanisms are admittedly really cool and fun to experience. The thrill of opening a new packet or acquiring a new bonus, is balanced with the anguish of placing an outbreak sticker on the board, or taking a scar. There are certain game changes that really liven up the game and provide huge narrative pivots, which help players stay interested through the twelve stages. The replayability argument is completely unfounded as after finishing the game, you will have already extracted more than your money's worth. Each decision made, and every card drawn has effects that ripple throughout the entire life of the game, creating a living narrative that you as a player have to struggle to control and adapt around. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I understand, and even partially agree, with lots of the detractors of Pandemic Legacy.  The rubberbanding is real, the plot is a bit generic, and the game is ultimately disposable.

But Pandemic Legacy is the most fun I have ever had gaming, so detractors be damned!  Pandemic is an incredible design, and this game is a great way to breathe new life into it.  I would heartily recommend this game to anyone.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Rating this game is tricky. I've already played 14 games of it, which is more than I've played my two favourite games of all time, so far. I also won't ever play it again. It feels like the BGG rating system breaks when confronted with a game like this. I had a few good experiences with this game, and two or three absolutely brilliant surprises. However, overall, I was very disappointed and often annoyed by this game. One particular issue is that Pandemic can often just force you to lose with no possible strategic or tactical decisions that could have saved you. That's fine, it's a relatively short game, and you could just play it again. In Pandemic Legacy, you can't play it again, and you're stuck with a permanently ruined board because the game sometimes throws out an impossible scenario.

If there are enough surprises in it then I think I would enjoy Risk Legacy. I do not intend to buy any other legacy games that have yet been announced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've really enjoyed playing this, especially as a long time fan of the original Pandemic and On the Brink.

This is a lot of fun, but requires a complete and thorough re-reading of the rules prior to and sometimes during each and every game. You can't just learn it once and know it forever. 

A couple of things to point out. Often, the print on cards and stickers is small or low contrast, making it difficult to read.

Another issue is the clarity of instructions. It is not always 100% clear when doors or boxes should be opened. At a couple points during the game, I failed to open a box, even though I had satisfied the conditions to due so, simply because it didn't give me a simple reminder of exactly what those conditions were. It was up to me to remember a card viewed several games earlier to know when it was time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
La base del juego es la misma que el Pandemia normal, pero la campaña es muy tensa y te mantiene sorprendido durante el transcurso, la sensación de que no hay vuelta atrás y que la has liado es genial, aunque la campaña no se puede volver a jugar siempre queda el modo básico.

Dificultad: 4/10
Diversión: 10/10
Rejugabilidad: 6/10

Me gusta: la tensión, la sensación de no hay vuelta atrás, las sorpresas durante la partida.
No me gusta: que solo se pueda jugar una vez la campaña.

RATING: 6.5
A great co-op board game. The main problems arise with the Legacy format. I like the progression and the story it tells, but the game reveals it's big surprises far too early. You'll be spending roughly 5-10 games playing the same game of Pandemic Legacy until you reach the next interesting content patch. Recommended for fans of puzzle games or those with a lot of patience.

RATING: 9
Gran experiencia lúdica. La única pega es una sensación de relativa facilidad con pocos jugadores, y cierta pequeña monotonía en meses centrales, pero disfrutar cómo evoluciona el juego y la historia es estupendo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
[b]The components[/b]: I don't have any objections to the quality of components. The map looks exactly as the one in Pandemic (so very tech-y and clean, which I like). The stickers are also pretty recognizable once on the board. For a game that can only be played once, they could have easily used cheaper cardstock for everything and nobody would mind, but they didn't, which I think is great. I also love the little details that are everywhere. 

[b]The theme[/b]: It is hard to speak about the theme of Pandemic Legacy without any spoilers but still, I will do it. At the start, it is just like a standard Pandemic game. The story obviously evolves but there is one thing that bothers me - I think the stories in between months are too short. Sometimes, it is even as short as 1 sentence. I hope the story will be much longer in Season 2...

[b]The fun[/b]: Oh, I never thought I would have so much fun playing a legacy game! But I just love opening all those boxes, number and stuff and applying all the stickers! I just can't stop at one game and always have to play at least 2 :)

[b]The gameplay[/b]: At its heart, [thing=161936][/thing] is just like standard Pandemic. So if you like that great puzzly coop game, chances are really high you'll love this. If you can get over destroying your game, that is :) Also, it gets harder and harder every month which is amazing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First impressions at the halfway point:

What is the game here?  


Is it the full 12 months?  If so, it seems really scripted and on rails.  Each game makes the next easier or more difficult to win/lose, but the same thing happens regardless.  It doesn't seem to matter if you win 12 in a row or lose 24 in a row.  I would have liked to have seen more if/then changes along the lines of the "if you lose 4 in a row, open box 8." Like "3 fallen cities, open box 9."  Maybe something like that is coming, but it doesn't look like it. It just doesn't seem like anything we do has any affect (besides making the next game slightly easier or harder).  Maybe the last half of the game will change this impression.

On the other hand, if "the game" is the individual game you play that time, I can appreciate the whole box as an elaborate series of mini-expansions and mechanism for introducing them.  Except you can't go back and play a version you liked a second time.  This makes the little rule snafus very frustrating.

Update: After the game sat on my shelf for another 6 months, my wife and I decided to "play" through the rest of the game by opening all the packets in order as if we had played and won each round. We didn't miss much. My initial assessment of the game being on rails stands.

This is one of the best games ever created.

RATING: 7

I think the rating is largely composed of people who didn't finish the game.

Some weird gaps in the rules, but a beautiful narrative, a welcome expansion to the Legacy... well, legacy, and beautiful production. I think this may have permanently supplanted the base game.

RATING: 5
With every game i play i lower the game's rating.
No, this game ain't good as its average rating may let you think. The mechanics are too simple to play 12-24 games. 
There's a lot of luck, you can draw 2 epidemic cards in 2 turns and there isn't anything you can do about it.
And the luck factor will increase as the campaign progresses.
Most of the times you have an only choice, and any error can mess up everything.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent game. Highly recommended for anyone who likes pandemic.

In regular pandemic, winning can feel like a bit of a letdown. Here you're just happy and relieved that no more permanent damage happens to your board. Also you will sometimes get greedy and try to win more in order to get better options for game end upgrades. I love that. 

Difficulty was perhaps a bit lower than regular pandemic. 

Gameplay has a few twists and new mechanics that really suits the game well.

I wish I could go back and experience it all again. But like with everything else, you can only experience the first time once :)

RATING: 9.5
Never played Pandemic before purchasing the Legacy edition Season 1. And, we never played a Legacy edition game before either. We were hooked immediately. It is an amazing game, as the rules, characters, strategies, and story develop based on your actions, reactions, and number of games played. It is brilliant in almost every way & changes what playing a board game means. Best to play with the same group of people through each month of the season. We cannot wait until Season 2 comes out!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I like this because it is built on the foundation of a great game (Pandemic), and adds in surprises and narrative development.

My first four plays were not that interesting to be honest: too much like Pandemic and parts of expansions that I had already played. But things changed dramatically, and I am at least in the "fan" camp now, even though it's going to need to really blow my mind to rise above 8 (mostly because base Pandemic is so good in its own right).

10 plays in, and this game feels like a chore. Simply too many small rules to remember. I like deep games - heck, COINs have more rules - but the small rule changes every game make it impossible to immerse. I'm tempted to drop rating to a 4. I would rather play base plus a single expansion. I doubt very much I will play Season 2.

RATING: 9
★ 별 5개 만점 기준 (1~4월 3인플, 5~12월 4인플)
1월: ★★★★★ (1회 승)
2월: ★★★ (1회 승)
3월: ★★ (1회 승)
4월: ★★ (1회 승)
5월: ★★ (1회 패, 2회 패)
6월: ★ (1회 패, 2회 패)
7월: ★★★ (1회 승)
8월: ★★★ (1회 승)
9월: ★★★ (1회 승)
10월: ★★★★ (1회 패, 2회 승)
11월: ★★★★★ (1회 승)
12월: ★★★★★ (1회 패, 2회 승)

최종 평가: 4인 팀원으로 플레이 하였고, 팀원 중 한 명은 인생 게임으로 꼽기도 하였다. 스토리 몰입감은 생각보다 약한 편이지만, 위기가 닥쳐올 때 압박감이 몰입도를 올려 준 것 같다. 시즌 2를 기대할만한 시즌 1이었고, 모두 함께 끝까지 플레이할 수 있어서 즐거웠다.
고정 멤버가 있다면 꼭 한 번 도전해 보시길!

- 생각보다 잔룰이 추가되어서, 텀이 길어지면 게임 보유자는 꼭 룰을 한 번 점검하고 플레이해야 한다. 사소한 에러플이라도 생기면, 팀원들이 이겨도 이긴 것 같지 않아할 수도 있어서 몰입감에 방해가 될 수 있기 때문에, 게임 소유자는 되돌리기를 하고 싶은 상황에서도 룰을 정확히 지켜줄 수 있어야 한다고 생각한다.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yeah, the hype was real. Me and my wife played this together, and became hooked. She often wanted a second game, a third game, gotta find out what happens next. It's not good because you tear up cards. that has nothing to do with it and I fear some people miss that. It's good because its a story, a book, a movie, and things have to change because the story keeps moving forward. 
It's an experience.
no resets, a problem? I can't unwatch a movie or reset my day either. why would you want to.

RATING: 10
Nehéz társasként értékelni a játékot, mert egy teljesen új vetületet hoz ebbe a világba. Igaz, hogy egyszervégigjátszós, de cserébe olyan izgalmat, olyan történetet, olyan karakterfejlődést ad, mint semmi más. És mindez a rengeteg irány ellenére érezhetően ki van egyensúlyozva, ami hatalmas meló lehetett. Tényleg olyan, mintha egy film közepébe csöppenne az ember. 
Ráadásul sokszor már nem is a játékon, hanem a játékok közti történeteken, fejlesztéseken van a hangsúly. Ezeket néha még jobban lehet élvezni.
Ha mindenképp kekeckedni akarok, akkor is csak egyetlen kérdés merül fel bennem. Vajon a 85. legacy játék is ezt az érzést fogja hozni vagy addigra meg fog kopni az újdonság varázsa. 
Talán mindegy is a válasz: 10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

The level of immersion is dramatically increased by the knowledge that changes to the board or characters could help or hinder you for months.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The 'Legacy' series isn't exactly something I am interested in, but as it is the #1 game at the moment and I pride myself on the hobby, it's only fair that I played it. I was actually surprised how much like Pandemic it is. It [i]is[/i] Pandemic, but with rule changes happening as the game unfolds. Perhaps it is an even more exciting experience for well-worn players of Pandemic who expect one thing and then have to deal with another. It was a journey, however. Good stuff was that it brought good people together and we got to live out a board game experience. Bad stuff: I found the game by the end lacked an interesting narrative, engaging storyline or did anything wild or innovative enough to release it from the chains of its base game. After the MAJOR PLOT DEVICE was introduced, there really was nothing that developed the game significantly afterwards. By the end, it really did feel like 20 games of Pandemic with increasing amounts of mud. I think there are opportunities to do something truly exciting with the Legacy genre if you're tight enough with a storyline and let that story inform your game design. Otherwise it can just fall flat, as I largely feel from my Legacy experience after 20 games. Still glad to try the number 1 game for the foreseeable while, but Pandemic Legacy doesn't come close in my mind to what makes gaming a great experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
12-2 with 3 players. 875 points.
This game is exceptional. It is building on the very simple and fun mechanics of Pandemics and adds a Legacy twist to it that changes everything. I like Pandemic but I am not a big fan of it. It feels like cleaning a blue board of little plastic cubes and that's it. Characters are nameless and even though collaboration is essential, the game gets very hard and depends a lot on luck with more than three players, which is quite frustrating as we can only use a very limited pool of synergies between characters each game.
Pandemic Legacy fixes all that for me. For the first time, I would consider playing 12+ games in a row. Each game adds a mini-expansion and tweak to the rules that feels very unique to our game - because even though the tweaks are scripted, their influence on the game is very much unique to your board; and that is enough to deliver a very exciting experience each time.
Also, the difficulty of the game scales up perfectly so that the game remains perfectly balanced - this is quite impressive.
Each time a big (morale?) decision comes up, the group has to weight pros and cons, not knowing what comes next in this game, but also in all future games. And that makes each discussion exciting, fun, intense and meaningful.
The game is not excruciatingly hard and punishing which keeps it fun, it is just the right balance and still feels you had to be at your best to beat the game. I still think it could have done a better job at leveraging down the difficulty for 4 players. Also on the downside, I think the game hasn't fixed the alpha player problem that was already in Pandemic and in fact is making it worse here because now we don't even have to hide our cards - which means the game could be played solo with no problem.
It is the first game I see somebody at the table saying 'this game is amazing' out of shear excitement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This takes the core game pandemic (a good game on its own) and adds a smattering of lightweight campaign options and role playing. It is really great fun. I would recommend people look into this market of campaign based gameplay further though as I feel the scoring people have applied to this game is a bit dramatic. I'm in no way saying Pandemic Legacy is bad (it is a really awesome play through) but I have played better campaign based role playing board games *cough* imperial assault *cough*.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
Loving it. Halfway through the campaign now. Full of surprises, and strategy is always changing from game to game. Sometimes I wish for my decisions to have more impact in the story arc. The luck factor (e.g. first infections) will also sometimes decide the game before the first turn. But... The story is really cool, and love experiencing all the new things together with my group. Highly recommended for anyone who's enjoyed the original Pandemic. If you're new to Pandemic, try a few "dry runs" (ie. without permanently changing the game) of the first month to get familiar with the rules and strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I am always skeptical of anything that becomes quickly and overwhelmingly popular. Pandemic Legacy (PL) made a lot of board game reviewers' top games lists, with many of them rating it their #1 game of 2015. I was also hesitant because of the "consumable" nature of the game (you have components that permanently alter the game, and you can play it, at most, 24 times).

My worries were unfounded. The hype was real. What did I say to myself just after finishing my first PL game, despite it being late at night and being tired? "I want to play another round. I want to see what happens next." PL echoes the success that serial dramas have had in recent years on television. You get hooked on the plot, and you care about the characters.

As for the consumable nature of the game: do the math. You'll play the game -- assuming you enjoy it -- a minimum of 12 times. How many games in your collection have you played at least 12 times? I'm guessing not many. There's some games I've only played once or twice and that are just sitting around.

NOTE FOR SOLO PLAYERS: Maybe you're like me and hate the "quarterbacking" aspect of co-op games, where you feel like you don't have much choice during your turn and you're merely doing what's optimal play for the whole group. Yes, you can play this game single player. (You can with *any* co-op game -- Forbidden Desert is great.) Simply assume multiple roles. I've read three works best. Also, use some kind of marker (such as the 4th pawn) to indicate which character's turn it is so you don't lose track. And keep pawn colors consistent to help you remember who's who... e.g. I always use the pink pawn for the Researcher character. This game is probably one of the best solo play experiences out there because PL is such a narrative experience. You're not merely counting up victory points as in some games -- you get to experience a great story as you reveal cards in the Legacy Deck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
At about March I decided that I simply cannot stand Pandemic as a game, and playing 18 or more hours of it was going to be too much. I endured to the end scoring well enough, but have since removed all versions of Pandemic from my collection. The game fails to reward learning and success. There is no risk/reward in this game and once you are playing at an optimal level you are essentially watching the unfolding process of a game you are no longer capable of controlling. The legacy system is exciting and I look forward to the many ways games can benefit from this, but I do not believe Pandemic was a good pairing for it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a good game, and a very interesting experience, but most of the appeal comes from its unfolding narrative. How much this idea appeals to you will probably determine how much you're likely to enjoy Legacy.

This game is rather over-rated (as of writing, it has been number one game on BGG for many months; in my view, it doesn't deserve a top 10 placing). The campaign is, I feel, over-long for what it is (I would score the game higher if it was a somewhat shorter experience); unless you do a lot of gaming, you're committed to playing Legacy as your main or only gaming for months on end. The campaign aspect makes it interesting, and is generally well handled, but introduces some problems (more on this below). 

Having an evolving campaign works well with Pandemic. This is firstly because it's a solid design that has had massive testing "in the field"; in short, the Pandemic engine is a great foundation on which designers can add new elements with relative confidence that it's all going to work.

Secondly, Pandemic Legacy fixes an issue with co-ops: namely, the "one player is an expert and tells everyone what to do" problem. Here, no-one is an expert after the first month or two, because no-one has played this particular version of the game before.

By continually dropping in new elements, the game is narratively exciting, but the constant change means that players never get to truly experiment with the game systems, because the situation is always changing, particularly in the late campaign. This means that you never find out if things would have been better or worse if you had done Y instead of X, as you won't get to try Y in a similar situation, because next time the situation will have moved on. 

The changing nature of the game theoretically has you thinking on your feet, but I would argue there is comparatively little information on how the interlocking elements work, so this is limited. This means you get the situation where one player strongly feels you should do something, but no-one really has a truly strong basis on which to agree or disagree, because there isn't time to get to know the game (although to be fair you're going to get this situation to some extent even in "known" games due to human nature).

One interesting side effect of the Legacy concept is that it gets players talking about game systems much more than they typically would (but if your group already talks in detail about game systems after playing, this may not be so big a change). 

With regard to rating, this game doesn't really sit well within BGG's rating system (it's a one-time-only affair, so the rating descriptions just don't apply). Therefore, I'm giving it 7 to reflect how much I like it (i.e. a fair bit better than average). At the start of the campaign, I'd have given it 9, but I have liked it less as the campaign has become, because of the increasing "wacky stuff happens" factor (as noted above, this is narratively exciting, but, for me, makes Pandemic Legacy less satisfying as a game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
