RATING: 6
Beginning the year of Pandemic Legacy is a treat. It is Pandemic with some persistent elements. The additions are great and wrap you in more and more, until about halfway through. After about 6 months, the game adds rules and missions that are not nearly as interesting as the early mutations. Even more, each successive month has a need to add a new tweak or rule. While tight and as good as ever early on, Legacy grew into something I liked less as the year advanced. It is a unique experience, but the game hit a peak at the mid-point and fell from there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Note: Two of the people playing with my wife and I, NEVER PLAYED any form of Pandemic prior.  After 8 or 9 turns of the first game they were playing like seasoned vets.  So if you are thinking about picking this up without having played Pandemic before, I would encourage you to do so.

RATING: 7.5
I won't rate this until I've played further in but here are some running thoughts:

January: I really like this game so far.  It is definitely still the familiar game of Pandemic but with a feeling of real consequences to each decision.  Events from the legacy deck have been interesting so far.  The way things play out feels a lot more like video game design with scripted events rather than a board game.  In that regard I'd say it's a successful hybrid.

April: Still interesting. The plot has been good so far and each month has had a different feel.  Mechanically it is the same game but the events spice it up and incentivize the next play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The highest expression of boardgames of our time. The hype is real, the bgg ranking is true, all your board gaming friends are right, this is as perfect as they come. Pandemic is, already, an easy to teach cooperative game that showcases the virtues of boardgames without falling into any of it's vices. You and your friends can work togather to save the world, how awesome is that? What Legacy does, is bring in a narrative that makes that theme shine as bright the sun. No movie, no videogame can give you this communal experience. Every game matters (won or lost), it is consistently surprising and, in the end, it is a masterfully crafted story that you can live through game.
Already purchase a second copy to play with my gf. If you haven't, you should play it too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm on my second play through (now in May) with a second group and am enjoying it as much as I did the first time even knowing most of what's coming. The game is dynamic and, so far, seems to allow multiple play groups to have a good chance at success is strategy and tactics are good. Both groups have used the Dispacher and Researcher every game thus far, but the first group relied heavily on military resources from their introduction while the second group has completely eschewed them while maintaining very similar success rates.  I can't speak highly enough about this game and have great anticipation for Season 2.

RATING: 5
I realize I'm in the minority here, but in playing with my girlfriend, we found the game way to fiddly in that you have to constantly add new rules and try to remember the old ones at the same time.  It really bogs down play and often leads to mistakes during the game, which are especially frustrating as you're permanently marking up the board. 

I dig Pandemic, and appreciate what this game is going for.  I can totally understand why people love this version, but for me, reading new rules every so often is not fun.

RATING: 7
Yeeeeah. So.
This isn't as good as I thought/hoped it would be. Make no mistake, it's very good--but the Legacy format isn't really shining. For one, everything is scripted in a way that Risk Legacy wasn't. For another, the new stuff that the boxes and stickers introduce is mostly just a subset of the stuff Pandemic lovers already have in the expansions.
You see, I still prefer normal Pandemic with the first expansion, because it has tremendous variety and customizability. Lots of roles, events, and options. With Pandemic Legacy, you just a small subset of that locked in month on end.
So, from my perspective, don't believe the hype--especially if you're like me, and you think Pandemic doesn't really sing until you add On the Brink.

RATING: 4
The game had lots of up and downs, but overall the boring parts outweighed the exciting parts. Often I was dreading having to play the next month as this game started to become a chore rather than being exciting. Additionally, for a campaign style game, the end was the biggest cop-out imaginable. If there had been a solid ending, something that made me feel like all my work had been worth it, I probably would have scored this substantially higher, but to find out that it's a score your points situation (for a game I'll probably never play again) I was devastated. It will be a long while before I can trust a legacy game again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As I write this, Pandemic: Legacy has taken the top spot on the BGG rankings, and not without cause. This is an experience unlike any other game (with the possible exception of its predecessor Risk: Legacy). However, as much as I enjoyed Risk: Legacy, I feel this type of game actually works even better as a co-op. Risk: Legacy sometimes led to moments of players colluding, not for selfish gain or mutual benefit, but simply to "open more stuff". When all players are working together by design, this type of behavior feels more sensible. Rewarding players for things they want to do anyway is a mark of good game design. 

As the game progresses, more and more complexity is added and at a rapid rate. Unfortunately, a lot of the complexity is a serious pain to track. By the end, nearly every city has special rules associated with it, the player actions have tripled in quantity, and it is very easy to forget some of the necessary bookkeeping that needs to occur. I'd be shocked if ANY group has ever played through the whole thing the first time without a single instance of inadvertent cheating. I think all this bookkeeping is worth the hassle, but it is a serious strike against the design.

I have high hopes for games of this type in the future and eagerly await Season 2!

RATING: 7
[No Spoilers]
Final thoughts after completing the campaign.
I really thought it would be better. I have really mixed feelings about this game.

The pure gaming experience is at the same level as normal Pandemic with expansion(s), just different. I liked some parts of the scenarios that changed up the basic Pandemic game play but also disliked some things that just felt tacked on.

The story was pretty unimaginative, but still had some redeeming twists.

The legacy aspect is fun (it's always exiting to open new "doors" or packages) but also a little bit disappointing. I wished the player actions had more (ie. any) influence on the story. I felt like the game drives the legacy aspect more than the players.

A time line:
After a couple of games, Rating 8:
Like normal Pandemic, but with some extra bits and bobs ans surprises that makes it a bit more interesting. Interested in what the next game will reveal. 

About halfway through, Rating 7.5:
The legacy bits of the game seems to be more affected by what the game does than the decisions of the players. The story that is told is not affected by the players' decisions. The "stickering" is mostly used to reduce bookkeeping between games. Also disappointed by a very unimaginative story.

A few more games, Rating 7.2:
Each new scenario just seems to add a tacked on mechanism that really doesn't contribute much to the enjoyment of the game. The "advent calendar" aspect of the game is what keeps it interesting.

Almost finished, Rating 7.4
The story got a little bit better. Still feel the same about the mechanisms.

Finished: Rating 7.2
Pretty boring ending and I found the scoring odd. We did well though.

Looking back at the experience: Rating 7
Didn't stick as something exceptional. Would have liked some branching story lines.

RATING: 8
(02/12/2016) Comment based on 4-5 plays.

Pandemic Legacy is a stroke of genius, taking the ever popular Pandemic cooperative game, and making it a "legacy" variant similar to Risk:Legacy. The game has an overreaching story arc that flows through 12-24 sessions, which represents a year of time in the Pandemic world. The components may be written on, ripped up, or modified by adding stickers. New rules are incrementally introduced throughout the year, allowing the players more actions, as well as potentially powering-up certain character roles. In some cases, some of the available player roles can be permanently scarred/damaged and even killed. It's like a soap opera in a board game format. You don't know what will happen next, and it keeps drawing one back because they don't want to miss an installment.

There is a sense of mischievousness when one is told by the game to deface it or to destroy specific components. Normally, this is unthinkable, but in this game format, it is encouraged. However, this means that the game will never be replayable back to its initial state. Also, after the year campaign is over, the game needs expansions (and hence the designations of "Season 1" and so on) for it to continue. At $40-$60, having 12-24 sessions with Season 1 may be on the expensive side, but it is great fun. It is a form of RPG, where the players do tend to get attached to certain characters, and as such devastating when one is killed off. It is sort of like the characters in Game of Thrones, where every character you get invested in will get killed. This is clearly the next evolution in board game design, where each session is unique, and the campaign world is irrevocably and permanently altered. Because the players are more invested than usual, and since there is a sense of finality, there is more tension than a usual recyclable game. This is for keeps.

Components are very good. Rules are well written. The graphics is much more stark, with a sense of urgency when compared to the original Pandemic. Unfortunately, there is a touch excessive downtime when prepping the game, as well as after the game, where permanent alterations are made. The game doesn't suffer from alpha-gamer syndrome that plagues most cooperatives, due to the unknown nature of the unfolding story. There is some downtime during play as well, but the design ensures that all players remain engaged regardless of turn order. The game somewhat requires a long-term committed group, although players can swap in and out between sessions and not miss much, so it is similar to playing in a moderate-length RPG campaign. Rating: "8". It is a great design, where I will gladly play my friend's copy, but no need to get my own. Still, a unique gaming experience that every gamer should have at least once.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[microbadge=37533] - [i]Los Angeles, Mexico City, Santiago, Istanbul, St. Petersburg, Moscow, Delhi, Kolkata, Chennai, Jakarta, Beijing, Tokyo.[/i]

[b]OH SWEET JESUS
HOW DO YOU SLEEVE A STICKER[/b]

"Are Legacy games for me?"  No, no they aren't.  Asking the question [i]is[/i] your answer.

This is an experiment in emergent narrative told through mechanical gameplay.  The physical game is the engine that drives the story forward, but it's not the "thing".  The thing is what goes on inside you, how it makes you feel, the stuff left over when all the bits go back in the box.*  

[size=7]*Well, some of them, anyway.[/size]

And it's fucking [i]genius[/i].

[b]ONLY THE STRONG[/b]

[microbadge=37534] - [i]São Paolo, Lagos, Kinshasa, Seoul.[/i]

[b]After 11 plays:[/b]  After a bumpy start due to the other three players taking it [i]very[/i] casually while I held true to my solemn vow to avoid alpha-dogging it, everyone woke up to the permanence of letting things slide, doing your own thing "just to see what happens", and [i]losing[/i]—so much so we've become a crackerjack team of 11-fingered dike pluggers, not having lost a game since [i]before[/i] April.  At first I thought we must be getting a rule or five wrong (not unusual what with the constant parade of new stuff) or maybe we just got a bunch of lucky shuffles; but discussion and dissection of the games showed that we were just making good, well-timed decisions.  

And that feels pretty cool.

[b]After 16 plays:[/b]  Reversion to the mean is, as they say, a bitch; we has got our comeuppance.  The world is duly fucked.

[b]After 20 plays:[/b]  Final score of 618/1000—which is a D-minus (!)—but the game grades on a curve so while civilization might have lost an eye and has a permanent lisp it can still ride a bike.  Hooray?

Our only regret was 

[o]not using the nuclear option to cut one of the major transmission nexuses—it would have saved us a ton of grief to have done so.  What stayed our hand was the belief that such an event would only further the enemy's goal of global destabilization, as well as the (emergent narrative) karmic debt of murdering millions of people just to make our jobs easier...  In the end it turned out that if we [i]had[/i] used the nuke it would have actually [i]increased[/i] our score and resulted in a better outcome—which is weird.  Filling in the blank in [i]Hiroshima, Nagasaki, [c][u]        [/u][/c][/i] should always be seen as a tremendous negative.[/o]
[b]The wrap-up session report:[/b]

[article=22635754][b]Don't stop for love she screamed.[/b][/article]

[b]For those with "concerns" about the one-shot/non-replayable aspect:[/b]  While we had great fun with this for four real-time months, [i]I wouldn't ever want to play it again[/i], rendering the massive amount of effort required to make it "resettable" a huge waste of time.  So what about the thing itself now that it's been "bricked" and is "useless"?  Well, we did get 20 plays out of it, [i]which is more plays than I've gotten out of 90% of my collection of 400+ games.[/i]  

Let that sink in.  

In that regard we got enormous value out of it. 

[b]Final analysis:[/b]  This was a weekly event that we constantly looked forward to—and will miss dearly.  There's already talk of what's next for that Tuesday time slot...

[microbadge=37535] - [i]Lima, Bogotá, Buenos Aires, Cairo, Khartoum, Joburg, Baghdad, Riyadh, Tehran, Karachi.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

RATING: 5
I plan on checking in on my rating every few games and updating accordingly. I'll keep a log of them here:

Rating 7.5 after 4 games played (2 in Jan, 2 in Feb) - Cool, but not a revelation.

Rating 7 after a few more games (we're into May now) - We've had a couple big mechanism changes/additions, but none of them really change the feel of the game. Each individual game is still not terribly note-worthy. Games tend to have pretty obvious best moves, and the infection deck either thinks you're lookin' purty tonight or it smashes your face with a brick. That said, the narrative arc _is_ clever, and the Legacy deck is inspired. It makes the Legacy concept work in a way that Risk Legacy never did. Still worth playing, but I'm glad I didn't buy it myself.

Rating 5 after Oct.1. I was pretty well done in September or so, though will finish the year out. Don't really care what happens now, however. Looked ahead at some spoilers and feel like one of the December thingies is really stupid and reeks of awful game design. They have somewhat spent the rest of the series conditioning you in one way, and then without any warning (as far as I can tell) they do a complete 180.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have never played a game that is more engrossing than this. I probably have some sort of undiagnosed ADD or ADHD and so often times I'm bored waiting for my turn in some games.

Not so with this one. There is SOOOO much going on - do we spend our time putting out the fire in south america or do we let that go and work on getting a cure for red?

There is no alpha gamer syndrome in play here because there is so much to do, it's like, we have to attend to all of it, so go go go! 

Each game is a fight to the finish and we are always having to make touch choices about what is our priority. Save a city or make a cure, often times you can't do both in the same turn and so you risk much.

What updates should you take after each game? We can spend 20 - 30 minutes after each game trying to decide that one thing. 

Even just trying to figure out which crew to take out that month can be an agonizing (in a good way) group discussion. This one is better at curing but this one is better at treating. 

So much tension!

Such great love for a game that really knocked it out of the park!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 9.5
Following on from the game changing Risk legacy, Pandemic Legacy flips the model on its head by applying the Legacy model to a co-op game to mind-blowing effect. The evolution of the journey is fascinating and I love the fact that we regularly play this with 5 players as it is very much a team effort versus a ruthless AI. 

Another absolutely must for all gamers - a sublime journey. It only misses out on top marks as Risk Legacy was the first, the benchmark, and the experience of Pandemic while brilliant is somewhat lesser than Risk legacy.

RATING: 2
[url=http://www.techuser.net/klondikeprob.html]Cooperative games are not games, they are puzzles. And whether I win or lose against a random inanimate/unintelligent algorithm, I am left feeling unsatisfied. I'd rather play a One versus All or a Team versus Team game. [/url] 

The Legacy mechanism is a sustainability nightmare that devalues a board game worse than driving a new motor vehicle off the dealership lot, and like a car salesmen the publishers are laughing their way to the bank. A short term narrative gain is not worth the loss of replay ablity. I'd rather play a campaign.

RATING: 9
Full disclaimer: I love legacy games. Or at least the ones I've played so far. Pandemic Legacy took what was a decent but IMO relatively unremarkable board game, vanilla Pandemic, tweaked it slightly and made it amazing. Each game is close, but never feels like it's completely out of grasps or clearly within your reach. The modifications between games add to the story line and make the game more fun, but don't over or under power the players. The only major downside I'd say is the concluding stages are a bit anticlimactic, but nothing is perfect. :)

Zomer 2017. Schitterend coöperatief spel; soort gepimpte en gepersonaliseerde versie van Pandemie. Tijdens het spel ontstaan onomkeerbare wijzigingen op het spelbord, in de spelregels, met de personages, etc. Geweldig gevonden en zeer goed uitgebalanceerd. Enige ervaring met de klassieke versie van Pandemie is aangewezen. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2.79
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Great game, though I'm surprised people consider this to be the best ever.  If you like Pandemic, definitely get this.  If not, I'm not sure you'd like this.  We found the rule book to be confusing, and the whole thing is pretty fiddly.  With those things said, one of the coolest gaming experiences I've had.  Definitely recommend playing with a set group of people and avoiding too much time in between sessions (we didn't play for like 3 months at one point and I think that hurt the experience). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.9
We're about to start June as I write this and we've had a lot of fun with it.  We started with just me, my wife and daughter and lost the first two games.  We started to win once my sister jumped in and we've reserve playing it just for times she's at the house.  One note of warning, it's VERY EASY to forget to check for when new cards should be revealed. We forgot more than once and even had to completely redo a month we had won but had forgotten to reveal cards at the beginning of the month. So be VIGILENT with the cards.

RATING: 8
The game deserves high marks for breaking new ground in a gaming experience.  It's a wonderful concept, and it plays really well.  It's better than traditional Pandemic from a pure enjoyment factor, although it obviously requires a far bigger committment.  I haven't finished the campaign yet, but I can confidently say this is a solid gaming experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
If you like pandemic then this is a no brainer. 

For myself, liking pandemic but not wanting to play it that often due to the fact that no matter how well you play, if the cards come out in a bad order then (without knowing it) you've lost before the game even starts. The legacy system doesn't change this, it just helps mitigate being unlucky/lucky multiple games in a row.

The legacy mechanics make it so that if you loose a game then the next one is slightly easier, and every month (2 games per month if you loose one of them) the game gets harder. Also every game you play (win or loose) gains you 2 upgrades before the next game. Basically the 12-24 games  that you play are one giant diffuclty balancing mechanism. So if you find yourself on a loosing streak, then the difficulty increases will slow down while the upgrades still come every game and the bonus for loosing occurs too.

The other thing that the legacy system brings to the table is the developing story, as the months go on, new rules/objectives/components/roles etc are added which makes every game different, and depending what decisions you have made, and which cities have had outbreaks, the game state will permenantly change each game as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(The following is all spoiler free.)

Final Thoughts (with 2 players):
The game is excellent.  If you like Pandemic, you need to play this game.  All my negative comments that I'm about to make are minor quibbles on an amazing game.  My main complaint is that the game was too easy and was especially too easy in the last couple episodes of the story, so it felt like a bit of a letdown after the excitement of the middle episodes.  One of the main problems was the funding mechanism, which gives incentive to lose on purpose at the beginning of each month.  There needed to be a penalty added to the empty-deck loss condition so that we couldn't just use that as an easy way to get extra upgrades and funding with no cost.  Even after fixing that, I'm not sure the last episodes are climactic enough, and that's something only the story writer can fix.  I have lowered my score from 10 to 9 based on the last episodes.

In all, it was an amazing experience and I do not regret the purchase and play of this game one bit.  I would do it again.


Old/detailed notes:
Pandemic was already one of our favorite games and this just takes it to a new and better level!

One warning, make sure to follow the setup rules and don't assume you know them based on the original game.  I made that mistake and it kinda ruined our January mission (we essentially had Funding 8 since I just stuffed all the cards in like in the normal game, oops).  We also goofed up on virus upgrades the first time around, thinking we got them as an eradication bonus without spending one of our upgrade slots.  So, after January we had an easy win and too many virus upgrades.  Since it's Legacy (and we are playing the destructive way) we can't really go back and fix it, so we just moved on.  My thinking about our path is thus.  We could have taken intentional loss in game 1 to get 2 upgrades and keep funding up.  We would then enter February with 4 upgrades and 4 funding.  Instead, we enter February with only 2 funding and 5 upgrades (3 virus, 1 lab, 1 skill).  I think we're still coming out ahead, but can't really think of anything better to do.

2017-10-28: Just got it, still in wrapper.  So excited!
2017-11-17: Won first mission (January).  So cool!  Though we messed up some rules, oops.  Zero outbreaks.
2017-11-20: Lost second mission (Feb).  Again quite fun.  The revealed stuff from the Legacy deck for this mission was great.  We took an intentional loss to keep our funding up and get more upgrades.  So far as I can tell, if the board state is right to prevent all outbreaks, then there's really no downside to just letting the deck run out as the loss condition.  Not sure if this is good strategy, but it seems favorable.  We had one unavoidable outbreak (Khartoum) before the decision to lose, but after that we got to eradicate one virus to upgrade it and didn't have any more outbreaks.
2017-11-27: Win Feb.  Man, this one was super easy.  We started with 3 yellow in hand and drew into cure on turn 3, followed by eradication.  One of the epidemics came on yellow (ignored!).  It was so easy in fact that we had several turns where we only took 1 or 2 actions due to the board being empty.  Zero outbreaks.
2017-11-28: Lose March (intentional).  Zero outbreaks.  Since we now have a nice stack of upgrades built in to help us manage the board, things are actually getting easier rather than harder as we go.  I really think this sandbagging trick is overpowering to the game.  Still, we're having fun.
2017-12-11: Win March.  Zero outbreaks.  The strategy is working very well.
2017-12-12: Lose April (intentional).  Zero outbreaks.
2017-12-22: Win April.  Zero outbreaks.
2017-12-23: Lose May (intentional).  Zero outbreaks.
2017-12-28: Win May.  Zero outbreaks.
2017-12-28: Lose June (intentional).  Zero outbreaks.
2018-01-01: Win June.  One outbreak (Bogota).
2018-01-01: Lose July (intentional).  Zero outbreaks.  Did the thing.
2018-01-07: Win July.  Zero outbreaks.
2018-01-07: Lose August (intentional).  Zero outbreaks.  Did the thing.
2018-01-09: Win August.  Zero outbreaks.
2018-01-09: Win September.  Zero outbreaks.  Did the thing.
further games not tallied here...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Disappointing experience.
Have only played first month. It felt very similar to regular Pandemic (obviously, since initially little has changed at the outset). Regular Pandemic is bland and almost plays itself. No meaningful decisions, as the optimal moves are more or less obvious.

I still want to try to play it more (due to the hype and to experience how it might change), but it left my regular playing partner (my wife) cold. I will have a very hard time convincing her to play again. This was not fully evident when we finished our first game, so we did apply all the Legacy stuff during and after the game.
 
Playing it with others will be less fun (at least initially), as the game has already been used and they won't be able to experience it from the start.

Am feeling quite stupid to have followed the legacy "mechanic" faithfully. I'm annoyed that a single (almost test) game has ruined the experience for later plays with other groups. 

The Legacy mechanic is interesting but it increases the cost of an unlucky purchase. You are ruining the resell value of the game, even after just one play.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As a consumable, I suppose it breaks the mold (and some of the things inherent in the rating system...)

it's an interesting game design, and I think we'll see the style evolve so, , perhaps, my rating will change relative to changes in the style - but I am basing my rating not on game design analysis  and just on pure experiential enjoyment.

FWIW I played it 2 player (2x2 which is totally viable given the open co-op style) with my wife and just had a blast with her. I think it makes a great couples game and the evolving narrative sort keep things moving.
I mean not only does it stay fresh, but that there is an end keeps the ball rolling as a "project" to complete

the weigh is relatively light so participation is "weekday easy" when people are a little drained, but the evolving rule set keeps the rules from being trite since there's a freshness.

as far as no replayability value...well the only misgivings I have there is the materials waste (but honestly, if I look at packaging in general. it's not so bad. I home designers just keep in mind to try to keep "hard components" re-purpose-able)

but as a value proposition I have zero qualms about the non-replayability. I certainly got an entertainment experience and moreso than many games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This was really a remarkable experience that my spouse and I had playing through this game together.  The legacy components work very well, and the game does a good job from the get-go in shaking things up so you realize This Is Not Your Usual Pandemic.  The basic model where the game is now "over" for us (until Season 2!) was well-worth the trade off of having the raised stakes and unfolding storyline as you play.  

I would recommend coming up with a theme for the names of all your characters--the way folks back in the day would have a motif for naming their servers--and having fun following it.  We went with animals, and there will always be a fondness in our hearts in particular for the adventures of Dr. Hedgehog-Warbler.

Playing through the game does ruin you for a little bit on playing ordinary board games, as games without a legacy element that seemed story-rich subsequently feel a bit more like, well, just games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Acquired 2015-11-07
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Wow! Believe the hype!  

I'll be honest, that I was a fan of Pandemic before this game, so yeah, I'll buy it.  However, my kids don't enjoy the regular Pandemic game as much as I do, so it doesn't see much regular play time.  

After two games, my kids are loving this game.  We've had the two most dramatic finishes to game than I could  ever remember.  The game makes you really care about what happens in the game, because events affect future games. No one wants their character to die.  You're invested in the outcome of the game like never before.  I don't know of a game experience that has ever been so intense and exciting.

It's fun to see what is revealed next in the legacy deck, top secret dossier, and player packages.  It's agonizing trying to decide what upgrades are best to get and which characters to bring into the next round.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2016-11-06

Initial Rating: N/A

I dislike when people rate a game without playing it beforehand (to me, it doesn’t make any sense) so I won’t rate the game. I don’t think I will ever play Pandemic Legacy, still I want to share my opinion about the game.

I heavily dislike Legacy games. I come from a third world country and since I was a child I was taught to not generate waste, so the idea of permanently change a game is anathema to me. When I do that, I lose all the financial value of the game (I cannot sell an used copy if I want to) and I facilitate the generation of waste. I’m sure all the Legacy games could be done in a way that you could reset them to their initial estate without losing any of the fun and/or surprises of playing through them (examples of this that come to mind are T.I.M.E Stories, Mechs and Minions and Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set). I understand that the permanent change is the whole point of the Legacy system, but I cringe every time I see a friend tearing the components of the game. I know I’m in the small minority here :D, but that’s the reason I dislike Legacy games, for me those games are really disposable and that makes me sad.

I won’t ever buy a Legacy game.

Current Rating: N/A

RATING: 10
Amazing ! Best gaming experience I've ever had. Incredible design fantastic game. Hands down game of the year .... game of the decade !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I was lukewarm about this title when I heard of it, as I'd not had the pleasure of playing Risk Legacy.  I'd seen about all the base Pandemic I needed to see.

This experience is as much like an RPG, or a season of television, as it is a game.  Pandemic engages me much more when each game has consequences lasting into the next, when new events and objectives are revealed, and when characters develop from game to game.

As of the beginning of September of my first campaign, I expect to finish this campaign and perhaps play a second time.  If Pandemic Legacy were available for mobile devices I would buy it in a second.

RATING: 6
As someone who only plays regular Pandemic two or three times a year, the prospect of a dozen sessions in a concentrated span of time doesn't have tremendous appeal to me. I lost interest after the first few sessions when it became apparent that the story is fixed (i.e., your decisions don't affect the narrative in any way) and that each month becomes increasingly complex and takes longer. I know I'm in the minority, but this just isn't for me.

(Side note: I'm not sold on the legacy concept as a whole. I'm just not sure about a game that ends up being unusable after it has been played. Tearing up cards, putting permanent stickers on the board, and winding up with a box that isn't even able to be traded or sold goes against my sensibilities)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This game still suffers from the alpha player dominating the game, only the game is much longer. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Unbelievable! The already great game gets better as, over the course of twelve "month" scenarios, the rules change slightly to make it more intense and more challenging... and your group will love the changes each time because it never lets you feel totally overwhelmed at all. My only disappointment is that, to replay it, you need to buy a new copy and start all over again.

PLUS: makes a great game even more challenging
BIG PLUS: new challenges don't overwhelm you
HUGE PLUS: new challenges increase the fun level
MINUS: replay is limited, two different boxes but same game inside
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
As we continue the game, I fear that enjoyment of the game comes more from winning than losing.  Of course, that may be true for many games, but I really hate the game when we lose and love it when we win more than other games I've played.  I'm still enamored by Pandemic in the Legacy format.  The fiddly bits are even more fiddly, but at least I'm able to remember when to place a sticker or add a rule, etc.  

SPOILER:

The addition of "search and rescue" missions has really bumped up the enjoyment for me.  I hope these continue throughout the remainder of the game and provide better rewards.

This comment will be updated as we go on, as well as the rating, as we continue further into this very interesting "Legacy" system.

RATING: 2
While Pandemic is a fine game, the legacy element is an emotionally and financially abusive system that adds nothing to the game and takes too much. RATING: 10
Just: Wow!!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Should this be considered one game in multiple parts or 12-24 separate unrepeatable experience games? I have assiduously avoided reading much on this game lest I diminish the experience of playing. I won't give anything away that you won't know before you start your first game, which begins just like a regular game of Pandemic until you draw your second epidemic card - then the changes come rapidly and unpredictably.

There is one variable aspect (again, that you learn before you begin playing), in that every time you lose a game your funding level goes up (which equals the amount of helpful action cards you have in the player deck) and when you win it goes down. This sort of self-correcting difficulty level based on past performance is genius. There is little else I can say other than every game is a bit like opening a Christmas present with a new game inside. 

For the great experience this game is, I can't score it higher. I am playing it two-player and there is a growing disappointment at that player count in that the objectives tend to favor the use of just two or three characters and the others don't make sense to use given the needed skills. I don't think this would be an issue at four players. There is also a part of me that feels it is merely a (genius) marketing gimmick - and disposable games feel like a terrible waste of cardboard and plastic (I'll pirate as much as I can for other games). Even though it is much harder for me to find 4 players with the required consistency, I will do so before playing Season 2!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

With Season one completed, it is difficult to give the game a ten as to play it again would mean buying another copy - maybe season two (and promises of further seasons) will allow for the ten star rating the game deserves.

59.49 CSI
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After 7 plays:
Upgrade from 8.5 to 9.5.  Best new game I've played this year, after 6 months of the campaign it's only getting more exciting and more interesting.

While I love the game and it's my favorite new game of the year, I do feel there were a few mis-steps on the designers part:
-It's very easy to mix up Package #s and Door (advent/dossier) #s.  The numbers should not have overlapped - Dossiers should have started with 9.
-It doesn't scale well down to 2 players/2 characters total.  Way too easy.  We ended up doing 2 characters each/4 characters total.
-SPOILER BELOW


SPOILER
-End of September/Paranoid Soldier: I disagree with the rules as written to allow the traitor to be an unused character.  The whole point of that event is to have a significant emotional, strategic & narrative impact, and the best way to do that is make it be an in-game character.

I do really like how it scales the difficulty based on your wins and losses, it fine-tunes it very well with the funding cards.  It's pretty brilliant how the funding cards act in two ways - they give you special abilities, and also their very presence as a physical card means that the epidemics will be more spread out.

My grades for each month, based on what it adds to the game (SPOILERS!)

Jan:
A+.  Very exciting, having one disease mutate and become uncurable was cool.  Loved the upgrade options.

Feb:
A+.  Adding the quarantine stuff and having C0dA become not only uncurable as before but now even untreatable was a fun challenge.  Relationships between characters was a neat twist and worked well.

Mar:
C-.  Felt like a "filler" episode.  Military bases are just weaker Research Stations, at least at this point.  So other than a powerful new character, there wasn't much new and exciting as far as rule changes.  It felt like just busy work, we were just building military bases to have something to do, to work towards, it didn't really help combat the diseases. 

April:
A+.  The game is back to form, the Faded mutation is awesome and literally a "game changer".  This makes C0dA even more dangerous.

May:
A-.  Roadblocks are a cool feature.  The new character (Colonel) seems a bit weak.  The increased incubation rate nicely amps up the pressure and makes sure all the C0dA regions become Faded.  And, the experimental vaccine is now available - we will surely need to use this soon, as we have lost twice in a row! (Both May attempts).
EDIT: It turns out we obtained the experimental vaccine in error - we opened Package 8 instead of Window 8.  The rules were unclear and we opened the wrong thing.  Thankfully, after the June game we realized our error and put the experimental vaccine back unused.

June:
B-.  Seems like another placeholder month.  The new Soldier character is also a little weak (can't discover cure).  Might be best in a game with a lot of people.  The equipment is pretty cool though, better than Military bases were when they were introduced.  Grenade Belts and Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells are particularly cool equipment.
(Edit: Revising this grade to A-.  The soldier, in combination with the equipment, turns out to be REALLY powerful!  We had him keep on throwing grenades at the faded figures, then picking his grenade belt back up.  Unfortunately I was spoiled to this strategy by reading the FAQ and seeing the Q/A that he is allowed to pick up and use the same equipment card multiple times in a turn - but, it is an effective strategy!

July:
B-.  I'm a little conflicted on this month.  On the one hand, it seems like they are saying there's so much going on with the game, at this point we're just going to add "mini-games/satellite games" (the search for the virologist).  On the other hand, it is a pretty cool way to add some narrative and theme to the story.  And, I did like the mechanism of "hunting" for the virologist, and epidemics pushing our hunt closer to ending in a cold trail.  On the other other hand, it was anticlimactic when we found her, b/c all we got was the gene sequence of C0dA, but we have no idea what the implications of that are.  We thought it would be some really cool immediate benefit, but instead so far it's just thematic fluff, at least as far as the game has revealed to us (I'm assuming it will be one item in a "collection" of things we will need to fight C0dA, but the game hasn't clarified this).  So, B- but flirting with C+.

August:
C+.  Another "Search," this time for the Immunologist.  We found our "checklist" of needed things for the cure, and as we thought one of them was the item we got from the Virologist.  Virologist character is introduced in this month - we thought she'd be a big help, but she turned out to be a bit of a dud - the whole game she only drew one C0dA color, so she didn't really get to use her power.

September:
A+.  Another "game-changer" month!  Losing one of our best characters (Soldier "Goose" van Gogh) as a traitor was devastating.  Great story-telling with the Paranoid Soldier discovery.  Ironic that we've been building up the military infrastructure and now we have to tear it down, but, they've sold it well and I'm buying :-)  Great month.

October:
A-. Satisfying resolution to finding the Immunologist's requests!  Can't wait to start vaccinating.  Cool new components and mechanics.  The vaccination mechanics address the military base sabotage "loophole" in the previous month of building a base just to sabotage it - now we really do need to get rid of the starting bases.

November:
B+.  Kind of a place-holder month, but I understand that for those who struggled with the searches, this month will be their only opportunity to use the newly-uncovered results of the searches (thanks to Team Bravo).  It was fun vaccinating the Faded Cities and getting some breathing room (especially since we had 2 shots at November... it might even be strategically better to lose the 1st November game so you can vaccinate even more before whatever's coming in December...)  We know at least we'll get an Epidemic in December thanks to the board spoiling that with an extra infection rate - they should've been stickers!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My current favorite game. Also, my first ever campaign style game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I love pandemic still to this day.  I don't need the gimicks, the 3rd grade level "story telling" (I have an imagination I don't need B Movie script writing to improve the experience.  I also don't care about destructive elements to the game if there are additional components to replace what you "fixed" or destroyed".  perhaps if they had expansions with replacement components and new missions I would be more excited.  I understand why the masses like this game, I get it but I am not easily swayed by gimmicks.  I hope everyone enjoys this game's time under the sun because it insures several years of people trying to create the next Pandemic legacy and I really don't look forward to such dark days for gaming.  We have reached the pinnacle where people try to out do the next game by coming up with new mechanics and new ideas.  Instead, its lets paste on a different theme, use the same mechanics and try to "replicate" the last hit.  Our gaming hobby is starting the backward slide.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It was a truly fantastic game, but my personal take away is that I will never play a Legacy game again.  It is too difficult to get everyone back to the table at the same time and with the rules constant changing and the gaps between plays, rules questions, problems, mistakes happen too frequently.

RATING: 10
NOTE TO OTHER REVIEWERS: Careful with the spoilers!!! Don't even hint at what happens without a spoiler alert! (rant off)

My review (spoiler free):
Own both Red and Blue versions (playing with 2 groups).

I admit I was surprised how high the current Avg Rating was before I played it. I don't feel like any game truly deserves a 10 because nothing is perfect. However, I own 400+ board games and it's been so long (if ever) that I've been this excited about playing a board game. 

I am giving it a 10 because I really want this game to be wildly successful, so companies make more games like.

The only thing that might be a negative is the experience eventually ends. On the flip side, that very thing is what adds to the uniqueness and intensity when playing each session.

RATING: 3
This one is the most difficult to rate of all games I have played. On one hand it brings Pandemic to a new level. After finishing the game I certainly want to play another which of course is a good sign. On the other hand, the permanent changes in the game sometimes made me not want to play it as I was tired and didn't want a poor play ruin my chances in future rounds. These two arguments should lead to the rating 7 or possibly 6 in terms of BGG:s suggestions. On the other hand, I can't restart the game whenever I want which qualifies for the 1 rating, a broken game. The game is very expensive so it's unlikely that I would buy it again. Knowing what will happen and also knowing the large time investment which is needed makes me going for a rating 3 - "Likely won't play this again although could be convinced".

As a side note. It's incredible and ridicilus how this could be ranked as the best game at BGG. One thing is that the audience is biased, the people who didn't like the original wouldn't invest time or money in this one and also the fan-boys where quick to buy it. Another is that many persons doesn't re-evaluate their ratings.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An extraordinary game. I had played the original Pandemic more than a dozen times when it originally came out, and while I still held it in high regard - it didn't have the same thrill for me. With that in mind, my hopes were relatively reserved as to how they could attach the Legacy trappings to it.

I was blown away. It hasn't ever happened that one game has dominated our weekly game nights over the course of several weeks. And yet every time we were able to get together, this was on the table. Maybe it was just because we wanted to plow through the campaign before anything was spoiled for us, or maybe we just wanted to be among the first to be able to claim to have completed it. Or maybe it was one of the most engaging, most memorable game experiences we'd had in some time. Playing this was a reminder how solid of a game Pandemic is, and the pacing of the plotted story was exceptional as far as how the narrative elements played out gradually upping the stakes and the tension.

It suffers a couple of the same drawbacks as the core game - pure bad luck with card draws can quickly destroy your chances; which happened to us on more than one occasion. But despite getting ground in the wheels of game a few times, it spun a wonderfully integrated story. Not every moment of those 18 games were memorable by any stretch, but certainly there are multiple instances that I will remember for years to come. When you look beyond the discussions of whether it's a good game, or the harbinger of doom of a consumerist attitude that will kill the hobby, isn't that lasting impression the most important part? That a group of people (in our case 3) got to experience and enjoy the tale that this game creates [i]together[/i], sharing in the victories and defeats, and relishing in the creation of our own unique gaming experience... You can't ask for a better result than that.

The game may be finished - and all but trash at this point - but given the option to go back in time and save my money, I'd spend it again in a heartbeat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Surprisingly, except for the legacy part, this is Pandemic. The legacy part spices up the game by 'saving' where infections have happened, rewarding victorious and even failed fights against infections, thereby customizing the game experience of each group. All this happens along a developing storyline I'm looking forward to explore further.

The added attraction of the legacy part at least compensates the loss in replayability once the game series is done. Hence, same rating for the time being as vanilla Pandemic.

I personally have no interest in seeing a slightly different version of the story, so what's done is done.  Having said all that, I think we all came to this game with low expectations, and were very impressed at how compelling it was, and how it was THE TOPIC that dominated our conversations, and it's all we really wanted to do.  Bravo!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Por mucho que se diga que es una experiencia, un juego de mesa es para cuidarlo y disfrutarlo cuando te apetezca y con diferentes personas.
Éste sin embargo se convierte en una obligación de jugar con los mismos, una partida tras otra, con pequeñas variaciones.
Estas variaciones son el bombazo de esta versión legacy. Que me parece muy buena idea, que es una experiencia y que es darle emoción, pero se debería hacer de otra forma: vender la campaña como una expansión para el pandemic normal, en una cajita con su sobre de cartas y componentes de usar y tirar, y no que te compres todo un juego entero y lo vayas destrozando.
El no destrozarlo e ir con cuidado, no lo recomiendo, si te compras esta versión es para hacerlo todo.
Personalmente en nuestro caso, vivimos la experiencia y acabamos tan hartos de jugar y jugar al mismo juego (porque de lo contrario si juegas cada mucho tiempo, ni te acuerdas de cómo ibas), que al final nos dio igual que quede un pandemic normal con pegatinas chulas, que ya no queremos más pandemic.
Sí que hubo un par de meses que molaron las cosas que sucedieron, y sí que hubo un momento al principio que vivías emoción de que las decisiones que tomases tenían consecuencias, pero el resto de meses fueron bastante poca cosa y nos fueron decepcionando. No comprendo que este juego esté el número 1, con los juegazos que tenemos hoy día.

RATING: N/A
2 - 4 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It is an extraordinary achievement in boardgaming history. The "Legacy" concept is perfectly suited to a game like Pandemic. They fit seamlessly into one another.

The game is tense, frustrating, challenging, frightening, and triumphant -- most of all it is engrossing. One is completely swept away by the story that Pandemic Legacy tells. It is a pleasure to play this game.

Bravo and hats off to Leacock, Daviau, and everyone else involved in producing this. [i]Shut Up & Sit Down, Rahdo Runs Through, DriveThruReview[/i] and Zee Garcia all named it the best game of 2015. I am in total agreement.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game accounts for my most memorable moments of gaming of all time. It took 4 days to play through it, with 2 weeks between each one, and it was incredible. In between games, we'd talk and text about it, read about other people's experience, I'd think about it in the shower or before going to sleep. Not only is it a great story, but how they modified the mechanisms and made them much richer, makes for one of the best games ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Completely played through.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Some "months" will be a breeze, some will kick your ass. It's a pretty good story, a ton of quality components, zero replayability but who cares? It's at least twelve sessions of a good game that you'll always remember.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you enjoyed Pandemic, You'll love Pandemic Legacy!  Legacy takes everything that was great about the original game and adds tons more.  Of course, you'll have to unlock this new content and it's well worth it.  The way you play the game influences the world and how it changes!

And now for those of you "nay-sayers" who think you can only play this game a limited number of times.  Says Who!?!  The rule book.  Once you've finished season 1 you can still play the game!  Play it however you like; traditional, with Legacy rules, etc.  I'm sure there's a way to add the traditional pandemic expansions as well.

And now for tearing up cards and altering, or as some of you would put it, "damaging" the game board.  If you really don't want to rip up cards just put them in the bottom of the game box.  I did that with my Risk Legacy game and it's just fine.  Once again I managed to overpower the rule book and realize that I could play by the rules and keep all the components to my game.  And as for putting stickers on the board and writing on game pieces, that's half the fun!  You're customizing your game so that it is unlike any other copy.  You can enjoy the twists and turns of your game and then see how things could have been different on your friends copy of the game!

Now, off the rant wagon.  This game absolutely deserves to be number one.  It's a solid game that gives you repercussions and rewards for your actions.  It immerses you in the game play.  You'll remember playing your game sessions for years to come.  Yes, sometimes bad things will happen to you in the game but the world is not all rainbows and butterflies.

This is a solid 10!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Blue box

UPDATE: Started the Legacy rules and we played 5 games in a row. Amazing.

RATING: 9
This game fits my game group really well. There is a lot of anticipation for each week and what new and interesting things will happen. We talk through all the options as a group and decide what we think will be best. Pandemic is a fantastic game and having lasting implications allows us to continue a story every week.

That being said like base Pandemic however this game doesn't need more than one person to play it. This leads to some players dominating the decision making and their decisions effecting the game more than others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
NO SPOILERS, don't worry.

2015-10-31 - 9 - After the very first game it's a 9. It's awesome and I can see that it is only the beggining of a great adventure. I have never felt before so responsible for my decisions like I did in this game.

2015-12-05 - After 4 games it's holding really strong!

2016-05-21 - 9->7 - We finished the campaign. This game had many great moments, but it suffers from some issues, which the biggest one is constant changes in rules, which are not precise enough or ephasized enough. Of course we could read the rulebook from the beggining to the end every time the rules were changed, but it's not a fun thing to do in the middle of the game.
The story was OK, but it was not as thrilling as the legends said. We were a little disappointed by the finale as well.
I enjoyed the game but I'm not sure if I would like to play it again knowing what I already know, even if the story would be erased from my mind.
After all I prefer regular Pandemic with two expansions.
I am really glad that I finished such a hyped game, but I know I will not jump on the second season right away as well as on other Legacy games.

RATING: 8.75
You won't play anything else like this game. That is at least until everyone copies it, but this is the original and it is an amazing game. The tense, dynamic and ever-changing situation makes it feel about as real as any boardgame ever will.

03/02/16 update: I have lowered my rating slightly due to some disappointment over how the last two months of the game played. It felt a bit anticlimactic after logging so many plays and so many hours with the game. Still a great game, but I enjoyed the middle months (April-October) the most.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
(Spoilers)Positives:
-Story is good for first three quarters
-Unexpected plot twists and turns
-Interesting mechanics, characters introduced
-Legacy elements keep game fresh, though become somewhat predictable later on based on shape of the cutout, etc.

Negatives
-Still pandemic at its core (meaning easy to have alpha players, mechanisms of the original game almost always present)
-Some bonuses are almost useless, or are underpowered compared to others.
-Story kind of tapers off at the end, would have liked more writing, kind of anticlimactic.
-Many rules discrepancies and broken combos which are legal. Needed to refer online for last several games. This stuff should be addressed in rulebook.
-Seems to be typos/wrong information in places, this may be fixed in newer printings. Was confusing at times.


Would recommend if you enjoy pandemic and have a good group without alphas!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
(2015-11-28)
I fully admit it crumbles my cookies to see something as bad as this shoot up the ranking.

"Defies description as a game" is very apt. Games have common-knowledge rules by definition.

Setting aside categorical issues, the story is laughably bad and the gameplay consists of unimaginative variations on pandemic. The level of game design effort is comparable to dreaming up a dozen chess variants without worrying about balance. It's made to be disposable — hardly an endearing trait, though not the root of my dislike.

I've explained and defended my remarks extensively in the forums and now I'm quite done with this shitty "game."

---
(2016-3-24)
On the bright side, this game has helped me be more economical with my time. Whenever I have been tempted to make a post on BGG, thinking to myself "the primary audience for this will be people who like Pandemic Legacy" has caused me to do otherwise.

It's also a good litmus test for opinions. That this travesty won 4 categories of the Golden Geek Awards shows them to be absolutely farcical.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
You need the right group to play this. Players that are not going to control people's actions while it's another player's turn. A passive player could feel like their not contributing and feel stuck in a campaign that can go on for weeks/months. And then that person may never come back to play.  I suggest making a rule, something that should apply to all co-ops that if it's not your turn let that specific player do what they want to do unless they ask for advice. The game itself is a very intuitive concept and I'm interested to see what they do for Season 2. I knock this down a couple points because I cringe at the idea of throwing away a game, and I wonder how many people have bought more copies because of mistakes or losing non-committed players and wanting to start over.

RATING: 7.2
I'm not too into coop games, but pandemic was a bit of an exception.   Because my son and his fiancee liked regular pandemic so much we decided to try Legacy.  For me it's the same gaming experience as regular pandemic, but with a different game set up each time.  It's fun, but we played February and March wrong due to the confusing rules about end-game conditions.  It is a bit fiddley and we have to review all the special cards & stickers before every game to refamilarize ourselfs with the "new" rules.  We're into June in the game (writing this in Jan 2017, started playing in November 2016) and my son is ready to take a break and play some other games when we get together.  I've gotten probably 20 plays of regular Pandemic the last 10 with "on the Brink" and honestly I would be just as happy to have had that experience and forgo Legacy.  Both are good for coop and entry games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pandemic is an already great game and the Legacy version expands on it greatly. One of the worries I had was as the game changes, and trust me it changes, that it would become slightly unbalanced. However, there are multiple systems in place that I will  not go over in this review that keep the game difficulty balanced. That is not to say it ever gets easy. The best part about Pandemic is that one wrong move and things can get out of control really quick. As far as the Legacy aspects of the game go, you have 8 secret boxes and many hidden dossiers that will change the game as you progress. These are welcome additions to the game and they do a good job of pacing them out as you go so you are never overwhelmed. For newcomers to Pandemic, I would play  few rounds of the base game, which you can do with the Legacy board, before starting. I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys strategic and tactical play with a good story and unique Legacy system.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.1
Some cool aspects to this game, but definitely not the best game of all time.  The legacy component is misleading -- the results of the game don't truly adapt to your decisions, you might get a slightly different experience on their narrative.  And it's still Pandemic -- far too much luck of the draw.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In a normal Pandemic session it does not hurt if the high amount of randomness destroys a game - you just reset and try again. The sessions are very short. But in this epic version every lost session carries over and has hard consequences for all the rest of the campaign. So if the huge random factors kill your session and result in a lot cities already in uprise, you have invested a lot of money in a game that will never make fun and that just plays you and not the other way round. Other than the normal Pandemic which is great here the randomness can kill a whole campaign. A pity.

(Random factor means: drawing always the same cities close to each other, so outbreaks kill the session without any chance for the group; the player cards always divide among the players without any chance to get a set; the needed action cards always coming at the end of the game; the first epidemic cards coming right in the first player turn AND resulting instantly in an outbreak...)

Our campaign has been totally ruined by starting with simple bad draw luck and having the first three months always exactly drawn the same color we cannot treat with right at the start of the game session...

Ah, and by the way: Why always the same f****** thematic background? It becomes anoying that even here you stumble upon... . Really, the designers had no other ideas than Captain Obvious?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I'm not sure, 5 games in and although there is tension and excitement, the knowledge that the game appears to proceed despite the outcome reduces the immersive qualities of the legacy concept. Still a long way to go and my impressions may change.

RATING: 9.9
Amazing experience. We've only played January at this point (will update this) but the Legacy system is incredibly compelling. Pandemic was already a great game and Legacy catapults it to the top of the heap.

That being said, I expect this to cool once other competitors start to introduce better Legacy-style games (Gloomhaven, newer Daviau projects) and the hype subsides but for now (Dec 2015), Pandemic: Legacy seems to be the game to beat.

Advent calendars in games are just too much fun.

(Nov 2016 update) Finished one campaign and into September in another. Definitely better the first time with the surprises. Different groups make for very different experiences. Still amazing.

RATING: 1
would like to try but have doubts. 
I have problem with pandemic and a problem with legacy.

The idea of a changing board is nice, but it assumes you have the time to play this, say, once a week. If you take it up after a month or so the tension is gone. 
Thematically, curing viruses in time wins you in Pandemic. Then more viruses come, and you must cure them. And again ad nauseam. Until the board is ruined.
Look if there was a way to capture the "story" that unfolded last time, I'd go for it in an instant, like "Last time in your favorite series happened this:" ...; 

You would play this with good friends only, and when you are young. You can't play with people you meet at most frequent once a month; you can't play it with acquaintances. You might start it up with your loved one, but how will you react when your loved one tells you half way (s)he's no longer interested, or just plays along in the impression that you want him/her to.

RATING: 7
I enjoyed the game in the moment.  I binged on it for 3 days, staying up much too late just playing and playing.  It was amazing.  However, after I took two steps back and looked at it objectively, I can see that it did little more than spoon-feed me some of the Pandemic expansion modules a game at a time.  Opening doors was interesting, but the fact that 99% of the doors were guaranteed opens, and that most of them were opened in waves, it made the "Legacy" experience feel a bit scripted.  I wish I had had more influence on the outcome of the story, rather than simply trying to do the best within the confines of a predestined outcome.   I also wish the game had resulted in some sort of stable-state unique Pandemic board and that it had more surprises.

All together, it was a great experience that I am glad I went through, but I am not sure how well it is as a game.

RATING: N/A
Pandemic Legacy is a co-operative campaign game, with an overarching story-arc played through 12-24 sessions, depending on how well your group does at the game. At the beginning, the game starts very similar to basic Pandemic, in which your team of disease-fighting specialists races against the clock to travel around the world, treating disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ugh! I would probably like this better if two things had happened: (1) Matt Leacock should have never released so many similar expansions for the base game. (2) It scaled better. Original Pandemic scales decently - it's not perfect, but those Event Cards do help ease the difficulty somewhat for a 4-or-5-player game (not so much in Original as much as in On the Brink). This game just takes away that huge advantage. It got to the point to where we were losing via the Outbreak track by the 3rd Epidemic. EVERY. SINGLE. GAME. That says to me that they didn't play-test the game enough. And I have always said that Pandemic feels like a game that they play-tested A LOT because so many games go down right to the wire. We rarely saw the wire in the last half of Season 1. The game promised a deeper story and stronger characters, but neither feels any deeper or stronger than in the original game. So, really, the whole thing just comes off as Pandemic: Now with Even More Rules! Pandemic has too many rules already. It certainly didn't need more! Had we played with just 2 characters, like so many others seem to have done, maybe we would have liked it more. With 4 characters, August through November were absolute chores. A game shouldn't be a chore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Bontatlan, magyar
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pandemic Legacy is an game that keeps you wondering, what's going to happen next?  The game provides a lot of different upgrades, abilities, and story.  What made it fun was either trying to eradicate viruses to get an upgrade, opening up new boxes and mission objectives, or the large amount of characters you can just shuffle around each month at your disposal.  Most friends or people with common interests will not sit and play this game approximately 18 times over until it ends.  However, for those that do, it is more than worth it.  You should be thankful for those friends because they are great people!!  If I were to state some items that I do not agree with, they would be that I don't like the scratch offs.  Even though they are fun and remind me of the times when I would get lottery tickets for Christmas, they make a mess when scratching which can be a pain in the ass.   One upgrade provided called the roadblock is pointless in my opinion.  My friend and I never used them, don't see a use for them, and would find other upgrades or tropes to be more useful instead of using them.  I also found that if the creators are to put in dialogue or story through letters and emails near the end of the game, put them in the beginning as well.  Most of the writing does not serve much of a game playing advantage besides extending the story.   While making this, the creators should have thought went with the idea of either we put it in for the whole game or don't put it in at all.  I would also have to say that game is a bit easy in my opinion.  Maybe I'm wrong but I do like a difficult challenge.  You could say it is well balanced.  However, my friend and I were two people playing 4 characters which makes it harder and we were rolling through 3 months without getting close to losing.  However, I don't hold that point much against the game since the progression keeps it exciting and fresh.  It got a bit harder when getting closer to the end.    What I do like is the large range of characters you get to use and the fact that they are expendable.  The medic you so badly covet can be lost and gone forever if you are not careful.  I also love the subtle upgrades.  Ones such as grenade belt and nuke made me and my friend chuckle when thinking about the application.  Again, Pandemic Legacy is so much fun.  My co-workers roll their eyes because they are tired of hearing me talk about how much fun it is.  I very much look forward to the next season.  From what I've seen and heard, it is going to be a dystopian future which puts it in a place to utilize a lot of post apocalyptic ideas and themes.  That being said, I like the game where it is going.  I hope they continue unless they are repeated and watered down like the hit T.V. shows Smallville or Scrubs that last for 9 or 10 seasons ugh...  In the case that if it does, move on!  One more note, the saddest part of playing Pandemic Legacy is the fact that you just finished the number one rated game from boardgame geek and have to find something else to do that is equally satisfying.  There is only one direction to go which is most likely down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm generally not a fan of cooperative games but Pandemic has always been my favorite. The story was captivating and intertwined with the legacy elements wonderfully. My wife and I were hooked from the get go although I don't need to play this again.

RATING: N/A
This is hard to rate. It's technically my favourite game I've ever played.

But, I wouldn't want to play it again. It's one of those weird things that don't fit into the boardgame rating system here.

I wouldn't want to rate it low, as people will think I don't like it. But based on what 8,9 and 10 mean here on BGG, I don't know how much I'd want to replay it now I have finished it.

TLDR: So I won't rate this game due to the above. But it is a 10 in terms of everything except BGG's own statement of 'would always play it'.

RATING: 10
Pandemic Legacy : Season 1 is my first legacy game and I love it so far. New elements introduced throughout the games make this an incredible journey. The immersion in this game engaged our playgroup in a way I've never experienced before with another board game. The brainstorming in the set-up for character/event cards selection, the harsh decisions during game and the choices of permanent bonuses after a game makes it a perpetual puzzle you try to optimize. I'm starting to appreciate Pandemic mechanics more than I thought since Alpha player syndrome doesn't seem to be too much of an issue with this group.

RATING: 9

RATING: 10

RATING: 9.5
Played months to coincide with calendar months in 2017.  An extremely enjoyable experience.  There were lulls where a few months were 'less exciting' in the narrative but overall it was fantastic. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't understand the people who didn't like original Pandemic but loved this one, but to me this is still a great game. Not on my top 10, but I can see how some people think it is unparalleled. 

*POSSIBLY MINOR SPOILERS*

The game starts off initially very much like original Pandemic, but as the game progresses your objectives, your character abilities, and the parts of the map evolves along the way. About a third of the way into the game there is a seemingly quite drastic change to the game. However, the general feel of Pandemic still remains, in that you are scurrying around trying to quell hot spots while still having enough time to fulfill the win condition. To me, the legacy system didn't seem that innovative. Instead, it felt like playing a campaign variant of Pandemic, with a ton of different modules thrown in. In fact, there are a lot of stuff that are nods towards things added in the normal game expansions. The ability to switch characters (and often advisability to do so), lack of uniqueness between specific cities, and few in game events I think made the story weaker than it could have been. However, playing a ton of modules of Pandemic with stuff carrying over from game to game is not necessarily a bad thing. One of my main complaints of base game Pandemic was it felt samey, and this game definitely spiced things up from month to month.

The constant additions to the board does make it cool that no two games are the same, but it also made the board very bloated with different modifiers and I think they could have made things a bit cleaner.

I went 12 & 3 on my campaign (which I binge played in one day), and while a bit disappointed the game wasn't harder, found it enjoyable even in our twelfth hour of game play, so there is something to be said about that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Simply incredible experience. Split the cost with 3 friends and have been playing it through. We are only ~1/2 through and we downright love this game! Simply Incredible.

RATING: 9.5
So worth the hype. Amazing experience that takes the original Pandemic game (great game in and of itself) and makes something magical.

The advent-calendar-esque boxes are a blast to open, the story is fun and exciting, the components are great quality, and the Legacy aspect is amazing. You definitely find yourself looking back and wishing you had done something differently to prevent an issue you're dealing with now, and it's great to see the characters grow across games.

Note: The campaign is long (as it should be, since it's only designed to be played through once) so make sure you have a committed group who is willing to meet once a week/month/whatever for a number of weeks/months to finish it out.

RATING: 1
(Math Trade: Got it for [thing=147190][/thing] in [geeklist=212479][/geeklist], 2016-09-07)

I'm not a fan of Pandemic in the first place, this rating is based on watching the GameNight! video. I have no objection at all to Campaign/Legacy games, it's an interesting concept. However in this case, the designers and/or publisher went too far, by deciding to make the game unplayable once the campaign is done. Instructing players to literally break the game while playing. Components easily could have been provided to avoid permanent modification of the game pieces, such as tokens, counters, notepads, erasable pens and cards (etc) instead of stickers and destroying cards. This game can no longer  be played once "finished" due to permanent  modifications which is absolutely unacceptable. A game should be able to be re-played and/or shared amongst friends. This is the very definition of a broken game.

Sold on 2017-04-28.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
It's good, but not #1-on-BGG good.

Update #1: We just started June, so we're at roughly the halfway point. The way the board becomes permanently modified is cool, as is the ever-expanding rule set, but man am I getting tired of playing against a deck of cards. Dumb randomization makes for a capricious opponent. No matter how well you focus on your objectives and manage the diseases, a bad shuffle can undo everything.

Update #2: We're in August, and I'm so ready to be done.

Update #3: September. I'm really starting to hate this game. It was early in the game, we had things under control, then over two turns things escalated to six outbreaks in difficult territory. We lost two turns after that.

Final update: I've come to despise this game. Unlucky card draws will cost you the game, no matter how well you plan. The final objectives would have been a joke had they not been so insulting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
[Played a full campaign]

For comparison, I rate Pandemic 9 (and On the Brink 8).

The rules changing between games are fine, to force the players to reconsider their strategic approach (and to add variety).
The rules chaning during a game are not fine at all. It randomly hinders you or has no practical effects or sometimes even helps you... based on something you had no idea would have those consequences (so, as random as it can be). I suppose someone may like the "surprise" factor, but I find it the epitome of bad design as far as "strategy" goes.

It is easier than normal Pandemic (and much easier than Pandemic + Brink), so the only challenge is due to the occasional random screwage. Not a good feeling at all.

The narrative is short, banal and fails to add anythin to the experience.

The whole "campaign" idea is the core of any RPG and many videogames (and when you're done, one click on "new game" is enough... you don't have to rebuy it), so I do not get why it is praised so much (it is not common in boardgames because... it is a plainly bad idea for this medium).

It is expensive and "play once" (that single campaign lasts for as few as 12 games)... not exactly why I appreciate boardgames.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Pretty solid and fun, yet don't played that much; rating will change in future

RATING: 10
Anniversary gift for my gf as it's a co-op game+ranked no.1 on BGG at the time. I have to say the 14 runs that we had were one of the best, if not the best, board-game experiences that I had.

Personally I'm not a big "Pandemic" person. I was never that drawn into the theme. Plus, I am not really a co-op person. But this legacy version completely blew my mind. The box-opening, the story-twisting, the event-triggering. Every decision you make will impact future sessions. And every session is so well-balanced that there were so many moments where our lives were dependent on the last few infection cards we drew. Excitements, suspense, and surprises. 10/10 all day.
