RATING: 9
I like original Pandemic.  This game is like playing Pandemic with a very clever friend adding expansion modules over time to keep the game fresh and interesting for every play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game truly lives up to the hype. You and your teammates play a series of 12-24 games where each of your games has consequences for the next. A bad decision or bad draw can haunt you for the rest of the game but similarly a well-planned upgrade can pay for itself 10 times over. As a cooperative board game it pushes you to your limits in the best way possible: this one doesn't play itself so you and your teammates will often take 5-10 minute pit stops arguing about the best course of action (at least we did!). The objectives can change without notice which keeps the game fresh and exciting.

 The biggest drawback is that the game's only designed for one campaign. This was initially a major turnoff but we got so much use out of it that I have not regrets: our campaign was 16 games and I can't think of any other game I sunk that kind of quality time into during the past 5 years. 

Everything from the high stakes decision-making to the wealth of personalized upgrades came together to make a super polished game. If you can get a dedicated group of 3-4 people together on a regular basis you owe it to yourself to try this one out!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
More entertaining than regular pandemic.  An intense short-term experience, like playing a good video game to the end. I suspect that this style of game is going to be a new fad.

It's not really new or revolutionary, though.. Well, except that it combines an advent calendar with a campaign-style game.  At its core, it's the same mechanism that drives RPGs and other campaign games.  But, it does have a couple of big reveals in certain months that change major assumptions.  The earlier games remind me of the training scenarios that some games have, where rules are introduced to you gradually from one game to the next.  Overall, it is well-done, the bling aspect is great, and it is quite fun.

Finished in 17 plays.  If you peel the stickers off after you're done, you can use it as a base game set that is compatible with the non-Legacy expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The Legacy aspect of it is awesome! Each game there's a new twist, new strategy that needs to be thought out and everything you do affects future gameplay! While original Pandemic got us into modern boardgaming back in 2007, this just brought a whole new fresh perspective. It will be sad when the year is done and there's no more 'surprises' to open each game, but I'm sure we'll still try to play it since it adds a whole bunch of new things to vanilla Pandemic. It may be hype that everyone is rating this game a 10 as it just came out, but it really deserves to be in the highest ranks given its innovative nature. The components are top notch and everything just work well together from the legacy deck to the boxes/tabs that need to be opened as you progress. The downside is when opening some of the tabs, they may rip or detach incorrectly so its a bit messy keeping track of all the new content introduced, but beside that we are really enjoying the gameplay so far (just finished June, lost a game in April and June when we tried playing with more than 2)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[There are NO SPOILERS in my comment]

My wife and I are playing this one together, with one character apiece (at least to start with, but probably for the whole run), and what a treat that is! I hesitated before rating this a 9 after our first play: I almost went with a 10 right out the gate, which I've only done once to date (for Hive Pocket).

Pandemic Legacy features everything I like about vanilla Pandemic -- the tension, the dash of good and bad luck that can make or break a game, the thrill of racing against the many loss conditions to win, the joy of cooperating against a challenging game (when there's no alpha player, of course), and solid and engaging gameplay -- but it adds delicious, and utterly delightful, legacy elements.

The "kid in a candy store" feeling from Risk Legacy (which I also loved) is present here, and maybe even more refined. Naming characters is a beautiful thing; it's charmingly evil because it grounds them, makes you want to play them again, and starts them on a more personal journey as you play. I love it.

Using the legacy deck to pace the year and reveal new goodies is a fantastic approach, and I can't wait to see what future months bring. I cooled on vanilla Pandemic after 10+ plays (it currently sits at a 7), but "Pandemic that changes every game" has my full attention.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Takes the excellent game of Pandemic and turns it into an epic story telling experience.

Pros:
-Pandemic core game
-Permanent upgrades
-Interesting story telling elements
-Captivating experience
-Solo or with friends

Cons:
-Permanent changes
-Once complete goes in the trash
-18+ Hours for full experience

RATING: 7.5
Dont own but played through friends copy.

My rating is possibly a little harsh as actually really enjoyed playing it. 
Dont want to spoil the story but was disapointed by the ending. The final scoring involved elements hinted at in the story but were independent from the indivdual goals of each scenario.
If at the start was hinted, pay attention to the story and overarcing plot not just individual goals would have fared significantly better in final outcome.

The other thing wasnt a problem with my playgroup (at least hope others didnt feal was from me!) and thats 'alpha player' problems.  Would be all to easy for one player who knows pandemic to dominate the group with others feeling like they were only helping them and not really playing themselves.
Bare that in mind when playing and people with dominant personalities try to make sure you are envolving all your group.

RATING: 7
The gameplay is more immersive than the original game, and makes for a remarkable play experience. But at the end of the day, it's still Pandemic.  It's very prone to the alpha player syndrome, making other players feel less involved. And the legacy version gets Way more complicated than the original, to a fault. The endgame is very analytical and think-heavy, like trying to solve a puzzle. That's not really a bad quality though, it fits in well with how you play the game. But should be noted with the overall playing experience, as lighter gamers likely won't enjoy that as much.

RATING: 10
A singular experience that I doubt will ever be duplicated - because of how unexpected it was, and how seamlessly the story and gameplay melded together. That said, there are more rules in this game than possibly any other game I've played, and I love heavy games. Each game took 10-15 minutes of setup and rules review before playing.

Super enjoyable but not for your baby gamers. 

(Marking as previously owned because whatever you call the pile of torn up cards I own now, it's not Pandemic Legacy anymore.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Regular Pandemic was quite fun enough (but would get boring in several sessions, leaving it as a "sometimes" game). But Legacy put it "on steroids": constantly changing map, evolving exciting storyline, new stuff all the time. It has quite simple rules but requires quite a bit of thinking to find an optimal way to solve the problems faced, which can escalate quite quickly. Mostly recommended for groups of 3-4 (best 4), and you should probably buy this game all together - it is a legacy game, board and its components are constantly modified/destroyed, so game loses its sell value completely by the time it is finished. Also duration of 15-20 games average is very decent - occupies quite a lot of time but not too much, making it boring. Duration is just right. Each game takes roughly 1.5hours, since you also need to constantly read new content and make decisions on the go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Bought at Go! Calendars store after Christmas sale.  50% off of MSRP.

First playthrough with Michelle and Daniel.  Such an amazing game, where every decision really counts.  We often spend as much time discussing character upgrades as actually playing the game.  The tension is unparalleled.

The legacy element means every game is different.  It's exciting to think just how different he board will be a couple months down the road.

The game also has a great "funding" element which helps scale difficulty as you win or lose.

Lack of "replayability" isn't an issue, since approx. 16 games (average played) is plenty for the value.

----

8/7/16.  Finished playthrough with Michelle and Daniel.
Total Score: 457
Total Games: 19
- Had a good streak first half of the year.
- Michelle took a break from gaming, with us having a 4 month hiatus.  On our first game back, we lost the dispatcher and the board exploded with Faded due to our mistakes.
- We forgot to add Faded to the board whenever drawing a yellow player card.
- We forgot we could add equipment stickers to cards when at Research Stations.
- The end was somewhat anticlimactic ("At Long Last, It's Over..."), although there were plenty of games that ended in bare wins or losses. 
- Maintains score due to memorable experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
2nd best game of 2015. I miss the expansions when playing this, but I think there will be more challenging elements as the game goes on. I love Pandemic so this is fun expansion/addition to family, but destroying the game feels wrong as I'm against consumerism. Continuous story is fun in itself of course. For now I'll give it about same rating as Pandemic (close to perfect), despite lack of fun elements from expansions, but I will easily lower it if endgame doesn't deliver.

Update: February game began to fix my problems right away. Ripping up the cards still feels very unnecessary, but sticker and surprise aspect have began to redeem themselves in my eyes. Most importantly an expansion element appeared in emergent and interesting way, which makes me want to keep playing. With only 2 funding from winning first game (in practice 0 as we they were shuffled to bottom..) it also wasn't a cakewalk like January. I guess January is best viewed as tutorial game that's mostly there to ease you in Legacy elements and set the scene. Hopefully rest of the months are as interesting as February and keep adding interesting decisions. I'll update once more when I'm through (more likely) or given up the game. For now it deserves 10..

Guide to not Destroying the Game: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1483324/guide-not-destroying-game-so-you-can-replay-spoile

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Possible Spoilers:

Great twist on an already great game. This was the first Legacy game I'd ever played, and honestly, I'm still only half-way through. I started a 3 player campaign over a year ago with my brother and  my roommate, and in a day in a half we covered some good ground, but haven't all been able to get together since then.

I love that as the months progress (in game) there's new challenges, characters, and rules that come into play... I mean, no shit right? It's a Legacy game, after all!

We had so much fun playing this, and I can see why it was #1 for so long, but let me tell you: this game is HARD AS SHIT! Seriously, just when you think your group might be finally getting the hang of things, Pandemic Legacy delivers a fucking haymaker! POW! And you're flat on your ass...

Maybe I should have started a full 4-player campaign.

Tip: START A CAMPAIGN WITH 4 PLAYERS!!!

RATING: 9
An incredible gaming experience. The plot is cliché and nothing to write home about, and there are some really retarded flaws when getting to the end of the campaign (about which I will not talk here, for that would require the giving away of some major spoilers), but don't let that push you away from the amazing game that's inside this box. A lot changes as you progress, and you really feel the changes, right from the first game. Alpha players can be a problem, but the whole puzzle-solving does encourage the team to think as a group and come up with a solution to everything that is going on. Highly recommended, especially if you can get 4 people to play the campaign from the beginning to the end.

RATING: 10
Can't believe the number of 0 ratings from people who have never played it. This game was such a fun experience, I can't imagine someone legitimately hating it. I will admit, it was a little bittersweet finishing the game, knowing that you can't continue to play it as the same experience... That is only due to the fact that it was so fun opening up the new items, knowing that the next game will change and the excitement of seeing what's next. The game is finite and changing, which is what made the gameplay so great, but it's literally so good that you don't want it to end, therefore making it a kind of catch-22. 
This game 100% deserves a place in the top 10 games on this site.

RATING: 10
Pandemic Legacy is an amazing experience. The permanent changes to the game make the game experience visceral and very tense. The feelings that I had while opening new doors and going through the story are simply incredible.

I finally finished the campaign and my rating stands. This games provides an experience like no other. I hope that others can build on this concept and continue to innovate!

RATING: 10

RATING: 6.6
Currently at the end of May. The game was very fun for a while, but the difficulty has gone through the roof (or we are just having terrible luck) because our last two games have both been literally unwinnable. In a legacy style game it is a real bummer to get crushed and have no chance whatsoever. It's strange because we've had some games that were mindlessly easy and others that were unwinnable. In regular Pandemic this doesn't really bother me because I can just shrug and play again, but I'm finding it to be a big turnoff here. Update: I think we have been making a couple of mistakes with the rules that have made the game harder, which raises another issue--you can't go back to fix this sort of thing once you've played enough to understand what you are doing...

RATING: 10

The changing elements in each game, narrative arc, and evolving objectives really work well here in creating a super compelling reason to just keep playing. RATING: 10
Wow!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Game in a Nutshell: Like base Pandemic, but with evolving storyline and mechanics.

Played as: 2,3,4 player

Pros: Great storyline with killer twists.  You really build a relationship with different aspects of the game as it evolves. For example, there become places on the map so destitute, that you get this sense of dread just thinking about going there.  And just when/if you think you have a handle on the current game state, the game throws a curveball.  Amazing.

Cons: The biggest con... the game is going to end. And then you're going to have this awkard dilema of if it's ok to just throw the whole game in the garbage. During the game, it can be a pain to evaluate rules on the fly. We made some mistakes, and though none really affected us too terribly, it's not like you get a re-do.

Other: You know that feeling of dread in regular Pandemic as you're drawing off the infection deck and you're anticipating your game escalating before you're ready? I had that feeling in this game on a grander scale. I actually had a point or two where I wasn't sure I wanted to play the next month (game), because I was terrifed of the next twist. That said, I'd have kept playing this game far beyond when the game ended had it let me.

Best Use: Enjoy it like your favorite TV series. Love it, talk about it with those in the know, but understand it's got to end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
https://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/201593/item/4340825#item4340825

"The Legacy Card Deck drives the permanent game changes -- These changes keep each game month fresh, proviiding a slightly different puzzle to solve each month.

If players didn't enjoy the group-puzzle-solving concept of the original Pandemic, they may not like Pandemic Legacy. Players are still tasked with finding an optimal way to play the game, and it's up to players to police themselves and not let someone alpha-gamer everybody's turns. "

RATING: N/A
2-4 Players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
10/10. Vanilla Pandemic is a 6 for me. I don't generally like cooperative games. Other legacy games do not have a strong appeal. But this was a great experience. While the story's twists are not all that shocking, they are well executed. That story combines with the characters and other personalized effects to create a lot of emotional investment. Decisions were difficult, sometimes gut-wrenching, the stakes felt high, and we always wanted to play "one more game" and only relented for sleep and other commitments. Highly recommended.

Choose a stable group of four players. The mechanics allow you to switch up, but players will feel like they've only watched half the episodes of a favorite series. Use a good ball-point pen; "permanent" markers wipe right off. Box opening instructions are under the stickers. They are easy to miss; always check under the sticker doors as you open them.

Played 16 games: 11 wins and 5 losses. Score: 749/1000 (Disaster Averted).

I played a second time with three first-timers. I had planned to stay out of some of the bigger decisions, but in practice since it had been nearly two years since my first campaign, I didn't remember things with such clarity that I felt I had to recuse myself. I knew about the major twists coming up but had forgotten some of the fine triggers and felt I could discuss things neutrally anyway.

A second play is not as exciting as the first, unsurprisingly, but was still excellent. One of the key things that makes the legacy aspect work differently than a typical campaign game (such as an rpg or rpg-like) is the repetition-with-changes model. It's not a sandbox and it's not strictly scenario-based. It is raw mechanical changes thematically woven (story-driven) into a solid, repeatable euro game. The result is amazing and I'm still mystified by those this does not resonate with.

RATING: 8
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Wildly popular legacy version of the nearly-as-popular co-op
* Legacy aspect lends a rich story feel to each subsequent play
* Price point (as well as the aforementioned story) make destroying parts of the game worth it
* Seems to be best for four (with less, you lose some of the possible storyline)
* Good for fans of co-ops and those with dedicated gaming groups
* Initial rating: [b]8/10[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Might have been a 10 with a 4 person group and/or more RP dynamic (or after the campaign ends).

Update: I've revised this rating up.  My observation still stands that both of those might have made it even better, but as the campaign wraps up (Currently heading into Dec.) this is easily one of the best gaming experiences I've been part of.

It's also not nearly as tough as it's made out to be and the fact that we've made it to December without a scar either says something to that effect or to our play style.

2nd Update: Finished the campaign without a scar on any character and kicked December's butt.  This was a great game.

Last time went swimmingly.  Things panned out in a nearly perfect fashion and we finished with no real consequences.  I'm digging how this game auto balances to make sure you can still enjoy it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a pretty awesome game. How could it not be, it is based off of one of the best coop style games Pandemic? We bought this near when it came out and super excitedly played about 2 games a week for the months. Fast-forward 1 year and we are about 7 months through the scenario and playing a game a month. At the two year mark? About to start December and it hasn't made it to the table in months. Remind me, what were the new rules? How many characters are there now? What were we trying to do? Uh.. so much work to play - I'd rather play regular Pandemic. Verdict - Buy this if you can play ~18 plays in less than 2 years. Oh, and one more knock, the best part of this game is opening the advent boxes - not actually playing the game.

RATING: 9
Pandemic is an excellent game, the legacy part is very well done. Interesting story with twists and turns, introducing new mechanics regularly and opening the boxes is very exiting. Component are very nice, felt kind of weird throwing the game away afterwards. I played through it with my girl in 1,5 week on a holiday in France playing one or two games every night. The randomness of the card draw in pandemic can really screw you over badly in some games, but I felt like the game did balance this out quite well. If you are in any way interested in this and you have the group and time to do it then this certainly is a must play!

RATING: 8.75
Wow. What a powerful game.

Pandemic (as can be read above) got sold because I played it too much and it was the same thing over and over. The core mechanics are solid (and super challenging), but it was always the same. Then, along comes Season 1 of Pandemic: Legacy. I never thought much of Risk: Legacy because I abhor Risk. But the idea of a game board which permanently changes with play... AND the story of a secret storyline revealed over time... intrigued the hell out of me.

Richard and I played through the whole thing. We played like trash, with an abysmal final score of 193. Total garbage. A huge challenge of a game. But we still adored it.

RATING: 6
We're done with this. A couple sessions flirted with an 8, but overall it felt like a 7 while we were playing. It's definitely a step up from vanilla Pandemic, but once you're done, you're [i]done[/i]. I'd somehow convinced myself that we'd have a cool customized version of Pandemic we could keep playing, but the mechanisms for December literally remove replayability as you try to win the game. As such, I have pretty much zero interest in playing again, but can't deny the good times we had. A 6 it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Shrink
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Just amazing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Spel Antwerpen

Wow! What an amazing experience! OK, we already loved Pandemic but this is even better. You really get sucked into the game from month one! Every decision counts and we really tried to do our best as much as we could and still it was only in one of the ultimate turns that we could win our first game! Ultimate game experience! Highly recommended! I don't get it when people just hate this game based on the fact that it's a legacy game without even trying it. Especially because this game will probably see more game plays than most of our other games. Imo it has a very good value for your money  just because of the legacy concept, we are going to play this game more than any other game in our collection of similar weight and after the campaign we still have a personalized copy of Pandemic. Update: we finished the campaign after 14 plays, which is less than 3 euro per game play for 4 players. One of the best price/overall experience values you can get!

*** TOP 5 games of all time ***

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
NO SPOILERS! Yes, this is a 'consumable' kind of game where you are 'spoiled' of the surprises and the story line when you have played it through. But it does not necessarily mean that this is a 'one-time-only' kind of game. Just because you know what are there waiting for you does not mean you cannot re-experience everything again and enjoy the game the second time around. I know people who are willing to replay it, particularly with others who haven't. I am one of them. Even if, it is solely because of this reason: the experience was that satisfying, that exciting and that electrifying, you want your loved ones, your friends, even strangers to experience it too. You'll be willing to sit through the long plays, even hold yourself back to not tell them the 'secret', to be with them when they discover the twists and the turns that make this game remarkable. That extent of willingness is a mark of a very good game in my book. We know movies, TV series, books that we watch and read many many times and sometimes do that with the uninitiated so we can share their happiness or disbelief when the 'turns' of the story appear. We don't call those movies or books a 'one-time-only', so I won't call this game that either. Come to think of it, isn't this what being a geek all about? We are sometimes the ones in 'the know' and the ones who hold 'the secret' just because we were there first. But it is the source of our deepest joy when that secret was finally found out by others and we are willing to go through the ride again just for that. Not to mention that we simply love the book, the story and in this case, the game. It is every bit the definition of 'outstanding' the way BGG meant it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Owned by Maple.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
There is no way around it: this is one insanely addicting game. Did it deserve its number 1 status? Maybe not, because it IS a one shot plus the base game is "just" Pandemic (which I've grown a bit tired of; it basically becomes a push your luck game when you learn the basics & has very few reasonable decisions), after all. BUT this is still 12-24 plays a box, which is more plays than 90% of games I've played get anyway.  

The Legacy system works incredibly well and improves the basic game in every way. The added mechanics and rules are thematically and mechanically sound. The Legacy system also just makes you want to play more, immediately. To get more stuff, to open more boxes. It's like crack. The flavour and suspension it adds to the game is truly unique, as of yet. 

Still, I hope Season 2 alters the base mechanics somewhat, because I've had enough of Pandemic per se.

The new stuff was really cool at times, but sometimes the games were just dragging on, or the chrome was too tacked on. Over stayed it's welcome. It had some high highs, and some low lows. I am glad I played it, but will never play a big legacy game like this again. I could have played 18 other games, and I wish I had done that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not so bad, but basically it´s still Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
WARNING! POSSIBLE SPOILERS IN THIS COMMENT!

I'm starting to come around on this game. Only a month in, and I'm already chomping at the bit to play it more. I don't even care for Pandemic that much, but to see all the permanent changes happen is something I really enjoy.
---
4 games in, January and February. I'm finding out just how poor of a Pandemic player I am, but a very cakewalk-like 4th game had me avoiding the 8th door in the box. I thought about throwing the game, but didn't want to mess with the system. This game is tough, but in a good way. I'm really liking how this game is developing. One complaint so far, however, is that the instructions on the cards don't really differentiate between opening boxes and peeling off things in the files. Seems like kind of an odd oversight. Still, this game is up to a 9 for me. We'll see how I feel when it's all said and done, but for now, I'm really enjoying the ride. Not to mention 2 of my characters are 1 scar away from dying!
---
Well, the Faded have shown up, with Taipei being City Zero. They have already spread from Beijing down to Sydney after a single game. I also ended up getting my first win without having to repeat a month in March. Ended up switching out the Dispatcher for the Operations Expert to join my Scientist, Researcher (Both still with 2 scars each), and Medic. So far all my losses have been due to outbreaks. Still don't see the usefulness of military bases.
---
Finished the game with 7 wins and 9 losses for a score of 706. Soldier, General, Medic, and Immunization Expert all ended up dying before the end. Quarantine Expert ended up being the traitor, which sucked because she was my favorite/most useful character. I loved this experience though, and would enjoy going back through with my wife. Favorite month was probably either April for the Faded Figures or November for the Immunizations coming into effect.

---

Playing through a second time, and I have to admit that the events aren't as interesting this time around. I'd rate the game a 7 on a second playthrough.

RATING: 10
Wow.
This game will win all sorts of prices.

I do like Pandemic a lot.
But this is something else. And it's even something else in comparison with other "Legacy type" games.
Flawless. Tight. Cleverly designed. Excitement and a true feeling a cooperation. Wonderful storytelling campaign superbly built into the the game.
A TRUE hit for coop lovers like myself.

We had played a few games when we decided to try out PL. This immediately lowered the other games we had played during the day to a mediocre level. It kept us up til 4 am the other day.

Well done Matt and the rest of you. I envy you!

EDIT: After 7 games played (2 losses) it's still a 10, but the greatness of the games makes my demands rise even higher. Therefor, I feel it's a bit repetitive, the storyline is halting a bit since the game basically "resets" every month, plus the fact that it suffers quite a lot from the Dominant player syndrome. The latter could start annoying me too much actually.

EDIT: Finished the campaign. 17 games. Fantastic experience even though our last months became ridiculously easy, leaving a bit of bitter anticlimactic after-taste. Nevertheless looking forward to season 2! Oh please make it good!

RATING: 3
We've played through september and this was our 6th loss in a row. We realized too late how important roadblocks were, and with a bit of bad luck the game snowballed against us.
We are going to finish this game, but we are definately in the mood of "Getting this over with" instead of enjoying it.
You may say we are bad players and made bad decisions, but the game should be able to guide us back to a state where it is managable again. This is however not the case. Asia is gone and so are parts of north+south America.
I consider this bad game design and not the fault of the players. We are barely able to set up the game for the coming months before the game destroys us. Getting 3 complete turns is neigh impossible.

I'm getting more and more convinced of NOT getting season 2.

To the normal Pandemic game is added a layer of rules and add ons for a campaign legacy game. The game itself is quite tense, but throw in a campaign and it becomes even harder. 

What makes the game shine is that you are problem solving as a team as new obstacles and surprises come up in the game. The story is really enjoyable and quite clever leading to a high enjoyment factor. It's quite thematic in the situations you are put in, and what your characters have to do.

RATING: 10
Pandemic Legacy contains everything that made the original Pandemic such a fantastic board game, repackaged into a campaign format that creates a deep sense of investment in the results of each passing play, and wrapped in a thrilling yarn of global politics and medical R&D. The resulting experience continuously shifts just enough that the individual rounds of the game never grow stale, while simultaneously conveying an overarching sense of epic scale and grand storytelling.

RATING: 7
After playing it five times, I disagree with both 10s and 1s out there. It is a great experience, but, just like Pandemic, not a very interesting game. The actions are repetitive and there are not many strategies here, even including the powers. But, then, this was my problem with Pandemic in the first place. I'd still play Robinson Crusoe any day of the week over it.

The fact that you can't play it more than 24 times (which is more than most people play most games anyway...) is not a problem, though. It feels like a video game or a movie experience, and I don't play or watch them more than once ever. It's a great experience (and I use this word again), so enjoy it while it last and that's it. As a game, it's a 6. As an experience, a 8. So I make it an 7 and I'm happy with it.

One more thing. Ok, I also don't think this is the best game ever. I have my own Top10 and this is not there. Giving 1s just because you disagree with people's choice is, however, a very stupid thing to do. Have you played it? Do you really think the game is that bad? If not, you're just an idiot trying to convince other people of your truth (like a fanatic, get it?). And, please, do not say it's not a game because it only lasts one playthrough.

Edit: I maintain my score, but I have to admit that I'm having a tough time finishing it. After a while, the surprise effect is gone and only Pandemic is left. Overall, a fun experience, but there are too many better games out there.

RATING: 8
SPOILER ALERT! This game comment contains spoilers. Do not read if you want to avoid them at all cost.
I waited to write a comment until the game was finished so I could include my full experience. Quick disclaimer: I played the entire campaign with Zeynep as two players. We had a blast! The beginning was incredibly fun and engaging as the game changed substantially every single month, with military forces coming into play, C0dA continuing to evolve, and new characters joining in the struggle. Around the middle of the game, we started to feel that the game was getting a bit repetitive, since the only thing that changed was the search card. With the medication coming in, things got exciting again and we ended the game on a high note. We both found the overall experience to be highly enjoyable and are looking forward to the next season.

Even after the campaign ended, we keep playing regular Pandemic by simply ignoring the stickers. The regular plays are also logged under this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
By February, I knew why everyone raved about PL:S1.  It's Pandemic in hyper-expansion mode -- January was a unique experience, February was a unique experience, but they built upon each other so well...

As much as I'm enjoying the experience, I hope the Legacy fad remains that.  I don't want every game I experience to be a 12-night adventure, never to be played with virgin eyes again.  I want most games to provide me with all the experience I'll ever need in the base, with occasional expansions to add variety once the main game has been well-loved.  Because that why this Legacy game works -- not because of the 'cool mechanics' but because it rips open the long-term nostalgia for the original game.

RATING: 9
This game really improves Pandemic for me. Since you're playing many games in succession, losing one doesn't seem like such a failure, especially since the game sets you up for failure and multiple points. The changing nature of the board requires you to change your focus, so the game is never quite the same with each subsequent play. If you can get a group of people together to commit to this, I recommend it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Much has been already said about Pandemic Legacy, so I'm going to be concise (and spoiler free). I like Pandemic and wanting to try the legacy experience, this was an instabuy for me. It took me little to no time to find players with enough interest to endure all the campaign, but our weekly meetings had to get cancelled sometimes, and we didn't finish until March.

The legacy experience creates a thematic environment that suits Pandemic like a glove. It was sorely needed. Now, for example, you will think twice (or thrice) before risking an outbreak, even if the chances for it to happen are low. My usual Pandemic game length doubled while we pondered all these decisions. Everything became much more intense, every success and every failure.

As for the story, I found it compelling enough, but I have to say that sometimes it's not immersive enough and you can see the actual reason for something is not a story need, but a game mechanism. My main issue though, is the final scoring system. I don't think it's totally fair, it detracts from the immersive experience and leaves you with a slight "bad aftermath feeling".

I have played 17 games and I'm not one of these rare few that will repeat the campaign, but I enjoyed every one of them very much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Better than I expected; provides some of the smack of a tabletop RPG.

RATING: 2
Updated 10/21. 
When all is said and done it's still just Pandemic and still the most overrated game on BGG. God there are so many hundreds of better games out there. Make that thousands. I rated the original Pandemic a 5. This gets a 2 for being a throwaway version of Pandemic. Sure, there are all sorts of little gimmicks included but that's all they really are, still Pandemic. And yes, you can play the game again but only in the state that it finished in your first game. So really no replay-ability to this and I think the game could have been produced in such a way as to make it replayable instead of having you destroy or permanently change the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I wanted to wait rating this, but I seriously can't imagine the rating to get any worse (currently played successfully until the end of May). 

I am already a huge fan of the orignial Pandemic and it's one of my favorite games even without the Legacy part, which is btw also not gonna change after having played this one, because Pandemic simply is the classic boardgame you can play over and over again and I like this as well. 

But this one is simply a very exciting, interesting and superfun experience. Yes the game is "over" after a certain number of plays and your copy might not be played anymore, but the experience on the way totally makes up for that. There is the constat tension in the games , because every outbreak, every wrong and every good decision you make matters and at least to me the fact that you only ever gonna have "one shot" at it and it's not "just" a campaign, simply makes this a very unique and interesting experience that at least to me is worth the money I spend on it. 

I know some people might feel different about it and I can understand that, but I personally loved and still love the experience and while it's not something I now want to see for every game out there, I'm totally up for a legacy game experience once in a while.

RATING: 9.5
No spoilers. 
Secret Santa gave me this game for Christmas 2017. Thank you, Santa!:)
We don't really like coop games, and don't like vanilla Pandemic, but decided to give it a go and finished it yesterday (14 games all in all). 
We enjoyed it a lot! Most importantly, my wife asked to play it almost every day, which is not something that happens often. 
Is it perfect? No, there are too many tiny rules that you need to remember and it's quite hard if you miss a few days between the plays, as the rules snowball. We had to consult the manual multiple times throughout the campaign and still managed to screw up a few things here and there. The storyline also sort of loses its momentum towards the end, in my opinion and overall is merely ok, nothing spectacular, reminiscent of a Syfy produced movie. My wife did not appreciate the fact that you need to replay the same game if you lose (we lost twice), saying that a few more changes apart from adding 2 bonus cards would be more interesting. 
Having said that, I really recommend this... experience. There is something cool about the way the game unfolds in front of your eyes and you get a bit invested emotionally. Winning feels good. Losing makes you want to try harder next time. There are quite a few interesting decisions that you need to make, before, during and after a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Part way through this and loving it.  Regular Pandemic is a solid game.  For me, this Legacy version just ramps up the experience.  In all honesty, with these legacy games I'm never quite sure wether it's the game itself I'm enjoying or the expectation/surprise factor of the reveals but whatever the case, I'm really enjoying this.  If you like vanilla Pandemic you have to try this out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]Pandemic Legacy: Season 1[/b] [i]
I gave this to my daughter to play with.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (4):[/COLOR]

[i]A year later and the shine completely wore off of Pandemic Legacy. It happened not too long after jotting down my original thoughts on the game. Two things happened that soured me on the experience. 

The first I seem to be at complete odds with most gamers because I thought the story took a nose dive once freaking zombies were introduced. Really?! Let's take one of the most overused themes in gaming, and pop culture, and make that the story twist. Then, wait for it, there is a traitor in your midst. Yup, didn't see that one coming a mile away. I'm honestly shocked that such a rote, predictable and uninspired story line was meet with such glowing praise. This is the game touted as a masterpiece of story telling in game design, no thanks!

Second, keeping track of the ever changing rule set (yes I understand it's a legacy game) became more of a nuisance than something to look forward to because I didn't find many of the rules changes to be that fun or exciting. Granted, I've come to realize legacy game aren't for me so this second gripe has more to do with my discovering that than any fault of the game. However; I still can't get over how bad the story was![/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating, after playing through March, (8):[/COLOR] 

[i]So far we are loving Pandemic Legacy and this is coming from a family that doesn't really care for Pandemic, or most co-ops for that matter (Robinson Crusoe and the 2 Forbidden games being the others). I think a co-op game really shines using the legacy model, I am enjoying it much more than Risk Legacy. The best part of the game are the roles we are developing for all the different characters and how they interact with one another; it's really the story makes this game.

As of now I'd rate it a 10 and it would be my game of the month, but I am reserving judgement until we play through the whole game we are 3 for 5 and about to play through April).

Update 3/22/16

My thoughts and my interim rating have dropped quite a bit. The story and legacy aspect everyone raves about is so obvious and overdone that I've lost most of my desire to even finish the campaign.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Odd one to rate as really enjoyed playing it through, but probably wouldn't be overly interested in playing it again.

RATING: 8.5
While I am not usually impressed by pure cooperative games, in this game the authors managed to balance it real well, so that the tension increases, and the finale is always emotional. Legacy introduces a whole new dimension to the game, with choices and events in a session having big consequences in the following  ones... Also the character evolution is well designed.

The campaign arc is very interesting with some plot twists, and it is a pity that the ending disappoints. In fact all your effort does not have an impact in the end-game...

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Cult of the New! Pandemic is a great game and one I consider to be one of the best. I rate it a 10. I believe what this Legacy system promised fell short for me. PL essentially is Pandemic with what feels like some expansion content added in from month to month of game play. My wife and I played the campaign through in 3 days and completed it in 17 games. 

At first we were very very torn as to whether we would go full legacy style or not. We decided to go the replaceable sticker route and to be truly honest after just 2 or 3 games in to the campaign we were absolutely glad we did!!! I for one would have been pissed off if I had gone the legacy route. I am very happy to be able to pull this game out again for us and begin again with another virus being the deadly one and watching a fresh new game develop in different ways. 

For me, I feel like what I expected from this game was not what I got. There were no huge surprises, everything was fairly predictable. What I mean by that is, I expected multiple routes to victory type game play. I expected if you opened one of the boxes or ripped open one of the cardboard flaps, there would be something breathtaking that would change the game dramatically. But every surprise was nothing more than the feeling I get when I add an expansion to an otherwise great game. A sort of...ok...that's cool feeling. I also, did not like when a certain card would be revealed and it would list about 5 or more flaps to open...all at once. I kept thinking, did we really earn opening that much new content for the next step of the campaign? The whole cardboard flap system really wasn't a very smoothly organized system to begin with anyway. A lot of times you open one up only to find a definition of what you just discovered from a previous flap. 

My feeling is there are a lot of new gamers out there that had not tried Pandemic before and experienced Pandemic through PL for the first time and are in awe of what really is the base game Pandemic. For the rest of us that know Pandemic really well, this game feels exactly the same with several expansions slowly added through campaign play.

I think Viticulture and the Tuscany expansion did it best. They could have gone with calling it Viticulture Legacy, but I think they did it right when they decided to have Tuscany add new game elements through an expansion adding system. One where each game you win, the winner chooses the next game expansion to add to the next game of Viticulture. This, for us, created the same kind of intensity and excitement that I had from PL. And I have a gorgeous deluxe edition box with metal coins and many expansions that include wooden meeples of varying sorts...a real joy to bring to the table every time. PL could have achieved the same thing with a chit system instead of a sticker system (wooden or cardboard). Bottom line...this game at it's core is a game that is replayable. One that you shouldn't have to purchase more than once unless you want to give it as a gift because it's just that good.

Update:
After resetting the game and packing it away. We have returned to PL for a new campaign. I think playing it again after only 5 months have passed didn't work well and it is affecting some of my choices. I remember too much of what will happen. If I waited over 1 year I believe I would have forgotten most of the surprises. We played a 2 player campaign the first time. This time we are playing a 4player campaign. I would like to clarify, the difficulty is the same I think. Some people commented that the game was much harder to win with more people playing...I disagree. But if you are playing with 4 different and inexperienced Pandemic players...then yes the game is way more difficult to win. 

My opinion is unchanged. I still believe this is an example of "Cult of the New."
We were excited to get it back out and play again, however it feels a lot like a "1 and done" game. The sad thing is pulling this game out and playing it fresh again didn't allow the game to develop in a fresh new way. The game is scripted to take you in one direction...the same direction it did before.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Let me add another selective bias rating I guess, where people who like Pandemic will play and like it, and those who don't play won't rate it. I'm in the former camp. It gets the same rating and same comment from me as for the base game, as it really is much the same experience, only you take a bit more time and care with the decisions because there are ongoing ramifications that carry into future games (eg if you let a city suffer an outbreak, or you eradicate a colour). Which makes for more interesting and longer discussions throughout (and after) the game, and that's a positive over the base game. It's the same collective race against time kind of thing though, doing the best you can with the cards you're dealt. But there are some nice strategic and tactical decisions along the way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Legacy; can practice before you play using this version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Thematically, it captures everything about Pandemic that made it fun to play, and added an overarching story that made you really think about every decision. We found that not only were we planning on what to do about surviving the current month, we wanted to make future months easier as well and made sure we did a bit extra on the last turns to increase our chances of winning later. 

We tried predicting the Legacy deck, but there were definitely some twists that entirely caught us off guard. There were definitely some epic victories where we won on literally the last possible player turn and move, as well as losses were we had a 50% chance to draw the ONE card we needed and failed. There are definitely multiple strategies to complete each month, and roles we thought were useless at the beginning (*cough* Generalist) became mainstays near the end of the game once we gave her enough upgrades.

All in all, our first legacy-style game was an amazing experience and with Season 2 coming in August, we'll definitely be getting that just to see how they'll modify and dare I say, improve upon their success.

[b]Rating History[/b]
• Original Rating: 10 on Nov 18, 2015 after 6 plays (through June)
• Downgraded to a 7 after playing all the way through (15 plays). This game actually turned Kristy off of Pandemic. She started to resent playing through the final months. It was all of the extra rules that did it to her. The story was neat at the beginning and really drove us forward but eventually, it just got to be too much. I enjoyed it but I don't have any desire to play through it again. I am mildly curious about Season 2 but I'll need to find a different group to play through it which will prove difficult.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game can't really be described. I went in knowing absolutely nothing about the game, and I was floored. I did not expect it to be THIS GOOD. My fiance and I played up to April and lost. Even just playing that short amount of time, this is the singular best gaming experience I have ever had. It is absolutely the best game I have ever played. I will update after we have finished, but I don't expect it to go lower than a 10. We have a second set we will be playing with 4 people, and I will update my feelings after that play is finished as well.

UPDATE: We are now on October and the game continues to surprise me. The only one thing I would say negatively is that there are many opportunities to mess up the rules because there's just a lot to take in. I would caution new players to really read the rules and have to rulebook open during your plays. I looked up many rules questions on my phone and well and we still messed up a fair few rules. I would suggest looking up a spoiler free message board post detailing common rules mistakes, and you can look at rules mistakes for each month as you play without spoiling anything for yourself.

UPDATE: We have finished the game. We did an okay job, pretty proud for our first playthrough. We did mess up a fair few rules but it seems like a lot of people did on their first run through. We are going to play it again with 4 people this time and I feel pretty confident that we have mastered the rules so we will have an even better experience next time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Having enjoyed Pandemic, I initially thought this was the best game I'd ever played.  The first half of the game was amazing, far exceeding my expectations for my first legacy game.  But the excitement of the changes to game play and novelty of opening boxes wore off about 1/2 way through the season and the second half felt like a chore to complete.  The story was good and the ending was satisfying, but it left me wanting vanilla Pandemic  more than ever.  My biggest issue was the rule changes - it was too hard to keep up with constant changes and there was always some rule I'd forget.  This normally would be forgivable, but in a legacy game it impacts everything that comes after, which is frustrating and I always wonder how things would have turned out if we had remembered to XX in this game, or hadn't forgotten to do YY in that other game.  I have little desire to play Pandemic Legacy: Season 2 unless it can introduce something truly novel and innovative.  I did keep one thing from PL to use as a mini-expansion for my base game, because I have the old version that's not compatible with expansions.  While I do feel this was the best board game experience I've had in my entire life in the ways it bonded us as a group and brought us together as friends sharing this experience together, I'll take vanilla Pandemic over legacy any day.

RATING: 5
Enjoying it so far but - I think the rulebook is a little weak. There are loads of exceptions and small rules that are on side cards, sticker sets etc. It would have been great to have better player aids than just the old Pandemic ones. I know they are trying to avoid spoilers but how are we supposed to remember to add scars, make cities unstable etc. etc? Also some of the character abilities need a little more description. 

I strongly recommend that you play a few runs of Vanilla Pandemic first so that the rules are fresh for all players. You will need your mental energy elsewhere! I also recommend that you play it through fairly rapidly. If you come back after a break it can be a little difficult to remember what the hell is going on.

We are at June now and I am losing interest a bit. It is still great but not as mind-blowing as I had hoped. Hopefully that will change when we open the next boxes!!

Yeah - June wasn't amazing. The rules become very complicated too - trying to remember how to handle everything, add stickers etc.

Was getting very sick of this game to be honest but October was pretty good and into November looks like fireworks for the ending!!!!!!!!!!!

Ok just glad to be finished now. Phew. Ok but not worth 22 games and not up to the hype to be honest.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pandemic Legacy is a new take on campaign-style games. The game is based on the cooperative game Pandemic, and during each play, players basically play version of that game that may have slightly altered rules or objectives.  As the campaign proceeds, players can enhance their character roles, save certain buildings built on the board for future games, or give cards permanent special abilities.  However, negative things that happen can persist too--outbreaks that happen in cities permanently increase its panic level affecting travel and building in that city, and character roles can take "scars", or negative effects, when bad things happen to them.  The plays are linked together through a narrative arc that's really fun to discover as the campaign proceeds.  This game really did a good job of melding what happened in previous games with the pre-written story to create an interesting game that players feel very invested in.  My main complaint is that the game doesn't scale as well as it ought to--lower player counts will certainly find this to be an easier experience.

(Played in its entirety)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A friend of ours started this game earlier in the year. After my husband talked to a few local friends, we gathered enough interest to buy the game. We are now half way through the "year" of the game and oh man is this game ever good. The changing, the uncertainty and the new characters really make it. I think I prefer this version over pandemic itself. This is a great co-operative game. And the fact we are somehow still doing well is amazing. I look forward to this game every week when we get together to play the next "month's" objective. 
I think we will get season 2 when it comes around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A second copy to play with the missus. Can't wait to finally finish this fucking game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I am an avid Pandemic fan, as I consider it probably the "best", for my tastes, cooperative game in the market, due to its puzzle-like nature. Pandemic Legacy adds a whole new experience, by unveiling surprises along the way. Clearly, from the perspective of just playing the game, it's excellent.

Nevertheless, I reckon that most ratings on BGG are from the point of view "[i]I am not the person who paid for it[/i]", even if many users actually had paid fully or partially for it. For me, when I rate a game, I have to take into account other factors apart from gameplay. Yes, it's so exciting to wait for new surprises and be ready to face the new challenges and the consequences of your actions. However:

(a) The game is not replayable; play it 12-24 times, then throw it away. You can theoretically "reset" it, but it won't be the same.
(b) It's too expensive for what it offers. As of 2016-04-20, it sells for EUR 85.- on amazon.de, while other games offering awesome experience like Mage Knight or Through the Ages are cheaper, even half the price.
(c) This is just a small nuisance for me, but you have to have a solid gaming group, determined to play it. Everyone that starts the game has to stick to the end, as you cannot just bring in new people mid-way during your campaign. I would be extremely put off and annoyed if I had payed 85€ and then have it on the shelve unplayed or, worse, with only one play and an unmotivated group. I can understand that this is just my problem, as I am traveling a lot due to the nature of my work.

All in all, if I was not the person paying for the game, I would had rated it much higher. I would also be unfair if I had rated the game lower, as a great effort has been put into it. Consequently, taking into account all the aforementioned factors, I reckon that Pandemic Legacy is an overhyped game, but with good reason.

RATING: 9.5
Only played one month so far.  Overall it's the same as the base Pandemic game that I love. I like some of the additions and we'll see how the campaign continues.

Overall I generally have issue with campaign games since I generally won't be playing with the same people.  If you can pull that off, great.

RATING: 6
Permanent detrimental changes to the game can (and too often do) occur through bad luck, with no chance for the players to mitigate the risks. These changes can detract from the fun, and are oftentimes frustrating. These elements are usually not a problem in shorter games, but bad luck in the earlier sessions of Pandemic Legacy left a bad taste for future sessions.

The theme is generally good, but the narrative element is not as strong as other reviews had led me to believe.

I enjoyed some of the mechanics added to this game from Pandemic, but ultimately, I would prefer to play regular Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is the best and most unique board game experience me and my group of 4 ever experienced. Full of surprises, just enough difficulties and always a ton of excitement to play games after games.

Until the end of March an improved version of Pandemic, but with beginning of April the game is a huge gaming highlight. Great story, interesting, challenging.... worth of money 100%. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Playing through the 12 months of this game was quite an experience. I've always thought vanilla Pandemic to be a good game but not a great one, but it definitely merited and benefited from the Legacy treatment. We played with the same group and with relatively few switches of character. This meant it became virtually an RPG, as we strongly identified with our characters - so much so that I felt obliged to contact Matt Leacock and ask that they preserve at least the option of carrying characters forward in Season 2. Our group did pretty well in the game - only 'failing' our first attempt in two of the 12 months. We also pimped the game by using carefully chosen Lego figures to represent each of the characters.

The elephant in the room is of course the literally destructive aspect of the game. I still cringe at the thought of writing indelibly on the board and shudder at seeing players tear up cards - and we weren't even playing with either of my copies (both of which are still securely in their shrink-wrap).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've only played the first month. I'll update the rating later. So far, I like this about equal with regular pandemic but I'm excited to see what is to come as we move forward with the game. 

Our first game was tense enough that we were going to win on the first move of the next turn, only to lose it with the infection card we had to resolve first. 

Edited to add: Having played through April, I'm bumping up the rating. Hubby even wanted to play twice in a row to see what the next month would hold... this has been a really fun experience.

RATING: 9.5
17th Jul 2017
Not even half way through but the game has a lot of pleasant surprises. There is a nice narrative to the game which in my opinion brings a game like Pandemic from "dull" to "great". The addition of rules is slowly eased into the game and as a result raises the complexity level of the game to the right notch for me. This is such a unique game and it is worthy of the hype but definitely a one-play only game. I have no interest in replaying another copy once this current campaign has finished as the surprise element will be gone.

7th August 2017
It's now the end of October in Pandemic and I wanna cry. This game certainly does ramp up the difficulty as you progress and it is a welcome addition. Luck still has a lot to play but the underlying narrative in this game is always a breath of fresh air as it throws surprises my way. I feel sorry for my teammate who had two characters die under her watch. Hopefully she got some sleep after the traumatic episode.

1st September 2017
We finished. Well played Rob Daviau. We lost. Just one pathetic card draw away from winning. Great narrative and one of the most challenging co-ops I have played. Not too hard and not easy. Season 2 here I come!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First Thoughts: Only played the first month (twice :s), but this was really, really fun. If course this game can only be something for you if you have a group of players whom you will meet on regular basis and who know Pandemic well enough. But if you have such a group, don't hesitate and just play Pandemic Legacy!

Edit 10/01/2016: Final thoughts after completing our journey. A game were you had to destroy components and that you could play only X times. That seemed odd for a 'classic' boardgamer like me. 
Then again I liked Pandemic a lot and I was glad that I could find 2 companions with Wouter and Wim who wanted to make the commitment of playing until the end with me, as that convinced me to get a copy (and even a second English one as the Dutch seemed to have translation errors :s). And I'm very glad I did it as we had a lot of fun exploring this game. You also can't create so much fun without permanently changing your board or destroying things, as it is that that makes it a very dynamic game and makes it stays interesting until the very end. 
So it was 100% worth it's money and I would still recommend it to all who have a group of Pandemic-fans, as for sure you want to play this with the same people the entire trip.

Everyone I know who has played it has messed up at least one rule.  2. Finite lifetime.  Definitely worth the money, but eventually the game will be over.

RATING: 9
This is the first legacy game I've ever played.  Let it be said that you will certainly miss something in the rules and/or will make the game more or less difficult because of it.  But with that being said, it was without a doubt, one of the most entertaining and most satisfying experiences in my gaming history.  I was adamant about destroying cards and placing stickers but once you put value into perspective it no longer becomes an issue.  We played 14 games in order to finish the overall story which is more than what I can say for a number of other games I currently have on the shelf.  A fantastic ride!

RATING: 9
KenSdJ-N
+Co-op, Legacy mechanic permanently alters game as you play through the campaign.
=Season is a single play through, but will take an average of 18 sessions to complete
-While you can add/subtract players, they will miss out on story/progression. Once you finish the campaign, the game can not be reset.

Update, played through May: We're riding a 5 game win streak, but May stopped us thinking it was too easy. Complaints about the legacy system, not being infinitely replayable, have completely misjudged the concept behind the game.

RATING: 2
Do I really think this game is a lowly 2 rating?  Not exactly - the game itself plays fine, it's perfectly good.  So why the crap rating?  Because I know the novelty of this is going to wear off.  Not only that, but this is a board game that costs a significant amount of money (for a board game), and yet which can only be played through one time, since you are permanently altering the game board and physically destroying components.

At the end of the day, this was just Pandemic mixed with a campaign mode.

RATING: 9

RATING: 9
interesting addition of plot to pandemic. maybe it was just our group but i had a really good experience with this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very well-done campaign version of Pandemic. Pandemic is one of my favorite games, and I still like the core gameplay here. I like how the campaign gives you tradeoffs between meeting your short-term objective and working on some long-term goal. There were several times when something genuinely new and surprising happened, which was fun and makes the campaign memorable. I did occasionally get annoyed at the surprise elements, since one of the things I like about Pandemic is working through the puzzle and finding an optimum path to victory, but you can't do that if new rules appear halfway through a game session. Overall I really enjoyed it and am glad to have played it. The narrative aspect was better than base Pandemic, but the tight gameplay suffers a bit in comparison to base Pandemic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Need to get a group together to play this.

RATING: 10
5 plays in and we're in April. The game has lots to keep itself fresh but more importantly after each game we've been talking and texting about what could have been done better or how we could have changed things. 

I had high expectations going in to this game and thus far it has not disappointed. The only real mark against it is that you should try to play with the same group the whole way.

*****
After completing the campaign I can say that this game has an amazing narrative arc that you just don't find in most board games and every choice has meaning. This was amazingly fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I LOVE Pandemic. I thought I'd at least really enjoy Pandemic Legacy. Part of the problem may be that we have too many versions of Pandemic, and there wasn't enough fresh material for me. I also wasn't a fan of the theme and story choices Legacy went with. It was intriguing to see how our gameplay changed when our choices became permanent, and the game did generate a fair amount of next-day discussion, but I feel like I can easily come up with one con for every pro (e.g. the sheer amount of garbage we produced while playing). In the end, I wish that I'd gotten two more Pandemic expansions instead, because now I'm left with a game I can't play. I think I just wanted Legacy to be more. I wanted the choices I made to radically alter the direction of my campaign (or at least have that potential), I wanted my story to be drastically different from anyone else's, I wanted to experience mechanics and scenarios I'd never imagined. But Pandemic Legacy really only had one possible story direction, and you were forced to stick to it. In the end, I enjoy playing Pandemic because winning feels like we *have* saved the world and averted catastrophe by curing disease. Pandemic Legacy didn't give me that feeling, even though it easily could have, and that's why I'm so sorely disappointed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
GAME OVER

The game had a lot going for it in the first few months. Unfortunately the game quickly lost pace and it became a chore more than an actual fun experience.

I'd recommend the game to people who absolutely love Pandemic. The added Legacy aspect changes up a few things, but the game is essentially Pandemic.

I would've preferred had the game been 4 months shorter.

EDIT: After revisiting ratings this has been dropped to 6. A rating lower than Pandemic. I liked the first third of PL better than vanilla Pandemic, but it very quickly became a chore to get through the story.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pandemic Legacy is an amazingly intense game.

At first I had reservations about the Legacy concept.  Ripping cards, writing on the board, putting stickers on the board...... I wasn't sure how I felt about that.  I also didn't like the idea I couldn't "start over" and had value concerns.

Due to these concerns, I wasn't planning on buying Pandemic Legacy but my wife liked the idea and convinced me otherwise.  I am extremely happy that she did.  

I am a big regular Pandemic fan, but this turns it up to 11 as Nigel Tufnell would say.  There is so much tension, and the feeling of surprise is astounding.  The game is unpredictable but you feel like early choices could have a big effect in later months.  

The game weaves a story - it's like watching a movie in some respects.  If you enjoyed the base game of Pandemic, I would strongly recommend this game - you will get your money's worth (I've actually bought it twice, it's so good.  One to play with friends, and one to play with family).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Have played through May

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm finally finished with this game.  Literally and figuratively.  I made a commitment and I wanted to see it through.  To be honest, I was a bit over this game around the time of the June missions.  By September I was starting to dread having to play it.

Was it a fun experience?  I enjoyed playing it with my gaming group.  I didn't particularly enjoy the game.  It was massively over hyped.  It's hard to rate this game based on the BGG ratings.  I will never play it again, and I rated it 4 because it did have enough interesting twists and turns along the way to get me through all 18 plays - but I was hating my life on the last 6 or so games.

We found it overwhelmingly difficult in some games and entirely too easy in others.  It was so swingy for us.  My group doesn't tend to like luck-heavy games and we started getting really down on the game when drawing 2 epidemics in a row (that happened several times).  By the first game in December we just said "ok, let's just play this back to back so we can get this over with."

This is my first experience with a legacy game and I'm not sure I would opt to do it again.  I like campaign based games very much.  I like the theory of things evolving between games.  I'm not sure I like it in practice.

One thing I find particularly difficult, and probably the primary reason I will never play a legacy game again, is that you are pretty much required to play with the same group every time.  If one person doesn't like the game you've pretty much just screwed up the entire experience for the entire time.  That sucks!

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [b]Components[/b]
:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: [b]Artwork[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Mechanics (general gameplay "fun")[/b]
:star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: [b]Rules (easy to learn/teach)[/b]
:nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Replay Value[/b]
:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: [b]Player Uptime[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Meaningful Decisions (luck factor)[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Total[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I am a fan of Pandemic and Pandemic Legacy really gives you a very unique experience. How you develope your characters and your infrastructure is engaging and leads to a lot of discussions between games. The story and how it represented is fine, but not outstanding.

I am amazed how this game auto-balances, but it can still get quite tricky, if you had some bad luck or made wrong decisions in your previous plays. In the third quarter of the year, the game gets a bit tedious when you try to fight against the "main-character-illness" (come on, this  is no spoiler!). 

The whole campaign format really captivated me and lead me to binch-play this game, which I have not experienced with any other game at all. Certainly one of my top games of all time and I really hope that there will be a season two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I understand why Alpha players and followers love the game. The Alphas get to run the game and the followers get to "win" on the backs of the Alphas. Why a competitive player would want to play continues to amaze me - or maybe such players do not play it.

RATING: 9
We are into June at the moment, having had a marathon gaming session on saturday 14/11.  
The concept of a legacy game, with a story arch that has permanent decisions is thrilling.  Would a legacy game be so successful if there was no original game that it came from.  I think not.  A game with a new rules system that you learn for one game, that then changes, potentially every next game, would make me wince.
I avoided Risk Legacy for the obvious reason that my wife and I are not huge risk fans.  We both like Pandemic and we both really like this.  Could i recommend this to friends, well only if they played original pandemic and enjoyed it.

17/11 We are now about to start November. Damn this game is good.  We've sworn out loud as events twist our fortunes up and down.  Current standing Won:9 Lost:3.

Finished and instantly bought another copy to play with friends. Love it.

Lowering rating to 9 as not played since

RATING: 8
(11/19/2015) - Grabbed this today off of CSI. Kier loves Pandemic, plus I have heard great things about the legacy format.

(12/27/2016) - [8] - With the completion of Season One comes my rating for the game as a whole. Overall I find myself a bit torn with Pandemic Legacy. Prior to the events of September, I would have rated it a 9.5. I was very disappointed with the twist, as I unknowingly predicted very early on what would ultimately happen. Losing the Quarantine Specialist was a huge blow. I felt like the game forced players into that eventuality, even if it gave the appearance of free choice in getting there. The months of September and October were closer to a 5 rating, and really soured me on the game. November and December did recover things, and overall I very much enjoyed playing Season One. I see myself grabbing Season Two when it arrives.

SOLD - (04/10/2017) - With Season One in the books, I'm not sure it is worth the lost shelf space to keep the completed game around for nostalgia only. I took a picture of the final board and scanned our final score and month tracking pages, in case I ever want to look back fondly on the journey.

RATING: 7.4
:) Legacy aspect induces some interesting considerations to take into account (sometimes damage control is better than a shot on winning a single game for example).

:) Over the course of the game, interesting challenges and abilities are unlocked, which makes the basic game mechanics of pandemic much more interesting

:soblue: I would have expected a deeper story to drive the game. Yes, there is a story you play out, but it will never become a bestseller :)

:soblue: Despite new abilities, challenges which add to the game play, I couldn't help but feel that the game got a little repetitive between the 4th and 10th month or so... It is a quite an inventment for me and my game group to play the same game about 17 times, and I would have hoped to get a little more variation out of it. Still the designers did a good job of adding content and finding a good balance between adding abilities and challenges in a way to keep the game pretty tense up until the end.

RATING: N/A
Absolutely, hands down, without question, the best coop game I've ever played.  Early coop games often times were kind of coop where a single player could ransom the entire group's welfare so that he could win.  That kind of poisoned coop to me for a long time.  Recently, there have been a few titles that were decent.  Damage Report was fun -- using the limited time mechanic.  Magic Maze was fun the first few plays -- using limited communication.  Time Stories... yawn.  With Pandemic Legacy, I look forward to the next play with incredible anticipation, and also with huge dread at the same time.  We haven't finished yet, but I'm already looking forward to Season 2.
