Pandemic Legacy takes the Pandemic formula and simply takes it to the next level. It makes every decision count for the entire life time of the game. The suspense that is created during some moments is simply incredible. No other game has made me appreciate a win so much and dread a loss as much as Pandemic Legacy has done. And it constantly gets fresh with new rules and mechanics as the game progresses.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Max Players 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played through the whole thing now.

It's Pandemic. What can I say? I'd rather play this than regular Pandemic but - without going into spoilers - there's just not enough in the box. It's less extra material in the box than in Risk Legacy and the story progresses linearly, which makes the game less organic then Risk Legacy - and the story presented in Pandemic Legacy is not anywhere near on the level that warrants this. The only thing that this game has going on Risk Legacy is that Pandemic is a much better game than Risk.

The idea that you replay a month if you lost it is just dumb. In the end, playing Pandemic Legacy becomes a choire, home-work. We become Tools, wanting desperately for the last reveal being something worthwile the whole agonizing 12-24 sessions, instead of just walking away and playing something fun. Much like the Candy Crush experience, I presume.

In the end, Pandemic Legacy reaches first place in the BGG because of the novelty of legacy gaming, as well as the fact that there are things that speak against the game that I cannot speak of because of the implicit rule that I must not spoil anything for the non-knowers. I do love the Legacy part but please, this game is a down-grade from Risk Legacy. When can we see a really good game get the legacy treatment?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Co-owned
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like Pandemic, and I like stickers. Playing Pandemic with stickers is a fascinating experience. It should've been longer (i.e., more than twelve "months").
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
This is basically just like playing Pandemic over and over again, while adding in permanent variants between games. 

For all the cool things that legacy adds, there are (for me) at least an equal amount of negatives. While cool on the surface, legacy locks you into playing the same game with the same group over and over. While that is fine with some, it tends to make the game exclusive instead of inclusive, and also makes each box only available for a specific number of people. This limited, throw-away, system is a gimmick that I'm sad to see more games adopting. It's going to make it harder for someone to walk into a game night for the first time and feel welcomed, and eventually hurt the overall hobby.

This game gets the same rating as regular Pandemic with a large asterisk next to it to denote that I will never buy it or any other permanent legacy games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have completed the campaign with 4 total players and I put this game in the solid "recommend" pile. There's not much new ground to break in describing what Pandemic Legacy gets right: an already-solid game gains an added evolving story with associated evolving game mechanics.

There's much good in this game, but I can't give it a perfect score because it's a little rough around the edges. The "reminder" token is hardly used (even in cases where it would be really useful to do so). Various Legacy cards have the same instructions phrased in different ways, adding confusion to no gain. The scoring system at the end of the game is bullhockey, and most of all, Team Bravo can eat a bag of zucchini.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Mostly, it's still Pandemic, which I do not enjoy.  Re-theming one of the infections as SPOILER doesn't really change the game enough.  I like looking at the stuff that was put into the various boxes, but I have little desire to actually play it.

A lot of the legacy elements are programmed, not conditionally unlocked, which makes it feel like the play experience and game history is not actually that unique (which is part of the appeal of a legacy game).  However, since it is a coop, there is more opportunity for players to make legacy choices strategically, which I like -- in contrast to Risk Legacy, where players were expected to self balance the game but the incentive structure wasn't really there.

Rating based on watching people play full games.  It does seem more social than Pandemic, since you can chat about the weird legacy stuff while someone else is taking your turn for you.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pandemic is one of our most played games of all time, so we were definitely excited about the legacy version of this game.  We played through the whole year and really enjoyed it.  The twists that they add to the game each month definitely increased the excitement and suspense compared to the original game.  The narrative aspect of the game was definitely interesting, but story was not particularly compelling.  Opening up all of the secret compartments was always exciting, but in the end it just seemed like so much stuff to deal with. We spent almost as much time opening compartments and putting stickers all over the place as we did actually playing the game.  I think there was much more stuff in the game than there needed to be.  The rules and conditions were constantly changing for no apparent reason.  Maybe it would have been better if we only played one month at a time, but we played this whole game in 4 sittings, so we ended up opening like 20-30 doors in the dossier each evening, which was just an overwhelming amount of stuff to deal with. We ended up just setting aside most of the extra stuff, because we didn't care about it.  There were too many upgrades, too many rules changes, too many random quests that were easy to complete.  

Overall, this was a fun game, but it seemed a little too contrived and complicated just for the sake of complexity.  It was an interesting experience, and we had fun for those 4 nights that we played it.  But was it worth $60?  Probably not.  We could have had just as much fun playing a game that we already had, and which we will be able to continue playing for years to come.  Some people have plenty of disposable income, and so disposable games may be fine for them.  But we do not have money just to throw around, so buying an expensive game that we are just going to rip up is just not worth it to us.

In the end, we went through and reset our entire game so that we could try to play it again.  Resetting it was actually pretty easy since we ignored most of the rules changes and upgrades that came in the dossier and we refused to rip anything up. But once that was reset was done, we decided to sell it for a deep discount, rather than play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm nearly finished with my second campaign... The first one was so much fun. I played it with a couple of my best friends, who don't play board games much, and we were totally engrossed. The fact that the events of each game will carry over to the next causes far more tension than in a typical board game, and since we took the time to name characters and the viruses, and read all the card text, it really made for an entertaining, thematic game.

In my second campaign, my teammates tend to want to rush through the game, and don't bother to create names for anything, nor read the text except for where it says something necessary for game setup. It's still fun, but I found it much more fun the way I played it the first campaign.

RATING: 10
This game is just absolutely phenomenal. This is my first experience with a Legacy-style game, and it hit for me on all cylinders. I am not yet finished the campaign, but after 12 plays or so, I am more excited to play games of Pandemic, even having played it so much already, than I have ever been to play one specific game. This game is an experience, plain an simple, and a very cool one at that. The theme and the story arch of the Legacy is something that no game can do as well as this one has WITHOUT including the Legacy mechanic. Until Plaid Hat comes out with a Legacy style game that includes Crossroads cards, Pandemic Legacy will remain my favourite game ever, completely usurping my original number 1, Game of Thrones. I can't wait to finish this, and I sincerely hope there IS a season 2 on the horizon. If you are on the fence for this one, don't be. Get it. It's fantastic.

Si Solitario
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun variation on Pandemic. The components were fantastic and the game was interesting. Rating this is hard. The gameplay merits a 7.5 (adding a half point for the components). The Legacy component balances itself out - the options add a point; but the one-time nature of the game drops it a point. 

A fan of Pandemic will love it. Casual fans I could see going either way - some will enjoy it more due to the game changing uniquely where others will shy away from "Pandemic Overload". 

Personally, I am not a fan of the Legacy System; but I do not believe this is simply a money grab. My regular gaming group are big fans of Pandemic - so I invested into the experience and felt I got my money's worth. I expect my interest on any further Legacy products will wax and wane depending on the property it is based on (and likely will be ignored if I am unfamiliar with it). That said, I will probably invest in Pandemic Season 2 when it is released.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A friend bought a copy, and we played the full thing, averaging a game an hour.  There's a decent campaign involved and some fun decisions, but we found some of the stickers could come loose and it was easy to forget a rule or two (sometimes in our favor, sometimes not).  Analysis Paralysis and Alpha Player problems aren't mitigated by the game, but a lot of that is a problem with the group and not the game anyway.  Also, not all characters are equally useful (some feel over powered and others are very situational), which can be an issue as the game progresses.  

Definitely a game to play all the way through, enjoy, and then go do something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pandemic Legacy does a lot of things well. The legacy mechanic is a really great way to invest the players into the game experience. There's something exhilarating about marking up the game with things that are unique to your group. There are goofy names to the diseases, departed characters, and memorable gameplay moments all through there. 

But for all of that I am left wanting more. First of all, this is a LOT of sessions of a game I didn't like that much to begin with, although this is a very good version of Pandemic. The overall narrative is also a disappointment. While individual choices make a huge impact within the session, they have almost zero impact on the narrative, which plays out the same no matter what. It might be asking too much for a branching narrative of some kind, but the player did not have a role in crafting the narrative, and that's a shame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I consider vanilla Pandemic a euro, an ok cube pusher (about a 7--my wife rates it an 8), but PL to be a fantastic thematic game that sucks you right in (and spits you out at times). My medic, Jamal Dube, is attempting to save the world with his cranky virologist partner Parker Watson (my wife's scientist character). It's been a wild ride so far! Jamal and Parker will never be the same...

Beautiful experience. Am playing it with my wife right now, and we couldn't have asked for a more delightful reason to get back into gaming together. We REALLY want to play those games! She remarked that she was already considering buying another copy when we're done, with ideas about who she wanted to play this through with for a second time--and she's usually lukewarm about games!

so, a success all around.

RATING: 10
This game is so amazing, its like a TV made out of cardboard! The lot twists keep you on your toes and delving deeper and deeper into the story is amazing. (Not a spoiler, just a gameplay mechanic in the rulebook from day 1) my wife is a Scientist and seeing the rule where if you do well your funding gets lowered the next month because the government isn't worried about it anymore and thinks you have it under control was a hysterical "art imitating life". This game just keeps giving and giving, your choices are permanent, which also adds to the tension.

Update: Beat it on January 7th, 2018. Such a great experience! I framed our finished board and hung it on the wall of my office.

RATING: 9
PL is one of those games that has taken Casa de'Tomas by storm.
We cracked it open the day it arrived, planning to play a single game. 6 games (and 4 months...) later, we had to put it away.

Then we got sucked into a 'game' with a different group (and a different box) at our weekly board game meet-up. 4 games later, the venue was closing, so we had to stop.

Since then, both games have been opened for additional sessions... but never less than 3 games at a stretch.

we're already talking about getting another copy, finding a different group, and playing through it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pandemic Legacy is an amazing board gaming experience with a phenomenal narrative arc, though this is more due to the iterative gameplay changes than to the story itself. The story itself is weak, but the long term consequences of your actions and the organic changes to the board create a sense of continuity that does a better job of generating a sense of narrative than other games I've played with ostensibly better stories. I played it as a 2 player game with 4 characters so that we had a lot to do, and it worked wonderfully.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fabulous, incredibly immersive game.  A definite must-play-through-the-entire-campaign kind of game!

Highly Recommended for 2+ players.

RATING: 7
A great game with seriously flawed end game scoring that left our whole group deflated.  We did not do great but though we did ok with 8 outright wins, 2 wins on the second attempt, and 2 lossed months. Our map was also in decent shape, though we did have a small cluster of fallen cities.  Had we scored just on that, we would have done okay.  But we got dinged because we did poorly in December and did not meet the objectives, got dinged for not completing an optional objective earlier in the game (other objectives were easier for us), and we got dinged big  for missing one optional objective that was part of a multi objective achievement (getting no credit for the parts we did accomplish).  We would have done better had we purposefully lost each month so that we could have more time to complete each objective.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1

I would give it a five like the original pandemic but a $70 disposable game makes it a solid one.  Plus what gives with the rankings.  Its been on the market for six months and its rated higher than all but three games.  A redone disposable game at that. Hmmm

I've been questioned from a few people about me rating Pandemic Legacy I honestly just don't understand the justification of the game being number one.  I am part of a big gaming community here in SE Michigan and granted it's not THE gaming mecca but its huge.  Gaming is my number one hobby and I enjoy it immensely.  I've played against thousands of different people throughout the years. What I am trying to say is that I think I can give an honest opinion about a game.  
Now about Pandemic Legacy: I've seen it played once and it looked OK.  I asked what the players thought of it and they basically said that it was OK and the game was over-hyped.  All three stores have it in stock and there were Christmas specials for the game,  Up until now I used the BGG ranking system to try games out that I normally wouldn't try out normally.  With the exception of Pandemic Legacy and the Star Wars/Descent game (I didn't care for Descent), I have the other eighteen games, with Netrunner probably being my favorite game. I haven't tried all eighteen yet but its close.  Anyways, the biggest factor of what makes an elite game in my honest opinion is the "fun factor", but since what's fun to me might not be fun to other people it can't be measured accurately.  So I measure games in other more objective ways.  Every game with the exception of Caverna was a completely innovative ideal that sometimes even spawned a new type of game.  Games like Twilight Struggles,which jump started the 21st century war-game, Terra Mystica, Agricola, Through the Ages, Castles of Burgundy ect bring much more to the table than Pandemic Legacy or Pandemic for that matter.  Another factor is what other people want to play.  I've been asked to play Warhammer 40k, Advanced Squad Leader, Panzer Grenadier, Combat Commander, Bolt Action, Magic, Splendor, Five Tribes, Dominion, Marvel Legendary, DC deck builder, Terra Mystica, Caverna, Castles of Burgandy, Castles of Mad King Ludwick,  that fast food Magnate game and countless others over the past month by many different people.  Not one person had Pandemic Legacy nor wanted to play it.  That just doesn't seem right in my opinion.  This game that is just an "improvement" over a game that is seldom played shouldn't even be close to number one let alone number one.  It makes me question the integrity of the BGG rankings and from now on I'm not going to use it to help me decide what to purchase.  Thank you for letting me rant.  I know its a little long but sometimes I enjoy writing.

Its been about six months, still haven't met anyone whose played it.  I cannot give an honest opinion other than the game is so good it never hits the table.  The local store that I frequent has several red and blue boxes for 20% off. Some number one game. 

Well when I write this it is April 15th 2017 and I still haven't seen the game played nor know anyone who played it.  The game sits on the shelf at the store I frequent (both red and blue) I've seen TIME stories played at game stores occasionally and from what I read that is also a legacy game. I've also seen risk legacy and many RPG games played at stores.  Again I just cannot understand how a game that is ranked the best never played.      

Its September 2017 and still haven't seen it played (exception briefly when it rolled out two years ago). I still don't know anyone who has played it.  I just don't understand how it can be the number one game and nobody plays it.  This is an exception of people should only rank games that are played as this is the only game I have ranked and not played.

RATING: N/A
Incredible variant of the classic co-operative game. Play through one year in trying to save the world. The legacy aspect means that the game changes for each play, and the final game is not the same as the first game. Legacy also means that it has a finite life as a game.

RATING: 9.25
[no spoilers] A truly engaging experience. Takes the solid design of pandemic to a new level with the legacy elements. Decisions are that much more tense and significant. Story is good and brings some interesting atmosphere to these decisions. However, the modification of core mechanisms resulting from the story and player decisions is where the game truly shines! Difficulty was weighted to the easy side, but even so we had some very exciting games that came down to the wire. Would be a 10 if we could continue to play it endlessly.

Only minor negative is that the stickers kept peeling. Would be nice if Z-Man went with a slightly better adhesive in the next release.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
[2016-01-08]
Három hónapot látva engem még nem nyűgözött le a Pandemic Legacy. Amennyivel kicsit érdekesebb, mint a sima Pandemic annyit nem ér, hogy a végén nem használható többet a játék. A másik dolog viszont pont ez, hogy egy pár órás munkával simán megoldható, hogy ne kelljen a játékot tönkretenni és újrajátszható legyen, nem csökkentve az élvezeti értékét. Simán újrajátszhatónak érzem a játékot az eddig történtek alapján.

[2016-01-22]
5 hónap befejezve. Továbbra is tartom a korábbiakat. Viszont egyre jobbnak érzem az újrajátszhatóságot. A sok új elem miatt abszolút sokutas a játék, így magának a megóvásnak is lenne értelme.

[2016-02-11]
Na a végére értünk 19 parti után. Nos nekem nem ütött a játék. Volt pár újdonság benne, de számomra már hosszú volt és unalmas. Kicsit több varianciát és új elemet vártam. A szerencse szerepe nagy, a játék nem enged különböző stratégiákat, vezet egy úton, amiről nem enged letérni. Igazából a sok karakterrel lehet variálni csak. Igazából talán csak a december más, mint a többi hónap. A pontozás is nagy részben a decemberi teljesítéstől függ. Úgy gondolom a sima Pandemic az On the Brink kiegészítővel sokkal többet ad és bármikor elővehető.

RATING: 5
This one seemed like a no-brainer for me. Pandemic is my favorite game so how about a Legacy-style campaign version? It's definitely Pandemic and early on, I was in love. However, as things progress, it becomes a chore of seemingly never-ending stickering and learning more and more rules exceptions, to the point where I am completely removed from the story being told. And while I appreciate the need to continue the story, having to replay months that you've lost is just terrible. I would prefer to just move on to the next month instead of going through the same situation again without any of the tension or excitement. While I think this is still a decent game, it is one of my biggest disappointments ever. I'm out for Season Two.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
As soon as we got the original Pandemic and played it once, I knew I had to get this - and wasn't disappointed! It is stressful, gripping, infuriating, fun, and torturous all at once! Knowing the decisions made from the first game effect the rest, and watching the story unfold were two really cool aspects - we played as a group of 3 with an occasionally 4th player dropping in and out over the course of about 3 and a half months, and somewhat took control of our gaming lives for that period - I didn't want to play anything else! The game evolves with new elements organically, and while we had to look some things up on the BGG faq (which is brilliant, kudos to the writers!) and we got a few rules wrong in places, it didn't stop us having probably the most fun and stressful board gaming we have experienced! 

My only complaint is that I hate the wait for Season 2 now!

RATING: 10
I trust there will be many more seasons. Great concept, great execution. This game is the epitome of greatness for this hobby: it creates a compelling narrative, beginning with having the players name the characters, establish relationships early in the year, and with the mounting tension and unexpected events as the months go by. The story sticks with you from play to play, and I fully expect to revisit this board and these people even after the Season is completed.

Subdomain_Strategy Games; Thematic Games

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have lost sleep over this game while playing it....fretting about past and future decisions. I've never lost sleep over a game, ever! This is by far the best game I've ever played, because I got this invested in it. We have quite the experienced game group and although I wouldn't call us jaded, it's hard to surprise us and for us to get worked up by new games. We were highfiving each other after wins and really feeling dejected after losses. We were already fans of Pandemic the base game, especially with some of the expansions and scenario's. Maybe between 30-40 games under our belt. And Legacy blew us away. Things to consider to enjoy Legacy even more:
- get familiar with the base game. At least around 10 games. Even play some games in the digital version (iOS has a great app) to "train" a bit. This will ease your entry into Legacy and enhance your enjoyment
- play the whole Legacy game as much as you can with the same people. It's possible to drop in/out later but it won't be as good for either parties
- read the rules and discuss them among the players before every Legacy session. The rules get complex (although the pacing in learning them is brilliant) and misinterpreting them or missing them altogether will be a detriment to your enjoyment. The game gets too easy or too hard quickly when you miss/misinterpret rules
- Don't ignore new stuff that gets introduced from time to time. Chances are, you will need it, maybe not at that particular moment but for sure in later months. We sometimes got stuck on neutral and tried to follow the same strategy multiple times. We had some success with that but we mostly had to adjust later on and had to play catch-up. 
- Check the brilliant FAQ thread here on the Geek to see if you played correctly and interpreted/used things the right way. 
- Avoid all spoilers at any cost, seriously!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Absolutely wonderful experience! This game combines one of the best cooperative games with a linear thriller storyline and does it amazingly well. Highly recommended and can be played with less experienced gamers as well. Also I've set the game as 'Previously Owned' simply because we've played the game through - thus I don't really own the game any longer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Quizás el mejor juego q he jugado en mi vida. Recomendable 4 personas. Giros inesperados y acción y debates durante semanas. Vale la pena la inversión. Quizás en algunos momentos falta un poco de narrativa.

RATING: 10
My rating was made previous to all the ratings drama that started in December 2015, and is based on a full playthrough of the campaign.

Pandemic Legacy takes a favorite game of mine, and adds an excellent narrative-based campaign on top of it.  The campaign kept me hooked through all twelve months, in many ways like a good TV show does.  It managed to add interesting mechanical and plot twists to the game without bogging down the game in complexity.  

Do I care that at the end of it all I'm left with a game with no replay value?  Not anymore than I care that at the end of a movie in theaters I'm left with a ticket stub or at the end of a meal at a restaurant I'm left with an empty plate.  It's one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had, and well worth the $50 I paid for it.  

Since Rob said he does appreciate more feedback about the game, I will say that while the Legacy deck did provide excellent pacing to the game, I did miss all the packets from Risk Legacy with goals on them.

RATING: 9
Actually pretty high praise for me, as I'm not a huge cooperative fan (although I do enjoy playing them from time to time). Pandemic itself is just OK, and I find that introducing it to new players, they often get the exercise that the other players are dictating their moves. Still, the storyline here is awesome, and it's extremely engaging to have your past games affect the ones you're about to play, while at the same time revealing new rules and complexity over time. Love that the roles have morphed into characters so that you build a bit of a relationship with them, and it's awesome how your game-end bonuses are tough choices for how well you want to set up the next game.

UPDATE: Still loving the campaign and getting more engrossed every time I play. Moving up to a 9.

RATING: 7
2 plays, 4er

It's Pandemic, which I don't love (it being a co-op), but with a key [i]legacy[/i] ingredient that, so far at least, makes the game much more interesting. 

The initial game is not too different from the original:
- now start with exactly 5 epidemics (I think you chose the difficulty level previously?)
- start the game with only 4 events in deck (chosen as a group during setup)
- character cards are not associated with pawn color; players play a color, and choose any available character
- fewer characters available (I think?) -- there are 5 from which to choose at the start
- panic levels: each time a city has an Outbreak, it's panic level goes up (0 -> 5). At 2+, it's harder to get to/from the city, or build a research station. At 5, the city is destroyed!
- if a character is caught in a city when it Outbreaks, they get a scar; if city falls, they die (permanently)!

Soon, though, you start opening up packets and changing the rules -- great fun!

----
10 plays (4er): we're through June now, and the shine is wearing off a bit. The legacy stuff is really what makes this game interesting, but I expect I won't want to play it again after we make it through to the end.

----
1 game left (late December)! We've seen everything (except the lose-4-in-a-row box) and are about to finish this thing. After that, on the BGG scale my rating would probably be a 4 or 5? I would almost like to try it again, but only because I'd do it with a completely different set of characters -- we played pretty much every game with the Medic and Dispatcher! Now that I've seen the story, though, it seems this is pretty much just Pandemic. Maybe if played with a group of newbies, the discovery aspect would still be fun to watch? Regardless of my dislike of coop games, though, the legacy part of this will likely have me back for Season 2.

----
18 plays:
Jan - win
Feb - loss/win
Mar - win
Apr - loss/win
May - loss/win
Jun - loss/win
Jul - loss/win
Aug - win
Sep - win
Oct - win
Nov - win
Dec - loss/loss


*** Spoilers ***

Final score: 576? The last game ended with us running out of cards to draw. It was relatively close: we needed to vaccinate just 2 more cities. The last game was just barely about diseases ... we should have left the medic out of the mix! Again! The scoring parameters were a surprise: the last cards of the deck, revealed after playing the final game. A pleasant surprise, though: it would have been a real letdown losing the last game and having absolutely nothing to show for it! At least we saved the world, marginally well.

*** Spoilers ***

RATING: 9
2-4, 60m
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I played through an entire Risk Legacy campaign and really enjoyed the Legacy part even though I really dislike Risk.  Pandemic however is a game I'm quite fond of.  Now we put those together and it is really as incredible as getting peanut butter in my chocolate.

For those not familiar the Legacy system is just a term in board games that came about from Risk Legacy.  It is a reasonably novel idea where each game played things happen and that cause permanent changes to the game.  Inside the box are compartments that are opened at specified times.  These do things from make permanent changes to the board and characters to even destroying some components or bringing completely new stuff into the game.

When you start the game it is almost identical to standard Pandemic but before the end of the first game several changes are made to everything from the board, to how the viruses act, to even what your objective is.  And just looking at the amount of stuff still hidden tells me there's even more here than there was in Risk Legacy.  Plus it's a much, much better game.  And they still put in some pretty stellar components as well.

This is a fantastic item if the idea of making permanent markings or even tearing up pieces to one of your games doesn't give you ulcers.  There is also the typical concern that after a campaign there's very little reason to continue playing it.  I have two responses to that.  The first is, at the end, even if you don't unlock anything new, you still have a neat Pandemic variant with its own crazy rules that is pretty unique to you and your group that you can play any time you want just like you would regular Pandemic.  The second is, one campaign is between 12-24 games...and it isn't going to be 12.  Since I got into designer gaming 3-4 years ago there are less than 20 games I've played more than 12 times.  So that's quite a bit of value even if you never play it again at the end of your campaign.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
We're up to April now, and there's now almost nothing this game can do to reduce it from a 10. It would pretty much have to self-destruct seconds before the winning move next month *and* leave scorch marks on the table to get downrated by me.

I like (regular) Pandemic because it's a fun puzzle with simple rules while hitting the right amount of decision-making and luck for me. I don't super-love it compared to other games, though, if only because the app delivers all of this faster plus anytime solo play. 

Pandemic Legacy takes everything I enjoy about the base game and coats it with a few other game elements that I really love: twists that change gameplay without having to learn heaps of new rules, new components to parakeet over, and emotional investment a la RPG without being an actual RPG.

I didn't think I'd be able to destroy/alter components. Now I've joined the crowd wondering which game will get "legacied" next.

UPDATE: Finished the game and standing by the above. The hype doesn't lie.

RATING: 6
WARNING MILD SPOILERS

What starts off excellent is sadly let down by a feeling of familiarity and some egregious plot decisions. I don't want to get into any specifics for fear of spoilers, but there is a major event near the end of the game that can cripple your endgame if you forget to do one thing. It is literally possible to have a much worse result if you win the game rather than losing it in order to achieve certain objectives. This left me with a feeling of severe disappointment that honestly made playing the latter half of the game feel worthless. I wrote a thread on it if you want spoilers details. 

MILD SPOILERS OVER

Altogether, Pandemic Legacy is a bit of a mixed bag. It starts out with a lot of promise and you will have a wonderful first few games. Unfortunately, some ugly elements start to rear their heads near the mid-game, with the result that some plays during the middle of the game can feel like a slog. 

Ultimately, I'm not sad that I purchased the game. I do feel like I got my money's worth. Instead, I'm just highly disappointed in my overall feelings after playing the game. There were several times where I felt like I could quit early and be satisfied with my experience, and knowing how it ends, I wish I had done exactly that. A game should never leave you feeling like you shouldn't have wasted your time playing it. If Pandemic Legacy had kept the fun of its initial few plays it would have been a surefire 10, but certain game elements and the ending are enough to knock it down to a 6 in my book and I highly doubt I will play any future seasons in this line.

RATING: 7.5
We liked pandemic, love legacy. So had to get this.
Rated it a 10, was thinking about deducting a point for the very bad translations in the dutch version, but decided to ignore those for rating purposes. 
Thinking about it later on, I really can't rate this game a 10, since the urge to play it now (variants) since it's finished is gone. I see us playing regular pandemic more often. So it dropped down to 7.5, but regular pandemic got boosted up, pandemic legacy made us appreciate it more.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'd be hard-pressed to say whether this game or War of the Ring has provided me with the greatest experiences I've ever had in gaming.  I've been seriously into the board gaming scene since about 2003, and in my opinion, the whole "Legacy" thing is the greatest innovation I've seen in the hobby.  Although the concept failed with both Risk Legacy (you started with a terrible game and very little to do with the actual game play changed over time) and with Seafall (a project that just ended up being too ambitious), Pandemic Legacy showed just what could be achieved with a Legacy system: players became extremely invested in the game, their decisions mattered a lot, and the game itself morphed into a unique world built by the players.  I truly believe this game deserves the #1 ranking here on BGG that it holds as of 2017, and I can only hope that Season 2 captivates me and my gaming group as much as Season 1 did!  Game design: 5/5  Personal enjoyment: 5/5  Total: 10/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've always enjoyed Pandemic. The legacy much more fun. Every decision has the potential to affect a large number of games. I realize you'll only play it 12 - 18 times, but if you can get 2 or 3 people to play it with you for each of those times, it will definitely be worth it.

The only real downsides are that it can be a little difficult to remember all the new rules that are introduced as you play and that it really is better if you can get the same players in each session. The player aids and rules are good though, and even if you make a few mistakes, you'll have fun doing it.

Once completed, I didn't have any desire to revisit it, but it's still a memorable and enjoyable play experience.

RATING: 5
Well, we only got up to May before deciding to call it quits. Too many rules piling up. Too many options. Too many things to remember not to forget. Frankly, it was starting to feel like a chore. My buddy and I are going to spend the next session just opening stuff up to see how the story plays out.

By all means, don't discount all the glowing reviews. This may be something you love. But we just could not take it anymore.

As far as the game being disposable -- as long as you know that going in, what's the problem? Don't buy it or play it if that's a deal breaker. I don't know what all the stupid fuss is about.

RATING: 9
Tells a fantastic story that is subtly (and not so subtly) different for each group. The permanent changes give each decision weight and heft and encourages a deep meta game, where you are desperate for certain characters to live, willing to allow certain regions to fall in order to save others and may even consider throwing individual games for the good of the campaign. Keeps everyone totally engaged. A great experience.

In that sense I would say the legacy format was a great encouragement to return to the game over a period of a few months.

RATING: 8.75
Extremely well designed experience. We scored 772 out of 1000. So I think we did pretty well overall. Wish they gave more indication on a few of the scoring things at the end before hand, but the score isn't really the point of the game.

Highly recommended to everyone who can get a group together to play through the whole game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I started off hating the "legacy" concept; to me, it is nothing but CRM (cardboard rights management); a way to stop used-sales and make you rebuy the same game multiple times. To me, if the game is any good, I'm going to want to play it again - and not to spend another $50 to do so!

However, I really wanted to try a campaign version of Pandemic, so I decided to go ahead and try this. The first impression is that an awful lot of effort was spent on this "legacy" concept that adds nothing but component complexity to the game.

* Game play on an individual scenario basis was good, with a nice variety of objectives and different situations.
* Campaign elements were weak. Late in the game we had a hard time picking upgrades because there just wasn't anything useful to get.
* Plot elements were awful. There are several that I not only can't stand in a game (or usually even in fiction), but they happen in rapid sequence. Probably the most ticked-off I've ever been at a boardgame.
* Everything bad that happens is permanent and solid. Everything good is abstract and temporary. Even if you win every game, it feels like you are constantly losing. Never once had a feeling of success in the game.
* Feels mostly like passive entertainment. All the important decisions and actions are made by the NPCs. We're just along for the ride and to "watch" the (truly lousy) plot.

+co-op+

RATING: 7
I think Pandemic Legacy is a great game. In terms of game mechanics and theme, I think this is close to a 9 or even a perfect 10. If you love Euro boardgames, I in many ways think Pandemic Legacy is a game you should at least try once in your life.

Though that is also my problem with the game. It is a game that I at least, cannot see myself ever playing again. And its not that you destroy the board, but also that I wouldn't be interested in playing with another group. Because what makes PL good are the surprises and curve balls that Legacy add to the mix, and if you know what those surprises are, the game is really not all that more interesting than Pandemic, which is a good game, but not great.

RATING: 9.75
Ratings (1 to 5):

Simplicity: 4
--> Straightforward, though there are a few thorny rules to remember as the game progresses and adds new components

Depth: 3
--> Requires proper strategy and tactics to play the game optimally, but this game is on the light side

Player Interactivity: 5
--> Constant communication and coordination with other players to achieve your shared goals

Theme: 5
--> Feels like you are there saving the world!

Fast-Moving: 5
--> Little downtime between player turns, as actions are small and fairly obvious

Replayability: 5
--> Love how the game constantly evolves and changes over its 12-18 game lifespan

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
OK, so take a solo game that masquerades as multiplayer and add legacy mechanic.  Now, you can pretend that it's not a solo game 12-24 times before you throw it away.  Yay! (Hive mind game; easy to determine optimal play each and every turn.  No mechanics to give any particular player any reason to play each turn as other than a "group" turn.)  Also, whether or not a game is won or lost is often determined by random effects; how hard or easy any given game is can be based upon factors outside of the control of the players, so to some extent, your decisions can simply not matter.  You make the optimal play and hope randomness swings in your favor.  I have much more of a deterministic preference.

I'm not the biggest fan of co-ops, but if done right, they can be quite enjoyable.  This is another lazy implementation of co-op though just like its predecessor.  I'm victim to the hype machine all too often, and I get caught up in cult of the new probably as much as anyone else, but I just don't get this one.  And I don't hate on legacy systems either.  I'm often satisfied with a $60 game if I can get as few as 2 or 3 good plays out of it, but this game does too little to fix the main things I hate about Pandemic.

I can understand why some may like this game even though I hate it, but certainly there are enough design flaws to make me question how so many could consider this the best game ever created.  Many, many games are much more intricately and intelligently designed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Uitgeleend: Rob
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I find Daviau's "innovation" far less of a revolution than an elaborate marketing gimmick under the guise of "narrative board gaming."  The intrigue of the system wore off after about three games, and then it just turned into an obligation. I will almost certainly not be purchasing another one. 

The game itself was boring; the narrative derivative and cliche, and ultimately very, very stupid. About 70% of the way through, we just gave up and thumbed through the rest of the Legacy deck to see how the game was going to end. There were so many stupid revelations-- both narratively and gameplay-wise-- that I feel vindicated by the decision.

If I want real narrative board gaming, I'll play something designed by Cole Wehrle or Phil Eklund. They create narrative gaming experiences that put Rob Daviau to shame. And I can play it with rotating groups of players as many times as I want... and I don't have to chuck it in the trash when I'm done with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
So far two games in, and I am enjoying the game.  I wouldn't call it amazing or anything just yet.  But we'll see I guess.  Maybe it will be more amazing later.

It is compelling playing a game not knowing what is coming but knowing that something is.  You don't get that kind of experience from games very often.

2017-07: We've finally finished the game, and while I enjoyed the experience, it is mostly pandemic, with an overarching storyline.  Although many of the plot elements were interesting, and I enjoyed going through them.  In the end, during the final stretch, the game started to feel samey, and if it were a great game, that would be fine, but like I said, I wouldn't call it amazing.

RATING: 9
Tentatively set to a 9, after playing out the first two months in rapid succession. I immediately wanted to play the third game. So...that's a good sign.

I really like that the game changes pretty quickly, giving you the feeling of a living world that you're working to try to save.

Very entertaining.

Update: We've played through August at this point, and the game remains at a 9. We've had only one month which was a double failure.

Update 2: We've finished the game. Total score: 667 out of a possible 1000.  Very enjoyable, and I'd happily play again.

Also, I think it's still possible to use the board again for playing regular Pandemic on when you're done. Playing the last scenario again doesn't make any sense, given the results of playing December.

My rating remains at a 9. I'm considering getting another copy.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

I liked standard Pandemic quite a bit. It has always been a game that I enjoy and rated it quite high. Then I read about Pandemic Legacy and I HATED the idea. I hated the idea that a game would require destruction of components and become completely non-re playable. I immediately thought that this was a new conspiracy of game designers to copy protect their creations. I was emotionally dead set against this.

But I kept reading great reviews and comments about how this made a game I really liked even better. So after eating a few meals out with my wife that cost more than the game, I decided I could spend the money for the experience. It took me this type of comparison to get me to consider the disposable game as a experience rather than a possession.

I have read that tearing up a card is a cathartic experience, but even when the game told me too - I couldn't do it. So I missed that part of the experience as I carefully saved every item - hoping that I could somehow make the game non disposable. But in the end, after completing the game, I decided that it was not the thing to do and fulfilled my promise to my wife that I would not keep this game forever. (Did I mention that I do not like to let go of games.)

Even without the emotional catharsis of ripping cards, I loved the experience of the game. It added twist and turns to a game I already liked and kept us wanting to play until the end. It was sort of like combining a game with a good book, you want to see what the next chapter will bring.

After playing, I thought quite a bit about whether or not the designer could have made the experience the same without making the game disposable. I believe the answer is no, not without increasing both the expense and adding mechanisms and setups that would greatly degrade the experience.

I rated it a 10 because of the great experience, and that is in comparison to the other games I also like. Would I play again? Yes, in a heartbeat, but alas my copy is gone. But I would expect that playing again would be more like rereading a good book than the excitement of reading it the first time. If I had a different group to play with, who had not played before, I would be happy to join them as a silent partner to watch them savor the experience.

***no spoilers, but its also important to note that setup and takedown are different from regular Pandemic and those that know Pandemic should pay very close attention to this as it will make a big difference (for instance choosing where to start, what extras you want, etc, - that is done AFTER the board is set up which impacts things quite a bit. when the game is over be sure to read the next appropriate steps before putting things away as it can have a bearing on some additional decisions for the next 'months')

RATING: 10
We played it every night until we finished the season.  Very addicting, very fun.  The biggest downside is that once you've completed the season you can't play it anymore.  There were times when there was a feeling of urgency that you normally don't get from playing a board game.  We even grew attached to some of the characters we used along the way (we loved our super-medic).  With a lot of board games once you come up with a good strategy, you can usually stick to that strategy and have success.  The ever changing rules in this game forces you to change your strategy as you play, which is a good thing.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Combination of two of my favorite games/concepts and designers!

Finished the campaign this weekend (May 2016). This was an amazing experience. Combining my experiences with reading reviews has increased my depth of understanding of what I loved about the game. I also see what frustrated others.
It is worth considering the story arc of the game. January, we had all kinds of anticipation just by seeing the stickers that came in the game and options like cities panicking. But then, even midway through game one we had to deal with a change to the basic game rules and a changed disease! We mostly loved the story buildup and we liked that we were fighting "zombies" because it gave a B movie vibe and we don't like to think of the world actually ending by disease. We knew we were getting into a weird situation by teaming up with the military but the game gave us good reason to do it, just like a team of doctors who are over their heads with the situation. We worked hard to complete the first search, and that was a small misstep in the game creation; since the reward did not payoff. Then came the big reveal; we lost an important character, and cursed the game designers while enjoying the twisting story and the cool components of text to read. The later searches were a little better since they led to story development. We guessed we would be spreading cures and then doing a final hunt and then we were right. By the end, we are not even curing diseases! While we expected to December to have some kind of final hunt; it was difficult, but not the highlight. The highlight was the traitor reveal. So after August and the access to vacines, the game plays out on a downward trend instead of a final boss bottle. The December boss battle felt challenging but then worked out okay; thanks to the Binoculars cards. So the arc of the story has the biggest height in August or so. Not what we expected, but it did not bother us either.
Comments have people most upset about two things: the one time to search in October and the points taken off for not doing that. (200 points). There are more points also for not destroying military bases but less upset about that. Related to this, it is unclear if the final scoring works or not, and the final texts are a bit brief compared to the investment into the game, but we were not let down either.  We felt like our score and final story line matched our expectations. Other people upset about the whole stickering and game design are just not the main voices, even if they are vocal. Look this game is number one!

No reason to play the same board; ready to frame it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Reviewed on TheGlassMeeple.com
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]No major spoilers.[/b]

:thumbsup: What you sacrifice now will affect all your future plays. It becomes not only about how to win a game, but also about how to minimise the damage done in the long run. I think Pandemic meshed perfectly with the Legacy framework.
:thumbsup: We enjoyed it greatly with 2 players and didn't find the campaign to be too easy. We lost or almost lost enough times.
:thumbsup: The story is very good. It could be great if it was fleshed out a little more, with more text and some images, but for something you read entirely as card text, it still creates an impressive amount of immersion. And it's tied closely to the gameplay and decision making too. We often found ourselves trying to predict what will happen next in the story so that we can make the right choice now, and it wasn't always easy.
[b][color=green]------------------------------[/color][/b]
:?block: We played the Legacy game 17 times, plus 2 learning games. You cannot play this after you complete the campaign in any way intended by the design. Is the price tag too expensive for 12-24 plays? It's for you to decide.
:!block: Adding rule stickers to the rulebook/board and keeping track of how the rules change after every game is not something everyone can do easily. Make sure there's a player in your group who will be comfortable with keeping track of new rules.
:!block: With variable setup, introduction of new rules, and post-game upgrade selection we found that the games takes much longer than the stated 60 minutes.
[b][color=red]------------------------------[/color][/b]
:thumbsdown: Ultimately, whether you will like the game or not depends heavily on whether you like the gameplay of Pandemic or not. Legacy is an improvement overall, but it's still the same game at the core. I think I find Pandemic just a little too light/simplistic, and my rating for Legacy reflects that too.
:thumbsdown: I didn't like the pace at which new rules and mechanisms were added to the game. Sometimes it felt like we didn't have enough time to explore a game element before we had to move on.
:thumbsdown: Having 2 tries to win a month for December objectives means that the finale will be too easy and a little anti-climatic. There's no way we could have lost on our second try in December. I would rather lose in December period, than lose on the first try and then have the easiest victory ever on the second try.
:thumbsdown: Pandemic itself has a few non-thematic mechanisms, like for example the way players can exchange cards. Legacy does not improve those, and it also adds some relationship effects that are hard to justify thematically too.
:thumbsdown: There is scoring at the end, and the fact that it's secret makes you unable to make optimal decisions to maximize your score. In the end we were saying, "If only we knew that this particular thing will be scored!"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
geht nur einmal - dafür war es aber echt super!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It is not as testosterone driven as Risk Legacy. The story arc begins slowly and a bit less than halfway through it gets intense. The difficulty increases step by step, and so does rules complexity. The game also has mechanisms to encourage you to use the new abilities that are unlocked. I would probably not play through the game a second time, currently it seems like the game would be too easy if you knew which upgrades become important later on.

First I thought the game might be too easy, but in June/ July we lost three games in a row and we are struggling to keep things under control.

A few months later, we tend to win more often again but the story arc has made another turn and we expect unpleasant things to happen in the last months of the game. We will see. Also, the game balancing mechanism of funding will soon do its job: When you win games, you get less good event cards, so the next game will be more challenging. Oh, and a very good and really useful character died, so we will have to completely change our strategy.

The next months were a mix of insanely difficult and then rather easy months. In the end, the final was a bit anticlimactic but satisfying. 

If you are playing the game, my advice would be: Every life saved matters.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like many people I was very enamored with this game when I first played it. However, after completing the game rather quickly and looking back on it, I have to say it really wasn't all that great. It's good and I enjoyed playing it but it really feels like it could have been better. Branching paths would have increased the fun of this game immensely and would have aloud for more interesting replays with new boards. While I do plan to play a second game of it with a different group of friends I find I am less excited than when I started my second board in Risk Legacy, there just doesn't seem to be too much that can be different. I hope a lot of the people that have given this game such high ratings look back after they finish it and reevaluate their rating as right now I feel it is vastly over rated on BGG.

RATING: 9.9
WHAT - A - TREAT! It's the first Legacy style game I played and I'm loving it. Tearing cards apart feels a little strange still but I'm sure it'll grow on me. What I can say about this game is, for me, that it contains many "christmases" in a single box. The original christmas, where your heart beats because you're so eager to open the box and you have no clue about what's inside. Not the christmas where you have a list of of things you want and where you expect your personal Santas to get it processed. I'm dying to see what's behind the doors of the dossiers and what surprises still wait in the packages. I'm totally enarmored with what this game does with and for me. Plus the original Pandemic is a game that is very high on the immersive side in my book. This one tops it easily. The original Pandemic triggered my interest in cooperative games and while my interest abated in the meantime, Pandemic Legacy restored it. And it restored it with a bang!

RATING: 10
I think Pandemic is a pretty great game, and the Legacy experience elevates it in so many ways.  This is a fantastic campaign, which I played with my whole family. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
*Spoiler-free comment below*

I feel like I'm going to look back on this as a cheap stunt, just a way to get us to buy a more expensive version of an exhausted game by intentionally withholding certain elements until they come up during the game.

But goddamn is it fun. I'm not even the biggest fan of Pandemic in general, but this is just great.

One thing that it does to improve Pandmic, besides the obvious primal experience of getting to open new things from game to game, is it gives the game more focus. Now you have certain areas that might be more important from game to game. You have certain things that you might want to accomplish besides simply curing the diseases. You might prioritize a certain section of the board to avoid outbreaks because of permanent game effects that could potentially happen, instead of just going straight for the cure each time. If it becomes apparent that you're going to lose late in a game, you might even just try to mitigate as much damage as possible instead of even worrying about trying to win.

For me this adds a much-needed layer onto the Pandemic system. In regular Pandemic the decisions were mostly obvious. Legacy offers more to think about simply by having permanent repercussions.

I highly recommend this game. It could even be my game of the year, but 2015 has been an incredibly strong year for good games so I'm not sure yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
It's pretty good. Very interesting concept and the first Legacy game I've played. The mystery really gets you going and having a new element of the game to pay attention to every now and then adds an interesting twist. I have one major problem with it though, which is that it rewards failure and punishes success (the number of event cards goes up if you lose and down if you win). The month-winning bonus counteracts this a bit but I absolutely hate when games do this. I get that it is basically a necessity to keep the game balanced but that doesn't mean I have to like it. A comparatively minor complaint is that as the rules get longer and longer you inevitably cheat for or against yourselves. Unlike a normal game where you get the hang of complex rules after a few plays you can't get used to this game.

RATING: 7
I never really loved Pandemic. It was always one that I was willing to play if other people wanted to, but I'm not the biggest fan. I probably won't play again, but I wouldn't be surprised if other people did. $60 for at least 12 games seems reasonable for me. A lot of people hate the idea of a disposable game, but for  the experience, I'd say it's worth the money. I'm sure something may come along that does the Legacy co-op better, but for now, it's great if you're looking for a unique experience.

RATING: 5
Overall it's...fine. My gaming group just finished our first play through of May (which we lost), and at this point I'm kind of dreading finishing the rest of the campaign. The changing storyline of this one is interesting, but it feels like both a slog to get through the whole campaign and stressful to deal with the changing circumstances and ever-adjusting rule set. By the time we complete this campaign (if we do), this will be, by far, the game in my collection that I've played the most, but nowhere near one I've enjoyed the most. Ultimately I think I prefer standard Pandemic or Pandemic: The Cure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can't see ever giving Pandemic Legacy a 10, and I feel like the score may degrade with time. The narrative driven gameplay is interesting, but let's be real: the story is pretty bland until September. I think this game would've benefitted from an Above and Below style treatment with some more robust storytelling than a few cards could provide. Also, I don't think this should really be labeled as a two player game without the caveat that 2 people should play 2 characters each. Maybe it is just me, but I can't see ever playing Pandemic without the medic, so I rarely got to explore other options as none of the other characters comes even close in efficiency. I don't know; I enjoyed it well enough, but it didn't blow my face off like people seemed to imply that it would.

RATING: 10
Stellar design, and an amazing experience.

The 'legacy' element adds an extra layer of strategy to a game that is quite tactical by nature.

Being able to plan you approach for each 'month' and choose your characters/upgrades according to a long term goal is very unique experience.

An yes, what upgrades, what characters, what structures(and where you build them) matters a lot.

It's also one of the rare games where you want to 'win more'. Taking a riskier approaches to mission is rewarded with better/more upgrades for the next.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love campaign systems and I really enjoy Pandemic. Pandemic Legacy really felt it was designed for me. 

Having played a full campaign I can only say that is is by far the best campaign system I've seen in a board game and is exceptionally fun. 

The pros: Easy to learn, gets progressively (at a fine pace) more complex. Super fast setup for such a full of everything game. Zero downtime (if you consider each action a team action to be discussed, as we do). Great narrative, perfectly tough decisions thanks to the amazing deteriorating cities campaign mechanism. Legacy deck creates a great overlaying story that adds thrills, a few surprises and keeps all players guessing for what comes next but only for the first campaign playthrough. It's great fun to play, and the added complexity discourages the alpha player syndrome. Great sense of accomplishment from game to game, and amazing at the end of the campaign where the whole progress of the group is tracked. RP elements with great attachment to the game characters, which grow from basic roles to characters full of traits, scars, experience and stories to tell - you really want to keep them alive! The game is very difficult to fully beat (best outcome), especially in the first play through the campaign. Stellar variability and replayability as the possible effective combinations of the roles with the upgrades, relations, events and equipment is mindblowing, and the possible team strategies really a lot and diverse.* (but see also cons as to why replayability can't shine in this game)

Cons: The game may be greatly replayable, but most of the components are also disposible. Each box comes with enough for just a single playthrough the campaign, and the rules actually encourage that. This means that playing through the campaign a second time to have a second great time demands either a new copy of the game, or some preparation and customization that may seriously detract from setup and ease of play. The first play through the campaign does have some added difficulty due to the unknown story, second play through should be easier because of that but still not easy to reach total victory. The game difficulty is very deceptive, as the group may achieve its objectives repeatedly and think all is good while the world is getting ravaged, when in fact they should be looking to prevent the world from being slowly destroyed which is the most important thing in the game, makes total thematic sense, is what counts in the end but may still elude some players as it's not "in the current objectives". Finally and despite the many supporting mechanisms that try to balance things, lost games really make the campaign much harder (again, even if it's not apparent for new groups), while won games make the campaign easier, though that's not by a wild or gamebreaking margin.

Overall the Pandemic Legacy succesfully introduces a campaign to the Pandemic game, and the result is absolutely amazing. Playing while knowing that your current decisions will affect all future plays effectively transforms your 90min experience to a ~1500min experience that is played in episodes (months) and can be easily saved. If you thought f.e. that Mage Knight was epic, with its 200-250min memorable experience think again. Pandemic Legacy is easily 6-7 times more epic, while retaing better easy of play and much faster setup. Now imagine a Mage Knight with a similar campaign system, and come and try and convince me that the "Legacy system" is something we should discourage.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
By far the worst part of this game is that the directions are VERY poorly written. Every month we spend far more time trying to figure out what the rules are then we actually spend playing. If you (foolishly) decide to play anyway, MAKE SURE TO CHECK THE FORUMS FOR RULE INTERPRETATIONS BEFORE YOU READ THE GIBBERISH THAT COMES WITH THE GAME. Even once you have the rules figured out for one month, it's difficult to remember what they are throughout the game because the so many things change from game to game (the rules don't change all that drastically, but they DO change strategy considerably, so even if the rule change isn't that huge, its importance usually is). The actual game seems okay at best, but it's not nearly good enough to make up for all the frustration of trying to figure out the rules. Other annoyances include: 
- It has a million little pieces that are hard to keep track of. 
- It's designed to only play through once (which is one or two games each for 12 "months").

RATING: 7.5
There were many reasons I wanted to try this. First, I'm a fan of Pandemic and have a couple of expansions for the original game. Second, I've been intrigued by the Legacy format for a while now, and really want to discover all the secrets and have a game where surprises crop up. Third, this game is getting a lot of praise and recognition and so I wanted to experience what everyone was getting so excited about. And lastly, Rob's in my game group and up till now I'd never played any of his games and felt a little guilty about that.

So I asked a couple of people if they wanted to go in on a copy and what do you know, but a pandemic just happened to break out right then and there. So I won't post many (if any) spoilers (although only being two games in it's not like I know a ton of them yet anyway).

The first game is basically a way for people who don't know Pandemic to get up to speed. There's some new stuff and you'll quickly discover some new twists after the first game. It's still got the feel of original Pandemic, so if you didn't love that game, I don't know that this will do anything to change that. But if you like Pandemic, this is definitely an interesting addition that throws you some new things and makes for some interesting decisions.

After we finished our first play, everybody really wanted to play again, so we doubled down on February, which was a cakewalk for us. We managed to eradicate two diseases and came close to eradicating a third. That fourth disease and those darned red cubes though...

One of the most important things with a co-op is getting a good group together, as the game is made or broken by the group interaction. Our group is having a blast and I'm really looking forward to the rest of the campaign. I can't wait to play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
About [thing=161936][/thing]:

[b]1) What is it?[/b]
[thing=161936][/thing] is a cooperative game fundamented in an older design ([thing=30549][/thing]) and based in the legacy format - which means that things done in previous plays have effect  (changes and additions, both in rules, game state and on the board itself) in sequential plays.

The legacy format also have unique surprises - as it builds a campaign in almost a TV series sort of way: throwing curve balls at the players, surprises, new characters and new situations. Not only this: the bad stuff also stays, which means that characters can die, places be taken by riots, collapse and fall completely to the disease, making them almost unreachable.

However, [thing=161936][/thing] isn't an open world. It isn't a RPG sand box, where anything can happen at any time and the path is in the hands of the players. No. It isn't also exactly like a TV show, in which you are just the viewer, unable to participate, just watching the plot unfold. [thing=161936][/thing] stays in the middle ground - it is akin to a gamebook: all the elements of the story were already written (put in the box), but the path you will make, while not completely free - you must pick paths already made, see situations previously thought - the whole thing, in spite of not being all up to you, feels like your own and unique path, a one of a kind journey, similar to others, still (almost) never quite like them.

Therefore, [thing=161936][/thing] is a board game equivalent of a gamebook, with an evolving and emerging story, with twists and turns, with surprises and mysteries ahead, strengthened by an already proven and well-liked design. All put together made for huge hit.

[b]2) How do you play?[/b]
Players have 4 actions per turn, and most of these will involve moving (in several different ways) and removing diseases. All players use characters with special abilities. The usual goal is to prevent outbreaks from happening, while trying to get enough samples (cards) in order to develop cures for the diseases.

The game is lost when there are too many outbreaks, the draw deck runs out or all the cubes of a color are on the board. Players win when all the cures are found.

This is the basic [thing=30549][/thing]. Differences will occur.

[b]3) Which are the decisions made during play?[/b]
How to best use the available 4 actions each turn. How to best coordinate with everyone else, in order to control the spreading of the diseases, to prevent outbreaks, to build research facilities, to share knowledge, and other possibilites.

Unlike most board games, the developing campaign and legacy format puts a weight to every decision as its effects can ripple into later plays. This spice things up and make the decisions harder to make, which is good.

There are also decisions made [i]in between[/i] plays, like most games with campaigns - what to add, who to play with, which thing will benefit the most? This part, more often than not, is what takes PL apart from [thing=30549][/thing].

[b]4) What are the good things in the game?[/b]
- Very good production quality;
- Campaing with a developing story;
- Mysteries and surprises throughout the plays;
- Difficulty adjusted by the game itself;
- The legacy format makes the players more engaged in the single plays and with the overall arc.

[b]5) Which are the bad news?[/b]
- Limited replay value for the mysteries;
- Luck of the draw can have big effects on plays;
- Alpha player allowance.

[b]6) How do you feel while playing?[/b]
In a constant Christmas mood - opening boxes with excitement on the heart and gleaming eyes, alongside a sticker fest. I do love stickers - I remember when I got a model airplane, with several stickers to put on it. The building of the model was too much for my young age, so my dad took care of it, but I was responsible for the stickers - not all turn out ok and in the proper place, but my fun was the same regardless. I still, as and adult, like to put stickers on things - it simply [i]feels right[/i].

Now, many people talked about how they feel regarding the limited number of plays in the campaing of [thing=161936][/thing]. There were many saying is simply too much hype, too high rating and too expensive for a game one can play under two dozens of times and be done with it. Several others pointed out that many games with high replay value keep these in store, being played rarely and, most definitely, less than the projected maximum number of plays of the PL's campaign; and some added that PL can be played as regular [thing=30549][/thing], with some adaptations, once the campaign is done.

How do I feel about it? I don't really care. One of my all time favorite game is [thing=2511][/thing], and this one has around half the amount of plays PL have. For me, it isn't the amount of games I can milk from a game that interest me, it is the experience I got from each of them. Sure, if a game allows for truly amazing experiences and has a high replay value, even better! But it seems that the limited life (much like the real one) helps bringing a sense of keener enjoyment, of savouring every detail, of looking with wonder to every nook and cranny. The senses and emotions are heightened. Maybe this plays a part in [thing=161936][/thing] shooting up the charts and ending up as the #1 game here in BGG - not in spite of its limited plays, but [i]because of it[/i].

The gameplay, for the most part, is vanilla [thing=30549][/thing], but put in a much more colorful and exciting frame. Still, there are many changes - the more months pass, the more is the game state different. Some major rules suffer tweaks.

This is great, overall, both to attract new players that aren't interested in [thing=30549][/thing] (due to the differences and legacy format), and also those that do like [thing=30549][/thing] (due to the similar mechanisms and feel of play). Yet, we had a problem: we found that [thing=161936][/thing] is best suited for constant plays in a small frame of time. Our three person campaign started december 5th of 2015, and ended in april 18th of 2017. This meant long hiatus of play, and once we returned, re-learning all the tweaks and differences was a chore, and usually something was overlooked (like forgetting a possible action during play). Sometimes we even grumbled a little at the ideia of returning to the campaign, knowing that we would had to freshen up rules and passed events - what had happened thus far. Our play style and commitments simply weren't best suited to enjoy [thing=161936][/thing] in its fullest state - and its attractiveness wore off, as opening packs and dicovering new things on it weren't exciting enough when they were cold in the shelf for months.

Coupled the less than ideal experience, we also found the story lacking. I saw many comparing the campaign and the legacy format and the closest an RPG can get from a board game. Is likely true. Still, the unfolding story was pretty weak, the writing subpar, with cliches and repetitiveness creeping in - and the end is simply lazy; if it was an awful thing, maybe due to trying to make it to grandiose or epic, I could forgive it; but the laziness and its unfufilling nature is much harder to excuse. Anyway, the board game format do help in lessening this weakness, since the mechanism take over and the story goes on the back sit. This would be a weak RPG adventure, a bad film and a terrible novel. In the end, what bothered me the most was the wasted opportunities - using the legacy to truly make unique experiences of gameplay, not just "I got red, you got black", with many of the major plots happening at the same time regardless of what is done.

I understand the limitations of the physical world: it isn't feasible to produce endless paths, cards, tokens, etc, to accomodate all possibilities. In an RPG the narrator swings something from the sleeve to carry on; on movies or novels the writer just conducts the plot; on a videogame the digital for more freedom, but is still limited. Yet, a few additions and changes, like in a pick-your-path gamebook (which would make a finer comparison with the openess of a campaign in board games than RPG), would make the experience be better. A simple: if you did X, that make Y. There is some of this, but not enough to change the story and lead it to difference places.

Overall, [thing=161936][/thing] started as a big promise and went into the disappointment territory. We considered it to be better than regular [thing=30549][/thing]. as it gives reasons to return to it: an unfolding story, surprises, twists, tweaks and changes. I like campaigns and the legacy format, as I have an RPG background (playing since '95, mostly as DM) and want thematic and memorable experiences in my gameplay. [thing=161936][/thing] opened the path, but is still all muddy and uneven; it is matter of waiting for someone to take the path and turn it into a proper road to awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love the concept and some of the execution. But I'm sorry to say that as a two-player game it was laughably easy at the beginning (new developments happened only at the end of a play and had little direct effect), and ridiculously tough near the end. It's still Pandemic but I think for two players, I prefer On the Brink.

RATING: 9

The story the game takes you along is extremely well thought out, and works so well.

It's been designed to be very tight, and events and circumstances happen which will test you, but the game never becomes impossible.

Truly worthy of the hype.  The only negative is that it has limited play...but you can still play Pandemic on it at the end of it.

I can't wait for next season!

RATING: 9
