=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Legacy games are a hard sell, even to boardgame enthusiasts. Do you want to have a finite number of times you can play the game you just bought? And especially in the case of Pandemic Legacy; the game you just dropped $100+ on?

But when a game can pull off what this one can then the answer is yes, yes you do. 

The format allows for such tense rounds, so many genuinely shocking surprises and that very pure kind of excitement you experience when you get to UNBOX THE HIDDEN THING!

Pandemic Legacy also enjoys the benefit of having SUCH a strong game to build from. Pandemic is a staple of this hobby for a reason. It's approachable, yet challenging. It's thematic and evocative and yet abstracts enough of itself to not bog its players down. It is a natural fit for a campaign, and the designers show such confidence in their decisions on how much to shake things up (and how frequently to do so). 

This game has generated such intense hype, and it was catapulted to number one on BGG (and was only just bumped down by Gloomhaven at the time of writing). But in what is a rare case; this game earns all the praise it has received. It is just as exciting an experience for new and veteran gamers. Grab a group and go in on it together, and enjoy one of the best and most unique boardgames on the market.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is a truly impressive production, the narrative in this game is unlike anything we've seen in the board game world before, and it is a superb accomplishment.  While I am a fan of the legacy mechanics, I'm not a big fan of Pandemic, so I was curious to see if the Legacy aspect would make a significant enough impact.  All in all, the gameplay is just Pandemic where a few extra rules are added occassionally.  By the end it does become quite bloated and it is tough to remember everything that happened.  Some say that playing this game is like being inside a TV drama, but I have to disagree.  The story in the game isn't nearly as immersive as the hype would have you believe (if you're looking for immersive story, play an RPG instead).  It is, however, an extremely unique and creative group experience.  If you like Pandemic and have 4 players that can consistently get together, this is a no-brainer.  I like it and plan to finish it, but I am still waiting for a Legacy game that suits my tastes better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Simply fantastic!

RATING: 2
We really, really did not enjoy this game. We were a bit 'Meh.' until April / Box 3, when the entire narrative arc turned to sh!t—and never recovered. Had Box 3 never opened, the game would merely have been disappointingly mediocre in terms of narrative & mechanics, but with a disease mutated into [redacted, but message me and I'll tell you] the game becomes a joke.  

We only made it through by treating it as a joke, a sort of "Bad B-Movie Legacy", to compensate for the trope-ridden, formulaic & obvious narrative and the manipulative & game-breaking mechanics changes introduced & later counteracted by the Legacy deck.

My disappointment was only enhanced by the hype and secrecy surrounding the game—if anyone with taste had remarked on the plot, or if the [redacted] had been spoiled, my expectations would have been appropriately tempered. Alas, I trusted the people who were so happy with the Legacy revelations that their excitement & secrecy had me fooled into remaining un-spoiled.

RATING: 10
Play this. 

It's unlike anything else I've played so far. Completely worth the investment of time and money.

Has what no other game does: closure. 
I don't have the time needed to play all my games to satisfaction, such is the renaissance of gaming that we are living in. However, knowing that this one has an end coming, that we can "complete" it, is exhilarating for me. It makes every play session more meaningful and intense. The way the game changes and evolves with each success and failure is simply beautiful.

Give it a go.
Worth it.

Don't like the idea of not being able to play it once it's finished? Fair enough, probably not your thing. This is a new concept and it is fair to object to a change in the conventions of gaming... if you are... the kind of person that doesn't like.. new things..? 
Literally can't understand why this is a problem.

The only problem with this game is that it makes me want to play vanilla pandemic less and less.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I know this game is getting great reviews, I understand why a lot of people like it, but I just cannot get behind it...

The game is divided into months, each month is a game session, you have one year to cure the disease.  If you fail a month, you are given a single second chance each month to re-do it.

But..  This game just does everything wrong for me.
Firstly: It's a public knowledge co-op game, meaning your team is only as good as its dumbest player.  Which for me translates to "Oh it's a solitaire game!  Like Forbidden Island, Xenoshyft, and XCOM."

Secondly: It's non-replayable, similar to Risk Legacy but cranked up to 11.  With Risk Legacy, the first 15 games shape the map, then you can just play on the completed map if you want.  With this, once you've played the 2-24 required sessions (each roughly one hour) it's over, you're done, buy a new box if you want, but it'll be the same story.

Third: It's $70.

So, if you really have a bad time, you can be that person who drops $70 to buy a non-replayable game, only to have to throw it out after 2 hours.
If you're a lucky or skilled person with a good team of enthusiastic players, you'll get about 16-18 hours of enjoyment out of it.  For $70.

This could be the game for you after you divvy it up, (18 hours gameplay, $70 game, 4 players playing, roughly $1/hour per player for fun)
but it's not the game for me.  Had I been the person to pay for it, it simply would have made me horribly depressed I just spent so much money only for it to be something non-permanent.  Even worse so if a nice but slow-witted player ruined it for everyone by making it a 4-6 hour purchase that we never got to see the end of.

That's a good place for a closing note:  It's a board game where if you don't beat it: either buy a new one and start over...  cheat...  or just pack it back up with that niggling doubt you'll never be able to complete it, because it's designed that way...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This was fantastic. It's only really good for a single playthrough, but I think that it's such a compelling experience it's worth it.

RATING: 2
While at first Pandemic Legacy seems like a step forward for the legacy style games it's actually two steps back. The same story plays out whether you win or lose each month and the different hero upgrades don't really add any abilities that didn't exist in either the pandemic base game or one of its many expansions. Unfortunately Pandemic: Legacy just rehashes the same old pandemic mechanics.

RATING: 8
Pros: cooperative legacy game, highly thematic, roleplaying with special skillsets in a legacy setting, highly tactical, varied game objectives in a legacy setting

Cons: prone to quarterbacking, high degree of luck, high number of minor rule changes related to legacy setting means looking up rules before each game

This is the only legacy game I have ever played, and as of January 2018 my gaming group and I are only halfway through the game. Every time I play it, I am simultaneously struck by the ingenuity of legacy mechanics and overwhelmed at the minutiae of rule changes between each game. I dread each set-up, as I have to go through the rulebook each time and make sure we are not missing something important. For this reason alone, I do not rate this game higher. However, during and at the end of each game, I'm also ready for the next one. It's amazing what a simple, ongoing narrative does to an already fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We blasted through this campaign quickly. It's an elegant design that integrates a great narrative into an already excellent co-op game. Highly recommended.

I do think that it is at the pricier end of things considering the lack of replay value. We also made a couple of (relatively minor) rules errors which was frustrating as there was no real way to 'roll back' our play-through. 

The legacy system is great and we certainly had a lot of fun, so felt like we had our money's worth. I actually found it quite liberating to mark and even destroy components. BUT I do think that there could be ways to achieve similar results (using apps for example) without permanently damaging/ altering the components. 

These are all minor nit-picks about a fantastic overall experience. This is certainly a step forward for table top game design. I look forward to seeing what comes next!

RATING: 8.5
Enjoyed this one. Would happily play again with a different group, though it would be a changed experience knowing the plot. Looking forward to Season 2. That said, I'm unsettled about the notion of use-once games -- not because I don't think this game is deserving of the money for the experience it offers, but because I see its success establishing a dangerous trend among games publishers who see this a means to increased revenue.

I suppose I should take solace in the fact that mediocre legacy-style games won't be played the requisite number of times for the purchase of a second copy. In that case, I guess my quibble may be self-correcting.

RATING: 6
This game definitely is susceptible to the alpha gamer problem.

I generally dislike cooperative games, partially because of the alpha gamer problem, and partially because the solitaire aspects can make a group's AP problems worse.  

Even though I generally don't like coop games, I've decided to play this with my group anyway for 3 reasons:

1. It's now the #1 game on BGG
2. The Legacy aspects are interesting
3. My friends in this game group are fans of coop games, and I know that they'll make it fun.

My rating of a 6 is pretty much my ceiling for a standard coop game.  Non-standard  coop games are games like Hanabi where the alpha gamer is not a problem, and they are not subject to this ceiling.

[-] replayability is low (of course), ~17 games, 1h each; I'm not a huge fan of pandemic, I think the gameplay is a bit repetitive and "old fashioned"; didn't like the way positive events are integrated (as a catchup mechanic), sometimes it was better to loose 1/2 scenarios on purpose to strengthen the deck for the harder scenarios (with research); still quite a bit of randomness
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I had very high expectations for this game. My wife and I both love base Pandemic, especially when the On the Brink expansion is added in. And all of the reviews that we had read/watched gushed about how good Pandemic Legacy was. But, unfortunately, it did not quite live up to the hype for me.

In this particular case, I think a pros and cons list is the best way to deconstruct my thoughts about the game.

PROS

--The bones of the game are solid. Base Pandemic is in my top 10 games and my wife's top 10, so we enjoyed having that as the starting point for this game.

--I enjoyed being able to try out modules and characters from some of the expansions that we do not currently have. In fact, we might purchase one of the expansions to the base game because of our enjoyment of its modules that cropped up in Legacy.

--I thought that the funded events were a relatively clever way to increase or decrease the difficulty of the game (but see the counterpoint in the cons section).

--I really enjoyed how some of the end-game upgrades enhanced the experience (especially some of the character upgrades).

CONS

--The story was not *nearly* as good as it could have been. After completing the first few months, I thought I could see an interesting direction that the story could have taken, but instead it seems that the designers decided to play it safe and retread tired ground (at least in the board game context).

--While we only lost twice, I could definitely see how a group with more losses could not recover solely with funded event cards. The brilliance of the base game is that you can make it easier or harder by removing or adding epidemic cards to the player deck. For Legacy, they should have instituted a rule whereby if you lose more than, say, two games in a row, then you have the option of either adding two funded events *or* adding one funded event and removing an epidemic card. (There should probably be a minimum number of epidemic cards that need to be in play, but at the same time, a group that has lost three or more times in a row needs something besides two additional funded events.)

--Whenever a certain mechanic was introduced, we usually did our best to take full advantage of it. Unfortunately, that meant that some of the drama/tension that could have happened in certain months (e.g., December) was not realized. Of course, we struggled from time to time throughout the game, but the overall intensity of the game was not as pronounced for us as it perhaps should have been.

--I thought that some of the months were rather monotonous, because new objectives were not introduced. Generally speaking, I feel like the objectives should have changed more depending on how well you did throughout the campaign.

--This was essentially covered in my first point, but the conclusion of the game fell flat for us. It was neither an interesting resolution to the various problems in the game, nor was it true to the spirit of Pandemic.

FINAL ASSESSMENT

Overall, I did enjoy playing Pandemic Legacy: Season 1, but I would probably not replay it, and I have little to no interest in playing Season 2.

Rating: 8.5/10

RATING: 8.06
In the end I'm happy that I played through this game. Pandemic is one of my favourite coop games (though I do not tend to really love many coop games) and initially through the first 3-4 months I had a really good time. However as the 'season' went on, I started to feel a little exhausted by the whole thing. Some negative points:
- Some of the mechanics introduces approximately half way - and during the second half was really dull.
- I didn't connect to the story at all. In all honesty though I think 'stories' in the board game industry as a whole still has a lot to go on. 
- The ending was probably the most anti climatic ending I have ever witnessed in any form of media.

I recognize it is a good game and I would recommend it if people asked. But I'm in no rush at all to play season 2.

I also was a tad disappointed that the story unfolded regardless of any choices made by the players - branching pathes with multiple endings would have been really cool.
I am glad I've played this one and it is memorable, but I did not enjoy the last four or so sessions half as much as I enjoyed the game round about the middle of the campaign.

RATING: 6

Also the legacy element is silly and unneeded, it could easily just have been created as a normal replayable campaign game.

I expected much more from the high ratings, but it's still an okay solo experience.

RATING: 8
I’ve been itching to break out Pandemic Legacy since I’ve been hearing so many good things from many reviewers. I can say that they weren’t wrong. You’re still playing vanilla Pandemic to some degree, but pretty quickly your objective changes and the situation is not what you’re expecting. The game does a good job of taking a pretty boring game system and making each game of it novel and different. It’s the difference between reading a book that you’re having a hard time finishing (Pandemic) and a book where you want to read just one more chapter (Pandemic Legacy).

However, should this game be the number one game on BoardGameGeek? Well, it’s not mine, but I am happy that Twilight Struggle isn’t number one anymore. It’s a fantastic game, that’s for sure, but it’s also a three hour, two-player, political, card driven war game, not something I’d want someone new to the hobby jumping into.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game was awesome! I already fell in love with Pandemic (especially the In The Lab expansion) and I was so stoked that the legacy version was set to come out on my birthday. So, of course, I had to get it.

My wife and I played the game through in only 4 days. We definitely binge-played one Saturday for like 8 hours. The game kept us hooked as to what would happen next.

At first we were both hesitant about making permanent changes to the game, never having played a legacy game before. But we found that it was exhilarating to know that the actions our characters took and the decisions we made had lasting effect in the game.

Overall, the storyline of the game was intriguing and kept us immensely interested in what new challenges lie ahead. Even developing a strategy was something we could do differently almost every month of the game.

The only reason I would not give this game a 10 is due to how it ended. Since we are only able to play this game once through, I wish the ending would have been more satisfying. It's like when your favorite TV show is unfolding in such an amazing way and then suddenly it ends, introducing a brand new element that seems only vaguely related to what has happened so far.

The point system unveiled at the end to determine how well your team did in saving the world was a real bummer. If you somehow miss out on one of the last two objectives in the very last month (December), your score is greatly impacted. (This is what happened to us). Also, had we known that what we were doing would have certain point values attached, we would have pursued objectives differently with known priorities. I am sad that there is a way to end this game without definitive closure (call it a personality thing) on whether you won or lost. Based on what our board looks like, I think we should have won, but the point system told us that it was a work in progress, which totally left us hanging without a sense of defeat or satisfaction in victory. It was just blah. It's over.

Don't get me wrong. We had tons of fun throughout the whole time we were playing. However, when something so good has a poor ending, it kind of leaves a bad taste in your mouth. I hope that when Season 2 comes out, they adjust something in regards to how it ends and how your team wins or loses overall. I would happy to provide suggestions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We played a 2 player game over two weekends and finished with 10 wins and 7 loses.

Was a unique experience which we enjoyed.

Could not give it a higher score due to lack of re-playability. Also games that I have rated higher we enjoy more generally speaking. They also come the additional bonus of being able to be played over and over again.

I would not rate vanilla pandemic more than an 8 (have it on the iPad), so the legacy tacked on experience does help push the score to a 9.

Will definitely be interested in playing season 2 when it comes out, but I see no point in keeping season 1 my self.

RATING: 8.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best tabletop gaming experience ever. Brilliant and unexpected story turns--in retrospect we should have predicted but it is much more fun to just let the story happen to us. Brilliant inclusion of various tactile reveal experiences when it was time to add something new. Love the feeling of sacrelige from defacing the game (which we soon got over and relished with childish joy). A handful of jaw dropping moments. The looks on our faces was priceless. The importance of each action.  Total commitment, total respect and focus. No one wanted to let the team down. We felt sick as a personal failure for each outbreak, each riot, each infected city. What a profound moment when you realize you are actually considering sacrifices of segments of the population for the safety of the rest of humankind. The only minuscule distraction was the other player quarterbacking at times but that was mostly from dramatic moments with everyone fully engaged. I can't think of another game that has brought a group of friends together to share such a special experience. The only thing that comes close was the first years of Magic.

RATING: 10
One of the finest boardgames even contrived by the likes of humankind. We were absolutely engaged during every game of the year and would routinely play back-to-back. So unique and so well designed and playtested. I have no idea how ZMAN can manage that with a permanently changing landscape, but they did it. Only thing to be warned about is that there are tons of rules and then, as you play, there are more. Having someone come in for a "cameo" that hasn't played from the beginning is really tough for them. Best to get your group lined up and stick with those folks the whole time. Work of art!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Picked up on clearance at Go! Calendar store the day after Christmas 2015.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
At the halfway mark (mid-June), the future is dark.  We've only won 4 of 9 games, and we're a single loss away from having to open package #8, the pity package for four-time losers.  The red sector is an oozing carbuncle that's fading into the twilight, with a torched research station acting as a beacon of failure and most red cities at panic levels two, three, or four.

Suicidal thoughts notwithstanding, the game has been great.  We've been willing to play as many as three games in a row, which would never happen with the original.  The Legacy aspects are top-notch, though occasionally overwhelming to track.  Particularly the new rules, which require a quick review before every session.

Our initial thought was to play two games per night every two weeks, but life's intrusions pushed that plan aside.  Now we're stuck playing once per month - though still two games at a time - which has interrupted our momentum and made it difficult to re-immerse ourselves in the experience.

I'm still extremely happy with our decision to only play four-player games, and always with the same people. That vow will never be broken, which has significantly enriched the experience for all of us.  Swapping people in and out of the campaign would be a real drag, for a multitude of reasons.

A tip for new players: The order of set-up is significantly different for Legacy than for the original.  The board is first seeded with disease cubes, then events are chosen, and then finally the characters and starting location are selected.  That's important.

Finally, for those worried about game disposability...

I'm guessing that we'll need to play ~18 games to finish the full campaign (i.e., we'll fail every other month and need to repeat those months).  I've probably only played 10% of my games 18+ times, so this actually makes Pandemic Legacy one of the most cost-effective purchases in my collection.

[i]Update:[/i]

We finished the campaign (Sep-Dec) in a marathon six-hour session at the 2016 WBC in its new Seven Springs location.  Absolutely fantastic game, but we screwed up badly by forgetting to open window #30 until it was far too late, which we only realized when the legacy game components started referring to terms and concepts that we'd never heard of.  By then, it was mathematically impossible to win the final month and all of our efforts had gone to naught.  :(

Final score: 442, which is surely an all-time record in the wrong direction.  21 total games played.  We did OK in the beginning, terrible in the middle, and very well at the end.  Until we hit a disastrous December.

As far as campaign stumbles go, one of my fellow disease-fighters said it best:  It's like each month introduced a brand new expansion, making it impossible to keep everything straight.  We regularly made rules errors that affected the game, although we did the best we could under the circumstances.

Still, I loved the experience and am anxiously awaiting Season 2.  We were never forced to open package #8, despite a deluge of fallen red cities. It's just too bad that there was so much pressure to get all of the new rules correct the first time through, since there were no opportunities for rewinding time to fix misunderstandings or unintentional omissions.

RATING: 9
Phenomenal game in every aspect.  The reveals, the permanents, and the gameplay are all captivating.   Recommended for all gamers, and highly recommended for anyone who enjoys Pandemic.

Just one caveat, which is the only reason I gave it a 9 and not a 10: Make sure you go into this with a group of 3-4 people who can get together to game *at least twice a month*.  Ideally, play this with roommates who you can play with multiple days a week.  We made the mistake of going into this with a group that only gets together once every 2-4 months, and it is very difficult to get back into the swing of things each time, refreshing ourselves on all of the changing rules, etc.  It's best to knock out the entire game (12-24 games played) in less than a month if you can.

RATING: 8.5
No Spoilers Included in Comments Below!

Sure, after 16 Games (for us) it's over, and we won't be playing it again. But it was a ton of fun. Enough so that we'll likely pick up Season II sometime this Fall/Winter. A very enjoyable experience, and for the $35 we paid for it (on sale), it was worth every penny.

RATING: 6
I like Pandemic, and at first this version really increased the tension because of the permanent effects. Players are a lot more emerged. Was very enthusiastic after the first few games, but later on the setup became more fiddly. 

Then we figured out we had made some major rule mistakes. The most important one was just something we overlooked in the rules, but others were due to weirdly worded texts on cards, or got lost in the deluge of small rule additions, and translation errors that plague the Dutch version. 

In the end, we were disappointed with the overal experience. Though we had some great new experiences, the last few games felt more like chores with the longer setup and additional rules to keep track off. And most of those rules did not add a lot of the experience of the game.

RATING: 2
Legacy adds elements that make Pandemic way too fiddly and is more about using stickers to reduce bookkeeping between games.  I'm not convinced the Legacy treatment is the better version of this game mechanically, and it feels noticeably easier.  The game sort of happens to you and choices don't matter in the grand scheme of things.

The biggest letdown is the "theme" and story.  We couldn't pull ourselves to finish the season, though we committed to playing through July.  PL's story reminds me of every popular serialized drama on TV - falling into the same tired tropes with no reason to stay engaged.  The big "reveal" was met with tired groans and the rolling of eyes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good game, but I like regular Pandemic better. There are some game months that I found quite boring and I felt a bit sour having to go through those. Those segments distracted too much from what I like to do in Pandemic: running around saving the world by curing diseases. I loved the first half of the game, but the 3 quarter fell really flat for me. After the plot twist, the game grabbed my attention again and I like the finish.

Still, I would rather advice people to take a look at vanilla Pandemic then Legacy season 1. The primary reason behind this, is that for Pandemic Legacy you very likely want to play the whole game through with the same people, which can become a hassle. With vanilla Pandemic, you can always drop down a game to play with anyone.

When it comes to recommendations, here are mine:
1. Most important: make sure you can get the same people to play the game with you on a regular basis.
2. If you intend to play with 2 players, have everybody play 2 characters instead of one. Having each player play a single character makes the game significantly easier and it'll cut some content away.

RATING: 8
"It's over. It's finally over." This is probably my most love hate game experience ever. My first legacy, but not my first one-time-play game (Time Stories and Unlock).

From the beginning I was in love with it, "it's Pandemic but with a story! and I can rip things apart!" Later on, it got a bit repetitive, but still, overall I liked it a lot.

The the very last game we discovered that we played one rule wrong, throughout the whole thing, not in our favour!! And we lost that game (December, 2 try) by one turn! We just restarted it and won the (out of the rules) third game. We felt the need for it!

Now I have a conflict in my head: What shall I rate Pandemic Legacy, considering that I gave 8.5 to Pandemic?! Sure, they are different games, but they are also very similar. And that duality is what makes is complicated. In one way, "it's Pandemic, but with more!" in another "it's just Pandemic, with more".

Edit 26-06-17: I gave it 8 (0.5 less than regular Pandemic). In the end it was for sure a memorable experience.

Edit 31-07-17: I now lowered my rating of Pandemic to 8, but I'll leave Legacy at 8 also, since the system and the "wow" moments make it this good.

RATING: N/A
Pandemic Legacy is a co-operative campaign game, with an overarching story-arc played through 12-24 sessions, depending on how well your group does at the game. At the beginning, the game starts very similar to basic Pandemic, in which your team of disease-fighting specialists races against the clock to travel around the world, treating disease hotspots while researching cures for each of four plagues before they get out of hand.

RATING: 10
It's Pandemic so it's already going to be great. The legacy system will probably never find a better game to take on than this one. We're only a couple months in but I can already tell this game will be something I never forget. I scoff at those complaining about the "limited" number of playthroughs. I only own a few games that I've played more than I'll end up playing this one and most of those I've grown a bit tired of. Even if you are a person who plays a game hundreds of times the value for money here is still incredible. An $80 game that plays an average of 16 times is a $5 per play experience that has incredible story telling and is a once in a lifetime type experience. There may be a lot of games in any one persons collection with even better value to money than this but it doesn't invalidate the bargain you are getting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The two of us burned through this one like it was a Netflix series. I found it really entertaining but I'm not throwing "game of the year" laurels at it. The legacy elements are interesting but people tend to over-egg the quality of the story which I thought was serviceable but nothing really original or special. The feeling was not really one of immersion into a story but more of playing Pandemic with ephemeral expansion content. Now that it is done I have little desire to play it again, I wouldn't get another season 1 box.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Legacy might be the best game I've ever played. I'm okay with the lack of replayability because the experience of beating it was incredible. We made so many memories.

If there's an issue here, it's the pure level of chaos. You have to keep track of dozens and dozens of papers, rule changes, characters, and exceptions at one time. We definitely screwed up some rules; a few of these mistakes made the game much harder, and a few of them made the game much easier. We also got unbelievably lucky in 3 or 4 straight games. January through April killed us, but we coasted through the rest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Such an exciting game, and so tense! Every month brings something new to the table and changes the game in some subtle and some not-so-subtle ways, but Pandemic Legacy is always a blast! I want multiple copies just to share with all of my different groups of friends! This game is beautiful. 

EDIT: I've become Pandemic'd out, so this game holds little interest for me anymore, as do any other versions of Pandemic. Definitely not a bad game, but I just don't really care for it anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really enjoyed the game because I love Legacy games but I was a little disappointed.  Story line is too linear because the hidden content gets flipped in order and is pushed more by how many games have been played than anything else.  Something like Risk Legacy that unlocks happened more often from events that could happen at anytime I felt was much more interesting.

I feel the first half of the game was more thought out than the end.  Felt like it started dragging on a bit at the end and evolved a bit less.

All that being said it is one of my favorite games because a disappointing Legacy game is better than most other games.  Leaves you wanting more and slowly builds complexity.

[Update:  I bumped down my rating on this a half a point for re-playability.  I own multiple copies doing multiple campaign's and after finishing the first campaign I don't find myself excited to play more because it is so story line.  Risk Legacy I still would play any day and still think about playing years later.  This is great for one time through but loses its magic after the last game for me.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Have now played this with two separate groups. The first, a 4-player group, the second a different 5-player group. Both enjoyed it immensely and we are now eagerly awaiting Season 2, due in mid-2017. 

Although the game states it plays 2-4 it plays 5 no problem with a couple of house-rules that I've documented under the Pandemic Legacy pages. 

The way the game unfolds is brilliant and there were only a couple of items we found a bit too theatrical/Hollywood and therefore distracting, but not so much so that it detracted from game play.

Having now played through twice we're all up for a bit of a rest until Season 2 drops :-).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Első 3 játék: Áhhh, nincsenek szavak. Zseniálisan vitték tovább az előd gyökereit, az alapokat megtartva, de mégis annyi újítással, hogy minden vele töltött percét megéri, még akkor is, ha már 100+ alkalom van a sima Pandemicben.
---
+4 játék: Tovább tudták fokozni a dolgot. Megint bejött pár újdonság, ami nagyon illik a játékba és teljesen megváltoztat mindent. Ja, és megvolt az első kártyatépés is. :)
---
+3 játék: Eszméletlen mit ad ez a játék. Nincs még egy ilyen hozzá fogható.
---
+3 játék: Oké, nyilván történt megint egy olyan dolog, h hűha, csak fogtuk a fejünket. Továbbra is nagyon izgalmas, nagyon jó, simán hozza egy körömrágósan izgalmas hollywoodi film hangulatát.
---
Utolsó 3 játék+összegzés: További meglepetések a végére, viszont katarzis nincs a legvégén. Itt igaz, h nem a cél a fontos, hanem a megtett út. Minden egyes perce maga az élvezet, a nagybetűs társasjáték ez. 
-------------------------------------------
Egy évvel később újra elővettük, immáron a magyar változatot. Továbbra is fantasztikus élmény, még ha a főbb csavarokra emlékszem is. Ez továbbra is egy páratlan társasjáték!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As opposed to Risk: Legacy, which I found to be Rogue-Like (Some clan development and world alterations). It ends up being an adventure that changes very little with no definitive end.

Pandemic Legacy is more like a TV show. Forcing you to play only two games in a month shuffles you through the narrative the authors have planned out. Interesting in that you can fail at the end of the game.

RATING: 8

Update after finishing campaign [no spoilers] : 

The good : game gives you new small gameplay elements to play with, therefore every session stayed fresh and offered something new to do, a bit of character progression, game balance was preserved throughout game 

The mediocre : the story 

The bad : the aweful dutch translation full of critical errors

Does the game deserve spot 1 ? Nope totally not , it's good and would recommend to play it but it didn't feel fantastic, grand nor innovative, just good.

RATING: 7
Definitely put in a 6th epidemic if you're an experienced Pandemic group. It's got less cool reveals than I expected, kinda thought they'd do more with it, but maybe that's an effect of having played Pandemic + On the Brink a bunch. It is a little addictive wanting to see what happens next.
=============
UPDATE: Just finished, overall a neat experience. One of the mechanics introduced later didn't excite us that much, but things got harder as the game progressed which made it fun to deal with, burning through various powers and options to squeak in the win. In the end we used a 6th epidemic in 4 of the games (starting roughly half-way through), as a step up from zero funding. But in the last few months we lost a few games so it was back down to 5 epidemics.

RATING: 9
Hard to rate. Hard to compare with other games I've given a 10, like Galaxy Trucker, Cosmic Encounter, and Netrunner, where I've played 100's of games and they still hold up to the test of time. On the other hand, I think the quality of the experience is just as good, and in some ways better than those games.

It's not flawless, but I'd probably rate it a 10 if it were more replayable. As it is, I'll dock it a point for it having a static ending while still highly recommending.
